description: Becoming a Linux Power User is a technical skills course designed to elevate viewers to "Power User" status. Linux provides a very robust and powerful platform that enables users to achieve great things. Unfortunately, most users only scratch the surface of what Linux is capable of. This series explores some of the more powerful functions hidden away behind the graphical user interface. Topics cover using terminals and shells, managing processes and files, and writing simple shell scripts.

episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.181
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.181 --> 00:00:06.526
Hello, thanks for watching.

3
00:00:06.526 --> 00:00:11.422
Becoming a Linux power user is an exciting
course we're offering here at ITPRO.TV,

4
00:00:11.422 --> 00:00:13.911
and to tell us more
about that is Don Pezet.

5
00:00:13.911 --> 00:00:16.460
Hey, Don,
tell us what is exactly the course?

6
00:00:16.460 --> 00:00:20.940
>> This is a pretty neat course, because
it is designed to get users introduced to

7
00:00:20.940 --> 00:00:23.160
how powerful an operating system Linux is.

8
00:00:23.160 --> 00:00:25.740
A lot people hear about
the Linux Operating System and

9
00:00:25.740 --> 00:00:26.750
they wanna learn more.

10
00:00:26.750 --> 00:00:29.540
They go and they install it, they get
a nice little graphical user interface.

11
00:00:29.540 --> 00:00:32.450
And they give you the basic things that
they're used to from other operating

12
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:37.580
systems like Microsoft Windows and
MAC OS and operating systems like that.

13
00:00:37.580 --> 00:00:39.580
But you hear about how powerful it can be.

14
00:00:39.580 --> 00:00:42.530
All this extra stuff, and
you don't immediately see it.

15
00:00:42.530 --> 00:00:43.230
So in this series,

16
00:00:43.230 --> 00:00:46.180
what we're trying to do is pull back
the veil and give us a chance to look

17
00:00:46.180 --> 00:00:51.032
at some of the really cool things you
can do behind the scenes, and it's hard.

18
00:00:51.032 --> 00:00:53.830
It's a challenging stuff, it's not stuff
you can just figure out on your own.

19
00:00:53.830 --> 00:00:56.880
So, getting a change to get
a guided tour through some

20
00:00:56.880 --> 00:00:59.560
of the powerful back-end
features inside of Linux.

21
00:00:59.560 --> 00:01:02.170
Is a really great thing to do,
especially if you're getting started.

22
00:01:02.170 --> 00:01:05.580
And that's exactly what this episode,
or this series, is all about.

23
00:01:05.580 --> 00:01:08.950
>> Now, who would benefit most from
watching, becoming a Linux power user?

24
00:01:08.950 --> 00:01:12.180
>> Well, mostly it's going to
benefit people who are new to Linux.

25
00:01:12.180 --> 00:01:13.880
If you've worked with Linux for
a long time,

26
00:01:13.880 --> 00:01:17.000
if you've been using it in the field,
you may well already know these topics, so

27
00:01:17.000 --> 00:01:18.270
it might be a little boring to you.

28
00:01:18.270 --> 00:01:22.060
But if you're just getting started it
is really daunting, really challenging.

29
00:01:22.060 --> 00:01:25.010
And instead of getting intimidated and
just going back to Windows or going back

30
00:01:25.010 --> 00:01:28.770
to Mac OS, here is the chance for you to
take that time to learn the features,

31
00:01:28.770 --> 00:01:30.940
get used to it, understand how it works.

32
00:01:30.940 --> 00:01:34.510
So if you're just getting started
with Linux, if you are a desktop

33
00:01:34.510 --> 00:01:37.980
support engineer, if you are a systems
administrator, that you're gonna

34
00:01:37.980 --> 00:01:41.340
be managing the Linux Operating System,
this is good knowledge to learn.

35
00:01:41.340 --> 00:01:45.290
And what we're gonna see in this series
pertains to servers as well as work

36
00:01:45.290 --> 00:01:47.820
stations, so
if you're working in either environment,

37
00:01:47.820 --> 00:01:49.290
you'll benefit from this series as well.

38
00:01:49.290 --> 00:01:51.900
So, it really does cover
a good group of people.

39
00:01:51.900 --> 00:01:54.840
>> Now, is there a certification
available for this course?

40
00:01:54.840 --> 00:01:58.000
>> There are a lot of really good Linux
certifications that are out there,

41
00:01:58.000 --> 00:02:00.950
many of which cover some of the topics
we're gonna cover in this series.

42
00:02:00.950 --> 00:02:03.150
But this series isn't really
built around a search.

43
00:02:03.150 --> 00:02:06.930
So there's no exam based on this content,
for what we're creating here.

44
00:02:06.930 --> 00:02:10.230
This is really focused, not to get you
a certification to get you a job, but

45
00:02:10.230 --> 00:02:14.950
to get you comfortable with Linux and
becoming that power user.

46
00:02:14.950 --> 00:02:17.360
So we tackle exactly what
we think is pertinent and

47
00:02:17.360 --> 00:02:20.290
relevant to a power user
to get you to that point.

48
00:02:20.290 --> 00:02:23.180
On one hand, it's really nice because
that means we're not saddled by

49
00:02:23.180 --> 00:02:24.470
a list of objectives we have to follow.

50
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:26.710
We get to hand pick what
we think is important.

51
00:02:26.710 --> 00:02:29.410
On the other hand, it's a little more
difficult to kind of show on the resume.

52
00:02:29.410 --> 00:02:32.660
So what a lot of people do is watch
a series like this to get started.

53
00:02:32.660 --> 00:02:35.583
And then move on to do things
like CompTIA's Linux+ or

54
00:02:35.583 --> 00:02:37.650
the LPIC-1 certification.

55
00:02:37.650 --> 00:02:40.680
Those certifications cover a lot of
the topics that we're gonna see here

56
00:02:40.680 --> 00:02:41.500
in this series.

57
00:02:41.500 --> 00:02:44.140
But they're not mirrored up exactly,
so these here won't get you ready for

58
00:02:44.140 --> 00:02:45.070
those exams.

59
00:02:45.070 --> 00:02:47.930
>> So what are some of the topics
covered in becoming a Linux power user?

60
00:02:47.930 --> 00:02:49.530
>> All right, we've got quite a few and

61
00:02:49.530 --> 00:02:53.510
the very first topic's probably the most
important one, which is using the shell.

62
00:02:53.510 --> 00:02:55.320
When you first launch a Linux desktop,

63
00:02:55.320 --> 00:02:57.570
you're gonna see
a graphical user interface.

64
00:02:57.570 --> 00:03:00.000
And a graphical user interface is
something you can stumble through and

65
00:03:00.000 --> 00:03:00.660
figure out on your own.

66
00:03:00.660 --> 00:03:02.800
You just click around until
you find what you want.

67
00:03:02.800 --> 00:03:06.290
But the shell, when you drop to
the command line there is so

68
00:03:06.290 --> 00:03:08.890
much more you can do,
but it's so much harder.

69
00:03:08.890 --> 00:03:10.640
And you can't just stumble around and
figure it out.

70
00:03:10.640 --> 00:03:11.820
So we're gonna learn how to use the shell.

71
00:03:11.820 --> 00:03:14.460
We're gonna learn how to
navigate the Unix and

72
00:03:14.460 --> 00:03:18.090
Linux file system, which is very
different than the Windows file system.

73
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:20.920
We'll talk about how to work
with text files, because almost

74
00:03:20.920 --> 00:03:24.790
all of the Linux Operating System
configurations are stored in text files.

75
00:03:24.790 --> 00:03:27.525
We need to know how to manipulate those,
and edit, change them.

76
00:03:27.525 --> 00:03:29.710
Then we're gonna take a look
to how to manage processes,

77
00:03:29.710 --> 00:03:32.860
how to run applications,
how to make them perform better,

78
00:03:32.860 --> 00:03:36.610
how to stop them if they're not performing
right and manipulate how they work.

79
00:03:36.610 --> 00:03:39.023
And lastly, we're gonna learn how
to write simple shell script.

80
00:03:39.023 --> 00:03:43.232
Shell scripting is really where a lot of
the power of the Linux Operating System

81
00:03:43.232 --> 00:03:43.944
comes from.

82
00:03:43.944 --> 00:03:48.530
The Linux OS was designed by
developers for developers.

83
00:03:48.530 --> 00:03:52.080
And it's evolved a lot since then, so
that now it's good for everybody to use.

84
00:03:52.080 --> 00:03:55.560
But if we know how to do a little bit of
development, we could take advantage of

85
00:03:55.560 --> 00:03:59.170
that and really streamline our
workflow by using shell scripts.

86
00:03:59.170 --> 00:04:01.220
So that's what we'll take a look
at at the end of the series.

87
00:04:01.220 --> 00:04:02.260
>> Well, thanks, Don.

88
00:04:02.260 --> 00:04:05.040
Now, if this sounds like something that
you'd be interested in, and it should,

89
00:04:05.040 --> 00:04:09.220
you should check out all the episodes in
the Becoming a Linux Power User series.

90
00:04:09.220 --> 00:04:15.384
Thanks for watching.
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss terminals in a Linux environment. They look at X-Term, GNOME, Terminator, and Guake. They explain the difference between preferences and profiles, and demonstrate configuring various aspects of a terminal.
episodes.title: Terminals and Shells
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:01.443
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your Host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:01.443 --> 00:00:07.314
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.314 --> 00:00:09.612
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:09.612 --> 00:00:12.267
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.267 --> 00:00:15.513
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here in ITProTV,

6
00:00:15.513 --> 00:00:20.023
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing becoming a Linux power user.

7
00:00:20.023 --> 00:00:23.706
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be taking a look at terminals and

8
00:00:23.706 --> 00:00:26.720
shells, and talking about
the differences in what we do with them.

9
00:00:26.720 --> 00:00:30.596
And here to explain that to us is Mr.
Don Pezet, welcome Don.

10
00:00:30.596 --> 00:00:31.618
>> Hey, thanks for having me, Mike.

11
00:00:31.618 --> 00:00:35.790
And we're kicking off our series
on becoming a Linux power user.

12
00:00:35.790 --> 00:00:40.182
And nothing says being a power user
more than dropping down to a shell and

13
00:00:40.182 --> 00:00:41.289
getting to work.

14
00:00:41.289 --> 00:00:44.994
The graphical user interface
in Linux is optional.

15
00:00:44.994 --> 00:00:47.822
On a server,
you're likely not gonna have the GUI.

16
00:00:47.822 --> 00:00:50.457
But even on a desktop
where you do have the GUI,

17
00:00:50.457 --> 00:00:54.187
the really powerful functionality
is not in a button somewhere.

18
00:00:54.187 --> 00:00:56.317
It's not in a little switch you flip.

19
00:00:56.317 --> 00:00:59.883
It's dropping to the terminal and getting
your hands dirty with the real meat and

20
00:00:59.883 --> 00:01:00.993
potatoes behind Linux.

21
00:01:00.993 --> 00:01:02.280
And so that's what we're
gonna be taking a look at.

22
00:01:02.280 --> 00:01:05.190
But in order to do that,
I kinda know how to get there,

23
00:01:05.190 --> 00:01:07.120
so we'll take a look at that
right here in this episode.

24
00:01:07.120 --> 00:01:11.388
>> Yeah, this is gonna be fun cuz I've run
a few distros of Linux, and it's true,

25
00:01:11.388 --> 00:01:15.150
you fire it up, and you've got this
pretty desktop environment, and

26
00:01:15.150 --> 00:01:18.639
you really feel no different than
a Windows user, for example.

27
00:01:18.639 --> 00:01:20.194
>> Yeah, [LAUGH]
>> It's like, wait,

28
00:01:20.194 --> 00:01:21.020
where's the good stuff?

29
00:01:21.020 --> 00:01:23.513
And that's what we're gonna do now.

30
00:01:23.513 --> 00:01:24.519
>> Even the Mac OS, right,

31
00:01:24.519 --> 00:01:29.326
you guys have seen I use a Mac on some
shows when I'm doing Mac virtualization.

32
00:01:29.326 --> 00:01:32.265
And when I'm on Mac OS
it's a super simple GUI,

33
00:01:32.265 --> 00:01:36.320
it's designed to be really easy to use and
what do I end up doing?

34
00:01:36.320 --> 00:01:39.190
I end up dropping to a shell most of
the time cuz it's BSD under the hood and

35
00:01:39.190 --> 00:01:40.570
that's what I'm used to.

36
00:01:40.570 --> 00:01:43.784
So I'll drop down to that and
do things cuz it's faster for me,

37
00:01:43.784 --> 00:01:46.028
that when you learn how
to do things by hand,

38
00:01:46.028 --> 00:01:49.200
a lot of times you can do it way
faster than you could in the GUI.

39
00:01:49.200 --> 00:01:54.650
And you can absolutely do repetitious
tasks insanely faster than in the GUI.

40
00:01:54.650 --> 00:01:57.388
So there's a lot of power to be
had by working in that shell, but

41
00:01:57.388 --> 00:01:59.145
if you've never used it before, well,

42
00:01:59.145 --> 00:02:02.266
this is gonna be the first step on
your journey to becoming a power user.

43
00:02:02.266 --> 00:02:05.239
You need to get used to the shell,
used to running commands, and

44
00:02:05.239 --> 00:02:08.177
learn how to get help,
learn how to figure out how things work.

45
00:02:08.177 --> 00:02:11.040
So that's what we're gonna be taking a
look at here in the next couple episodes.

46
00:02:11.040 --> 00:02:11.770
>> All right Don, well,

47
00:02:11.770 --> 00:02:14.600
I guess the first thing we need to do
then is really talk about the difference.

48
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:18.166
Cuz we said terminals, we also said shell,
and I know a lot of people,

49
00:02:18.166 --> 00:02:21.138
when they're getting in Linux,
aren't those the same?

50
00:02:21.138 --> 00:02:22.310
Or they think they're the same?

51
00:02:22.310 --> 00:02:24.848
>> A lot of people think they're the same,
but they are indeed different right.

52
00:02:24.848 --> 00:02:27.665
So, a terminal and
shell are two different things.

53
00:02:27.665 --> 00:02:31.280
So the shell is actually
a little program that runs.

54
00:02:31.280 --> 00:02:35.250
And the program is allowing
you to talk to the kernel.

55
00:02:35.250 --> 00:02:37.933
You can issue commands,
the kernel receives those commands and

56
00:02:37.933 --> 00:02:39.433
does something with them, right.

57
00:02:39.433 --> 00:02:42.640
So the shell is obviously very
important that's who we wanna talk to.

58
00:02:42.640 --> 00:02:44.760
But, how do you even see the shell?

59
00:02:44.760 --> 00:02:48.110
Well, the terminal is what
lets you see the shell.

60
00:02:48.110 --> 00:02:50.840
Then you can actually visually
with your eyeballs see it.

61
00:02:50.840 --> 00:02:52.125
I shouldn't say with your eyeballs.

62
00:02:52.125 --> 00:02:53.418
Cuz you might have a braille keyboard or

63
00:02:53.418 --> 00:02:55.072
other attachments that
let you interact with it.

64
00:02:55.072 --> 00:02:56.990
Those are different types of terminals.

65
00:02:56.990 --> 00:02:59.890
Terminals can be software or
even hardware terminals.

66
00:02:59.890 --> 00:03:02.835
That name terminal actually comes
from the old mainframe days, right.

67
00:03:02.835 --> 00:03:07.441
In the old mainframe days,
you had a massive computer somewhere.

68
00:03:07.441 --> 00:03:10.691
And then on everybody's desk you didn't
have a computer you had what was

69
00:03:10.691 --> 00:03:11.870
called a dummy terminal.

70
00:03:11.870 --> 00:03:16.610
And it was called a dummy terminal
because it didn't do it's own thinking.

71
00:03:16.610 --> 00:03:20.260
It was a monitor, a keyboard,
maybe a mouse usually not even a mouse.

72
00:03:20.260 --> 00:03:21.678
So a monitor and a keyboard and

73
00:03:21.678 --> 00:03:25.379
it was displaying information that was
actually coming from the main frame.

74
00:03:25.379 --> 00:03:26.784
The main frame was doing
all of the thinking.

75
00:03:26.784 --> 00:03:29.480
The terminal was just letting you see it.

76
00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:35.470
And in the terminal, you would see a shell
that was running on the mainframe.

77
00:03:35.470 --> 00:03:37.990
And so now you're interacting with that,
that's the two different pieces.

78
00:03:37.990 --> 00:03:41.290
Now, back then, the terminal was
a physical piece of equipment.

79
00:03:41.290 --> 00:03:46.167
Nowadays, the terminal is just as
likely to be virtual as it is physical.

80
00:03:46.167 --> 00:03:50.862
Now, technically when I log into my laptop
and I see this graphical user interface,

81
00:03:50.862 --> 00:03:52.670
this is a terminal, right.

82
00:03:52.670 --> 00:03:56.500
It's running a display server and
it's got a window manager on top of it so

83
00:03:56.500 --> 00:03:58.460
I see graphics and prettiness.

84
00:03:58.460 --> 00:04:01.673
But there's an actual terminal
that's running in the background.

85
00:04:01.673 --> 00:04:03.145
Let me show you what I mean.

86
00:04:03.145 --> 00:04:08.710
So if you look at my desktop, what I'm
looking at here is technically terminal 7.

87
00:04:08.710 --> 00:04:12.820
That there are seven terminals
created on most distros.

88
00:04:12.820 --> 00:04:15.012
It's up to distro,
they create 1000 terminals if they want.

89
00:04:15.012 --> 00:04:17.612
But most of them are settled on seven for
some reason.

90
00:04:17.612 --> 00:04:21.766
[LAUGH] I don't actually know why,
but this happen.

91
00:04:21.766 --> 00:04:25.630
But when you fire up the Linux kernel,
it's not a GUI.

92
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:27.360
It's not all this crazy stuff.

93
00:04:27.360 --> 00:04:29.817
That's not the way that Linux
was originally designed.

94
00:04:29.817 --> 00:04:33.056
It was all designed in command line.

95
00:04:33.056 --> 00:04:35.378
So when you fire it up,
it's the display server and

96
00:04:35.378 --> 00:04:37.810
the window manager that
generates all this, right.

97
00:04:37.810 --> 00:04:42.962
On your keyboard,
if you're on the Linux machine,

98
00:04:42.962 --> 00:04:47.877
you can hit Ctrl+ Alt, so
you hold Ctrl and Alt and

99
00:04:47.877 --> 00:04:51.058
then hit F1 through F5 or F6.

100
00:04:51.058 --> 00:04:54.702
And what those will do is they'll move
you between the actual terminals on

101
00:04:54.702 --> 00:04:55.418
your system.

102
00:04:55.418 --> 00:04:59.884
So I'm gonna hit Ctrl+Alt+F1 and
my screen is gonna go blank for

103
00:04:59.884 --> 00:05:02.860
a second and then, there we go, all right.

104
00:05:02.860 --> 00:05:08.120
This is Linux, this is me logging into
my operating system, and it's really

105
00:05:08.120 --> 00:05:11.890
small because I've got a high resolution
screen and this is a simple text.

106
00:05:11.890 --> 00:05:14.453
But you log in and
you punch in your username and

107
00:05:14.453 --> 00:05:17.298
you punch in whatever your
password happens to be.

108
00:05:17.298 --> 00:05:22.030
And once you're in, now you start working
with the system and interacting with it.

109
00:05:22.030 --> 00:05:24.688
You're in a shell, I'm accessing a shell.

110
00:05:24.688 --> 00:05:30.328
I see the shell, but
I'm using a terminal, I'm using TTY1,

111
00:05:30.328 --> 00:05:35.346
my first terminal on this
system to get connected, okay.

112
00:05:35.346 --> 00:05:38.897
As I continue to use the system,
I might run a program here.

113
00:05:38.897 --> 00:05:44.474
And then I could hit Ctrl+Alt+F2 and
it takes me to another terminal, okay.

114
00:05:44.474 --> 00:05:47.753
And it's really small on the screen
I can't really highlight it.

115
00:05:47.753 --> 00:05:52.815
But up there in the top it says
Ubuntu 17.04 Dons-laptop TTY2, right.

116
00:05:52.815 --> 00:05:59.360
So I'm in TTY2 and if I go back to
Ctrl+Alt+F1, this one says TTY1, right.

117
00:05:59.360 --> 00:06:02.030
TTY is actually short for teletype.

118
00:06:02.030 --> 00:06:05.856
And this was built around the same
technology that was used for

119
00:06:05.856 --> 00:06:11.390
the original teletype machines to be able
to hook a keyboard up to a phone line and

120
00:06:11.390 --> 00:06:12.020
to communicate.

121
00:06:12.020 --> 00:06:15.923
That if you know anyone who's hearing
impaired, they still use TTYs today that

00:17:31.890 --> 00:17:33.900
>> It's the stone wash terminal.

346
00:17:33.900 --> 00:17:37.800
>> My favorite is the light grey text on
the white background, which kills me.

347
00:17:37.800 --> 00:17:42.240
I don't work for Apple,
I don't wanna lose my eyes before I'm 50.

348
00:17:42.240 --> 00:17:48.890
So, what you'll find is that most
terminals have preferences and profiles.

349
00:17:48.890 --> 00:17:52.810
Preferences change the way that
the terminal itself works, and

350
00:17:52.810 --> 00:17:56.050
then profiles change the way
that the terminal looks.

351
00:17:56.050 --> 00:17:59.880
And you'd kinda set up custom profiles
that are quick and easy to switch between.

352
00:17:59.880 --> 00:18:02.510
Preferences, you can only set one way,
profiles,

353
00:18:02.510 --> 00:18:04.870
you can create more than one profile and
easily switch.

354
00:18:05.880 --> 00:18:08.910
You might have one profile for
when you are at work and one profile for

355
00:18:08.910 --> 00:18:11.970
when you are at home or one profile
when you are on your laptop screen and

356
00:18:11.970 --> 00:18:15.140
another profile for when you are on
the big monitor on your desk, right?

357
00:18:15.140 --> 00:18:18.600
You can set those up so easy but
preferences, they are just set one way.

358
00:18:18.600 --> 00:18:23.420
So when I'm in my terminal here,
if I go to the file menu and I look,

359
00:18:23.420 --> 00:18:27.110
I'll see New Profile right there
where I can create a profile.

360
00:18:27.110 --> 00:18:29.970
But if I go under Edit,
I'll see Preferences and

361
00:18:29.970 --> 00:18:31.770
Profile Preferences, right?

362
00:18:31.770 --> 00:18:34.710
So preferences are on the terminal itself.

363
00:18:34.710 --> 00:18:38.781
And we'll see options like
whether we'll show the menu bar,

364
00:18:38.781 --> 00:18:42.860
what keyboard shortcuts we support,
what profiles exists.

365
00:18:42.860 --> 00:18:46.390
I've got one right now called unnamed
cuz apparently I haven't named it.

366
00:18:46.390 --> 00:18:48.110
What encodings we support.

367
00:18:48.110 --> 00:18:50.040
And if you're in the US you don't
have to worry about this cuz it

368
00:18:50.040 --> 00:18:51.240
defaults what you've got.

369
00:18:51.240 --> 00:18:55.740
But if you're in China, they have a very
different encoding, so you need to

370
00:18:55.740 --> 00:18:59.430
come in and set that to what will render
characters on your screen properly.

371
00:18:59.430 --> 00:19:04.340
Or if you're in Russia, Macedonia, places
like that where they use the cyrillic

372
00:19:04.340 --> 00:19:08.300
alphabet, you need to make sure
that you update to reflect it.

373
00:19:08.300 --> 00:19:13.370
So, these are settings that affect
the terminal itself, right?

374
00:19:13.370 --> 00:19:17.200
And then, if I close that and
I go back up to my File menu and

375
00:19:17.200 --> 00:19:19.820
I'm gonna choose New Profile, right?

376
00:19:19.820 --> 00:19:23.620
I can create, Don's Custom Profile.

377
00:19:25.210 --> 00:19:29.650
And this might be Don's desktop,
or Don's laptop or

378
00:19:29.650 --> 00:19:32.690
whatever, whatever it is I intend
to use this profile for and

379
00:19:32.690 --> 00:19:36.100
then in here I can adjust things like
what size I want the terminal to be.

380
00:19:36.100 --> 00:19:37.628
It defaults to 80 by 24,

381
00:19:37.628 --> 00:19:41.523
80 columns by 24 rows cuz that's
what the old dummy terminals used.

382
00:19:41.523 --> 00:19:43.282
Well it's not 1984 anymore.

383
00:19:43.282 --> 00:19:44.496
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can go ahead and

384
00:19:44.496 --> 00:19:46.726
bump this higher if you want,
it'll fit on the screen.

385
00:19:46.726 --> 00:19:49.289
Or you can leave it and
just make your font size bigger,

386
00:19:49.289 --> 00:19:51.330
which what I normally end up doing.

387
00:19:51.330 --> 00:19:53.760
It's got cursor shape,
whether we do the terminal bell.

388
00:19:53.760 --> 00:19:55.510
You know when you get an error or
whatever to go ping!

389
00:19:55.510 --> 00:19:57.490
You can turn that on and off.

390
00:19:57.490 --> 00:20:01.310
And then you'll see here
where I can do a custom font.

391
00:20:01.310 --> 00:20:03.530
The default on this one
is Monospace Regular.

392
00:20:03.530 --> 00:20:05.099
It may or may not be that way on yours.

393
00:20:05.099 --> 00:20:09.554
And then it's a 12 pitch font, well 12
pitch is a little bit small on this screen

394
00:20:09.554 --> 00:20:12.150
so I might wanna come in and bump that up.

395
00:20:12.150 --> 00:20:15.900
I'm gonna go 18, so I'm gonna bump
that up to an 18 pitch font and

396
00:20:15.900 --> 00:20:19.270
that mono font is fine but
you might want something different.

397
00:20:19.270 --> 00:20:22.200
Mono space is great cuz things
always renders out the same width.

398
00:20:22.200 --> 00:20:25.348
But there are other fonts like Courier,
well Courier's monospace too.

399
00:20:25.348 --> 00:20:30.760
Like, what's an example of
one that is not, it's like,

400
00:20:30.760 --> 00:20:36.620
Sands Serif or something like that,
that is a variable width.

401
00:20:36.620 --> 00:20:40.340
Like the letter I is thinner than
the letter M, but in a monospace font,

402
00:20:40.340 --> 00:20:42.080
the letter I is the same
width as the letter M.

403
00:20:42.080 --> 00:20:44.040
They kind of follow that pattern.

404
00:20:44.040 --> 00:20:48.295
But I can set that, and that's being
said inside of this profile, and

405
00:20:48.295 --> 00:20:51.182
so when I launch terminals
using this profile,

406
00:20:51.182 --> 00:20:54.807
they'll now have an 18 pitch font,
they'll be larger.

407
00:20:54.807 --> 00:20:59.238
And I can go to like the colors tab and
I can change the way the coloring is done.

408
00:20:59.238 --> 00:21:01.960
I might want to do green and
lack like the old terminals.

409
00:21:01.960 --> 00:21:04.660
Well, I might want to go
something different, right?

410
00:21:04.660 --> 00:21:08.882
Black on white, where it's black text
on a white background, or vice versa.

411
00:21:08.882 --> 00:21:10.625
We can do, is white on black in here?

412
00:21:10.625 --> 00:21:13.200
Yeah, white on black,
where it's white text on black background.

413
00:21:13.200 --> 00:21:16.050
You can define the bold coloring and
other color pallates.

414
00:21:16.050 --> 00:21:18.628
You can set all these options,
all really customizable.

415
00:21:18.628 --> 00:21:21.924
This is also where that annoying
transparent background setting is.

416
00:21:21.924 --> 00:21:24.904
A lot of people think that's really cool,
like, I want it to be transparent,

417
00:21:24.904 --> 00:21:25.830
it looks neat.

418
00:21:25.830 --> 00:21:27.100
Well, here, let me show you.

419
00:21:27.100 --> 00:21:33.350
So if I go in here and
pull up a new terminal,

420
00:21:33.350 --> 00:21:38.090
and what I did is, I went to File > Open
Terminal, and I chose my custom profile.

421
00:21:38.090 --> 00:21:42.000
And when I did that, notice that it's
a nice, dark, black background now,

422
00:21:42.000 --> 00:21:45.530
versus the fake black scent,
for that is so annoying.

423
00:21:45.530 --> 00:21:48.610
And that green is so much more vibrant,
cuz it's on a real black background.

424
00:21:48.610 --> 00:21:51.240
But it's also a larger font, so
it's easier for you guys to read now,

425
00:21:51.240 --> 00:21:52.330
so we could see it, right?

426
00:21:52.330 --> 00:21:54.120
That's a great way to do that.

427
00:21:54.120 --> 00:21:56.410
But if we turn that transparency.

428
00:21:56.410 --> 00:21:59.280
So if I go back into my
profile preferences.

429
00:21:59.280 --> 00:22:02.204
And I take that transparency,
it's under colors.

430
00:22:02.204 --> 00:22:03.284
There, transparent.

431
00:22:03.284 --> 00:22:07.036
And I set this transparency,
maybe I'll put it at 50%.

432
00:22:07.036 --> 00:22:08.369
And I'll close that.

433
00:22:08.369 --> 00:22:10.964
See how you can see through the terminal,
right.

434
00:22:10.964 --> 00:22:11.564
>> That's cool Don.

435
00:22:11.564 --> 00:22:15.020
[LAUGH]
>> It looks cool, right?

436
00:22:15.020 --> 00:22:18.050
If you're gonna be on a hacker movie or
something like that,

437
00:22:18.050 --> 00:22:20.270
you certainly want to be able
to see through your terminal.

438
00:22:20.270 --> 00:22:23.300
But man, when you start working with this,
and you're going through and

439
00:22:23.300 --> 00:22:26.350
you're working through your files,
it gets annoying after a while.

440
00:22:26.350 --> 00:22:29.566
And maybe you could turn on
a little bit of transparency, but

441
00:22:29.566 --> 00:22:32.290
you end up with this fake black color,
basically.

442
00:22:32.290 --> 00:22:33.010
And it's annoying to me.

443
00:22:33.010 --> 00:22:36.453
But the cool part here is you
get to set your own preference.

444
00:22:36.453 --> 00:22:39.158
You create your own profile,
you can customize it,

445
00:22:39.158 --> 00:22:43.110
you can change the dimensions of
the terminal, the way that it's rending.

446
00:22:43.110 --> 00:22:46.860
All of that stuff is customizable and
it's easy to switch so

447
00:22:46.860 --> 00:22:50.600
if Mike comes to my computer and
he hates this profile he can just go

448
00:22:50.600 --> 00:22:53.520
open a terminal and
choose a new profile or create his own.

449
00:22:53.520 --> 00:22:55.050
And now it's customized to his needs.

450
00:22:55.050 --> 00:23:00.320
And so very easy to flip between those and
make them the way that you want.

451
00:23:00.320 --> 00:23:01.740
As far as the setting in here,

452
00:23:01.740 --> 00:23:05.600
it is going to vary a little bit,
based on what terminal you're using.

453
00:23:05.600 --> 00:23:07.520
Some of the setting I
recommend you check out,

454
00:23:07.520 --> 00:23:11.980
under scrolling it'll choose whether or
not you display a scroll bar.

455
00:23:11.980 --> 00:23:14.290
And displaying a scroll bar is kind
of important if you're going to be

456
00:23:14.290 --> 00:23:15.300
running long output.

457
00:23:15.300 --> 00:23:16.644
Also the scrollback.

458
00:23:16.644 --> 00:23:18.049
You have a scrollback buffer.

459
00:23:18.049 --> 00:23:20.700
Mine is set to 10,000, okay?

460
00:23:20.700 --> 00:23:21.490
That's not the default.

461
00:23:21.490 --> 00:23:22.570
That's what I set it to.

462
00:23:22.570 --> 00:23:24.880
Sometimes I run really
long running commands and

463
00:23:24.880 --> 00:23:27.000
I wanna be able to scroll back and
see that history.

464
00:23:27.000 --> 00:23:30.127
Well, the default I think it's
something like 200 lines.

465
00:23:30.127 --> 00:23:33.323
So if more than 200 lines of
output comes up on the screen,

466
00:23:33.323 --> 00:23:36.957
you can't scroll back to see what it
was so I like to bump up that number

467
00:23:36.957 --> 00:23:40.430
right there the scroll back buffer
to get that to a larger number.

468
00:23:40.430 --> 00:23:43.532
And here it just calls it scroll
back other terminals might call

469
00:23:43.532 --> 00:23:46.530
it a scroll back buffer because
it is being stored in memory.

470
00:23:46.530 --> 00:23:48.981
You have other things
like compatibility here.

471
00:23:48.981 --> 00:23:53.377
Sometimes you'll bump into systems
where your back space key doesn't work.

472
00:23:53.377 --> 00:23:56.273
And hit the backspace key and
it sends a control H for

473
00:23:56.273 --> 00:23:58.776
some reason, that's one of the mappings.

474
00:23:58.776 --> 00:24:02.649
You can come in here and tweak what the
backspace key sends, so your Ctrl+ H or

475
00:24:02.649 --> 00:24:04.087
automatic delete.

476
00:24:04.087 --> 00:24:07.061
So you can tell it how
you want the function.

477
00:24:07.061 --> 00:24:09.536
And that's something you may
have to adjust for some systems.

478
00:24:09.536 --> 00:24:10.614
This is in the profile, so

479
00:24:10.614 --> 00:24:13.849
you could have a profile that you use when
connecting to one of those systems and

480
00:24:13.849 --> 00:24:16.465
it's different profile used normally,
flip back and forth.

481
00:24:16.465 --> 00:24:19.893
I've had to do that there's some I think
it's one of the switches we have here in

482
00:24:19.893 --> 00:24:23.490
the building that the delete key doesn't
work when I'm connected to that switch.

483
00:24:23.490 --> 00:24:26.360
So I have a different profile that I
switch to when I'm on that switch and

484
00:24:26.360 --> 00:24:27.740
now I can use my delete key.

485
00:24:27.740 --> 00:24:29.580
And then I flip back to my normal profile.

486
00:24:29.580 --> 00:24:31.810
Those are all things we can
do inside of a terminal.

487
00:24:31.810 --> 00:24:35.360
Now, you can use xterm, gnometerm, kterm.

488
00:24:35.360 --> 00:24:37.730
You can use Terminator, which is,
I think, pretty awesome.

489
00:24:37.730 --> 00:24:38.474
You can use Guake.

490
00:24:38.474 --> 00:24:40.501
All of these are different terminals.

491
00:24:40.501 --> 00:24:44.127
And when you launch them, at the end
of the day they're all just giving

492
00:24:44.127 --> 00:24:47.530
you access to a shell which I know,
I'm a little low on time here.

493
00:24:47.530 --> 00:24:51.340
So we want to cover the show in part two,
but they're gaining access to the shell.

494
00:24:51.340 --> 00:24:54.480
The shell is the same regardless
of which terminal you used.

495
00:24:54.480 --> 00:24:57.990
I could have five different terminal
programs all accessing the same shell,

496
00:24:57.990 --> 00:25:01.240
same command, same keyboard shortcuts,
that kind of stuff, but

497
00:25:01.240 --> 00:25:01.930
different terminals.

498
00:25:01.930 --> 00:25:03.520
So feel free to shop around.

499
00:25:03.520 --> 00:25:06.350
Find the terminal that you like, pick one.

500
00:25:06.350 --> 00:25:08.776
I do recommend Guake,
which I use all the time.

501
00:25:08.776 --> 00:25:11.980
And Terminator which what I use all
the time, those are two good ones.

502
00:25:11.980 --> 00:25:15.210
But even Gnome Terminal and xterm,
kterm those guys, they're all good.

503
00:25:15.210 --> 00:25:16.901
They all give you access to that Shell and

504
00:25:16.901 --> 00:25:20.510
let you do the stuff they're gonna be
doing in the whole rest of the series.

505
00:25:20.510 --> 00:25:21.840
>> Fantastic, all right Don.

506
00:25:21.840 --> 00:25:23.246
A lot of great information there.

507
00:25:23.246 --> 00:25:24.199
A little bit of a cliffhanger, right?

508
00:25:24.199 --> 00:25:25.772
>> [LAUGH]
>> We got the terminals,

509
00:25:25.772 --> 00:25:27.942
we're gonna get to Shells in our part two.

510
00:25:27.942 --> 00:25:31.570
So make sure you join us for that,
we're looking forward to it.

511
00:25:31.570 --> 00:25:33.688
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

512
00:25:33.688 --> 00:25:36.865
Signing off for IT ProTV,
I've been your host Mike Roderick.

513
00:25:36.865 --> 00:25:39.427
>> I'm Don,
just say no to transparency Pezet.

514
00:25:39.427 --> 00:25:40.427
>> And we'll see you next time.

515
00:25:40.427 --> 00:25:42.458
>> [LAUGH]

00:25:42.458 --> 00:25:48.414
[MUSIC]

00:25:48.414 --> 00:25:51.881
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss what shells are in a Linux environment. They cover the various shells that are available, and how to determine if a particular shell is installed. They also demonstrate how to change the default shell for an individual user.

>> Hello, welcome to another

5

I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our part two to Terminals and

6
00:00:20.290 --> 00:00:20.940
Shells.

7
00:00:20.940 --> 00:00:23.820
We left you with a little bit of
a cliffhanger on that previous one.

8
00:00:23.820 --> 00:00:24.890
We talked about terminals.

9

13
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:35.010
And yeah, like you said,
in the last episode we saw terminals, and

14
00:00:35.010 --> 00:00:38.510
when you launch a terminal,
it lets you see the shell.

15
00:00:38.510 --> 00:00:41.220
So we probably need to talk a little bit
about what the heck that thing is that we

16
00:00:41.220 --> 00:00:42.970
see, but we really didn't do
that in the last episode.

17
00:00:42.970 --> 00:00:45.480
We just focused on getting the terminal
itself kind of customized and

18
00:00:45.480 --> 00:00:46.690

19
00:00:46.690 --> 00:00:49.980
But then you're exposed to this
command-line interface, and

00:00:49.980 --> 00:00:51.550

So we need to talk a little bit about that

There is one that's pretty common.

00:00:58.250 --> 00:00:59.550
So we'll talk about each off those and

00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:01.270

26

Now we're not gonna launch

00:01:03.270 --> 00:01:04.520
things like that in this episode.

28
00:01:04.520 --> 00:01:05.870

29
00:01:05.870 --> 00:01:08.370
But just understanding
the environment that we're working in

00:01:08.370 --> 00:01:11.880
is a critical thing before we start
jumping into all of the extras.

31
00:01:11.880 --> 00:01:13.032
>> All right, Don, so where do we start?

32
00:01:13.032 --> 00:01:17.650
>> All right, well,
much like the window managers and

33
00:01:17.650 --> 00:01:20.350
the terminals and so on with
the shell you have a lot of choices.

34
00:01:20.350 --> 00:01:21.890
Linux is all about choices.

35
00:01:21.890 --> 00:01:24.620
If you don't like one thing you can
swap it out for something else.

36
00:01:24.620 --> 00:01:27.320
And the shell is no exception to that.

37
00:01:27.320 --> 00:01:30.100
That the shell has been around for
a long, long time.

38
00:01:30.100 --> 00:01:33.391
But when the original,
it didn't even originate in Linux,

39
00:01:33.391 --> 00:01:34.820
way back in the Unix days.

40
00:01:34.820 --> 00:01:36.560
In the original version of Unix,

41
00:01:36.560 --> 00:01:40.110
when they had the Unix kernel that would
fire up you had a way to interact with it.

42
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:42.600
And so they created the original
shells to be able to do that.

43
00:01:42.600 --> 00:01:48.271
And one of the earliest shells was what
most of us just call SH, the shell.

44
00:01:48.271 --> 00:01:52.135
And it's the Bourne shell was developed
by somebody who's last name was

45
00:01:52.135 --> 00:01:53.249
Bourne [LAUGH].

46
00:01:53.249 --> 00:01:56.233
I can't remember the whole name but
that was the Bourne shell.

47
00:01:56.233 --> 00:01:57.481
And it was very basic.

48
00:01:57.481 --> 00:02:00.955
It allowed you to enter in commands and
it would be interpreted and

49
00:02:00.955 --> 00:02:03.177
processed by the kernel and executed.

50
00:02:03.177 --> 00:02:06.805
And you could enter in commands
almost like a programming language.

51
00:02:06.805 --> 00:02:11.298
You could really put in a lot more than
just some straight up single command.

52
00:02:11.298 --> 00:02:16.270
You could pipeline commands and
really write simple programs and

53

be some kind of consistency between them.

00:13:48.290 --> 00:13:53.370
And so they had POSIX compliance,
you could license the Unix source code.

280
00:13:53.370 --> 00:13:55.470
And choose to be POSIX compliant or not.

281
00:13:55.470 --> 00:13:57.829
If you were POSIX compliant,
then a program written for

282
00:13:57.829 --> 00:14:00.960
your system would likely run on
other POSIX compliant systems.

283
00:14:00.960 --> 00:14:04.660
And the Dash shell
enforces POSIX compliance.

284
00:14:04.660 --> 00:14:07.240
So it makes sure than anything
you do is POSIX compliant, and

285
00:14:07.240 --> 00:14:08.540
that means it's going to be portable.

286
00:14:08.540 --> 00:14:10.960
You can take that code, or
script, or whatever and

287
00:14:10.960 --> 00:14:12.140
take it to other systems and run fine.

288
00:14:12.140 --> 00:14:15.650
And that's one of the reasons why
Debian latched onto that one early on.

289
00:14:15.650 --> 00:14:19.665
Some of the other shows like Bash,
Bash doesn't care if you want to be POSIX

290
00:14:19.665 --> 00:14:22.690
compliant great,
if you don't want to that's fine too.

291
00:14:22.690 --> 00:14:24.140
They leave it up to you so

292
00:14:24.140 --> 00:14:28.574
Bash is more flexible which is kind
of why it's the default everywhere.

293
00:14:28.574 --> 00:14:33.830
But Dash is still around because of
that enforcement of POSIX compliance.

294
00:14:33.830 --> 00:14:35.985
So that's a reason why we
might choose to use that one.

295
00:14:35.985 --> 00:14:39.773
>> All right Don let's say for
some reason I really need that C shell,

296
00:14:39.773 --> 00:14:42.970
to be my default,
can we change what the default is?

297
00:14:42.970 --> 00:14:46.070
>> Yeah, yeah absolutely, so
if you're worried about forgetting.

298
00:14:46.070 --> 00:14:47.840
So maybe I wanna be POSIX compliant, or

299
00:14:47.840 --> 00:14:50.640
I wanna use Dash,
I wanna make sure that's my default shell.

300
00:14:50.640 --> 00:14:54.139
Well, I could say I'll leave Bash and
then every time I open up a terminal,

301
00:14:54.139 --> 00:14:55.710
I'll just make sure to run Dash.

302
00:14:55.710 --> 00:14:58.580
I can even add a little like
profile script to say run

303
00:14:58.580 --> 00:14:59.930
this command every time I run it.

304
00:14:59.930 --> 00:15:01.180
That causes problems though.

305
00:15:01.180 --> 00:15:03.700
So instead it's better
to change your default.

306
00:15:03.700 --> 00:15:10.910
And there's a command you can run chsh,
which is the change shell command.

307
00:15:10.910 --> 00:15:14.670
And when you run that, it allows
you to change what your shell is.

308
00:15:14.670 --> 00:15:17.930
Now, it's gonna ask you for your password
because it's changing your user account.

309
00:15:17.930 --> 00:15:19.400
So, you need to provide your password.

310
00:15:19.400 --> 00:15:22.040
And then after that it's gonna ask
you what shell you wanna use and

311
00:15:22.040 --> 00:15:25.000
you need to know where
your shell is stored.

312
00:15:25.000 --> 00:15:32.570
So, before you run chsh, it's a good idea
to run which followed by your shell name.

313
00:15:32.570 --> 00:15:34.620
And that that way we can
find the shell for you.

314
00:15:34.620 --> 00:15:37.010
So mine is in /bin/dash.

315
00:15:37.010 --> 00:15:41.560
That's important because,
on Ubuntu the dash shows a default and so

316
00:15:41.560 --> 00:15:43.550
its in /bin/dash.

317
00:15:43.550 --> 00:15:47.581
But if you run Fedora it might not have it
you might have to install it now it's in

318
00:15:47.581 --> 00:15:49.090
/user/bin/dash.

319
00:15:49.090 --> 00:15:51.980
So its in a different place so
you need to find your shell first.

320
00:15:51.980 --> 00:15:53.640
That's kinda step one.

321
00:15:53.640 --> 00:15:57.757
And then after that you can run chsh.

322
00:15:57.757 --> 00:15:59.661
You can provide your password.

323
00:15:59.661 --> 00:16:03.544
And if you're an administrator you can do
a command line argument to specify other

324
00:16:03.544 --> 00:16:06.510
users here so you can change
somebody else's default shell.

325
00:16:06.510 --> 00:16:08.100
But, I'm changing mine.

326
00:16:08.100 --> 00:16:11.020
And so I'll punch in my password,
if I can remember it.

327
00:16:12.370 --> 00:16:14.820
There we go and now it's asking for
what shell I wanna use.

328
00:16:14.820 --> 00:16:17.700
And you'll notice the default
login shell here, is /bin/bash,

329
00:16:17.700 --> 00:16:19.520
that's what it wants me to use.

330
00:16:19.520 --> 00:16:26.490
But I can put in /bin/dash and I'll hit
that and now, my default shell is changed.

331
00:16:26.490 --> 00:16:33.840
If we go back to the passwd file,
that password file and

332
00:16:33.840 --> 00:16:39.070
I look at my entry, see how my default
is now /bin/dash instead of bash.

333
00:16:39.070 --> 00:16:42.030
Now, does that take effect right away?

334
00:16:42.030 --> 00:16:43.890
Well it actually doesn't.

335
00:16:43.890 --> 00:16:48.870
If I log out and log back in,
I've still got the longer prompt here.

336
00:16:48.870 --> 00:16:54.950
I'm still in bash, sorry because I didn't
log out and log back in let me clarify.

337
00:16:54.950 --> 00:16:56.070
If I log out and

338
00:16:56.070 --> 00:17:00.160
log back in, that little profile gets
loaded, it only gets loaded at login time.

339
00:17:00.160 --> 00:17:02.630
So I need to logout and log back in.

340
00:17:02.630 --> 00:17:07.190
And then when I open up a terminal,
I'll get the regular Dash terminal.

341
00:17:07.190 --> 00:17:10.640
And now I'll be able to go in and
start in doing things in that way.

342
00:17:10.640 --> 00:17:12.705
And know when I'm being POSIX
compliant because that's important.

343
00:17:12.705 --> 00:17:13.682
>> [LAUGH]
>> Maybe is, and

344
00:17:13.682 --> 00:17:15.270
that's how we'd ensure that.

345
00:17:15.270 --> 00:17:17.990
But chsh that's how you
change the shell and

346
00:17:17.990 --> 00:17:20.448
then whoever the user is just
need to logout and log back in.

347
00:17:20.448 --> 00:17:22.563
That's their new default and
that's what they're gonna get.

348
00:17:22.563 --> 00:17:24.864
>> All right Don again
a lot of great stuff there,

349
00:17:24.864 --> 00:17:28.110
really taking a look at the different
shells that are available.

350
00:17:28.110 --> 00:17:29.347
How we can determine
what shell we're using.

351
00:17:29.347 --> 00:17:31.642
What shells we have on our system, and

352
00:17:31.642 --> 00:17:34.455
how to change that default
shell if we need to.

353
00:17:34.455 --> 00:17:37.440
I'm really starting to feel
like a power user on Linux.

354
00:17:37.440 --> 00:17:39.640
We've covered terminals in that part one.

355
00:17:39.640 --> 00:17:41.540
We looked at shells in part two.

356
00:17:41.540 --> 00:17:44.700
So anything else you wanna add
before we close this one out Don?

357
00:17:44.700 --> 00:17:46.926
>> You know the shells are all really,
really small, so

358
00:17:46.926 --> 00:17:49.464
don't hesitate to install four,
five, six, all of them.

359
00:17:49.464 --> 00:17:51.863
[LAUGH] You can jump in and mess around.

360
00:17:51.863 --> 00:17:54.583
But if you are getting started out,
I do recommend that you stay in Bash.

361
00:17:54.583 --> 00:17:56.672
That Bash is kind of
the way of the future,

362
00:17:56.672 --> 00:17:59.030
it's what most things have settled on.

363
00:17:59.030 --> 00:18:01.428
And so that's the one you really
wanna learn and get used to.

364
00:18:01.428 --> 00:18:04.823
That's what we're gonna use the whole rest
of this series we're gonna be in Bash.

365
00:18:04.823 --> 00:18:06.096
I'm not gonna mess the other shells.

366
00:18:06.096 --> 00:18:08.155
But don't discount the other
shells they're there for

367
00:18:08.155 --> 00:18:09.782
a reason mostly backwards compatibility.

368
00:18:09.782 --> 00:18:12.490
>> Very good, all right Don well
we thank you for that information.

369
00:18:12.490 --> 00:18:14.581
That's gonna do it for
this one, signing off for

370
00:18:14.581 --> 00:18:16.469
ITProTV I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

371
00:18:16.469 --> 00:18:17.239
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

372
00:18:17.239 --> 00:18:18.430
>> And I'll see you next time.

373
00:18:18.430 --> 00:18:26.096
[MUSIC]

374
00:18:26.096 --> 00:18:28.454
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike demonstrate executing basic commands. They start with simple commands like date and hostname. Then they look at using commands that take options, like ls and cat. They finish by demonstrating how to use history to execute a previously used command.
episodes.title: Executing Commands
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:08.067
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:08.067 --> 00:00:12.292
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.292 --> 00:00:15.739
>> Hello, welcome to another
exiting episode here at ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:15.739 --> 00:00:20.140
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today we're
doing our become a Linux power user.

5
00:00:20.140 --> 00:00:24.326
And specifically int his episode,
we'll be focusing on executing commands.

6
00:00:24.326 --> 00:00:25.915
I know, sounds exciting right.

7
00:00:25.915 --> 00:00:27.989
[LAUGH].
And here to help us with that is Mr.

8
00:00:27.989 --> 00:00:28.650
Don Pezet.

9
00:00:28.650 --> 00:00:29.530
Welcome back, Don.

10
00:00:29.530 --> 00:00:31.240
>> Hey, we're going to make
it as exciting as we can.

11
00:00:31.240 --> 00:00:34.350
You know, in the first couple of episodes,
we got a chance to see.

12
00:00:34.350 --> 00:00:36.564
Using the terminal and
accessing the shell, but

13
00:00:36.564 --> 00:00:38.462
we didn't actually do much of anything.

14
00:00:38.462 --> 00:00:39.887
>> We could type anything.

15
00:00:39.887 --> 00:00:40.431
[LAUGH]
>> At some point,

16
00:00:40.431 --> 00:00:42.760
we've got to do something or this is
not going to be very powerful at all.

17
00:00:42.760 --> 00:00:44.330
So, this is the episode where
we're just going to start.

18
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:46.140
We're going to start issuing
some command line commands.

19
00:00:46.140 --> 00:00:47.770
We're going to see how
the command line works.

20
00:00:47.770 --> 00:00:49.420
There's some really amazing,

21
00:00:49.420 --> 00:00:51.510
amazingly powerful stuff you
can do from the command line.

22
00:00:51.510 --> 00:00:54.360
This whole need for a series called
Becoming a Linux Power User.

23
00:00:54.360 --> 00:00:56.110
So, this is where it really starts.

24
00:00:56.110 --> 00:00:58.110
But we do need to know
how to issue commands and

25
00:00:58.110 --> 00:01:00.380
what Linux is expecting us to do.

26
00:01:00.380 --> 00:01:02.650
So that's what we're going to take
a look at right here in this episode.

27
00:01:02.650 --> 00:01:03.220
>> Fantastic.

28
00:01:03.220 --> 00:01:04.700
All right.
Where do we start?

29
00:01:04.700 --> 00:01:06.090
>> Well,
let's just start with basic commands.

30
00:01:06.090 --> 00:01:09.800
Right, basic command entry,
a couple of things that

31
00:01:09.800 --> 00:01:11.990
you may not be familiar with
from other operating systems.

32
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:15.955
You're coming from Mac OS or Windows or
whatever is that a lot of what we do

33
00:01:15.955 --> 00:01:19.931
in the Linux world and really the UNIX
world as a whole is case sensitive.

34
00:01:19.931 --> 00:01:24.085
And expects a very particular syntax if
you deviate from that syntax it's not very

35
00:01:24.085 --> 00:01:27.831
nice to you it is not going to hold your
hand and give you a whole lot of help.

36
00:01:27.831 --> 00:01:30.889
So we gotta have a good understanding
of what we're expected to do and

37
00:01:30.889 --> 00:01:34.264
understand how to get help at those times
when we need it so we're gonna punch

38
00:01:34.264 --> 00:01:37.558
through in and take a look at some basic
stuff right here in the beginning.

39
00:01:37.558 --> 00:01:40.030
Talking about executing a single command.

40
00:01:40.030 --> 00:01:42.250
I'm in my terminal right here.

41
00:01:42.250 --> 00:01:43.900
And I can see my command prompt.

42
00:01:43.900 --> 00:01:46.020
And it's basically waiting for
me to do something.

43
00:01:46.020 --> 00:01:47.570
And so I need to type in a command.

44
00:01:49.240 --> 00:01:52.970
It's just normal keyboard type stuff
if you know the command to type.

45
00:01:52.970 --> 00:01:56.850
If you don't know the command to type,
you're kind of just dead in the water?

46
00:01:56.850 --> 00:01:58.610
>> Yeah, yeah!
I mean, you type a question mark,

47
00:01:58.610 --> 00:02:01.920
it does nothing because it thinks
the question mark is the command, right?

48
00:02:01.920 --> 00:02:04.490
So, we need to know
the commands to execute and

49
00:02:04.490 --> 00:02:07.510
there are a standard set of commands
you can expect to be there.

50
00:02:07.510 --> 00:02:11.330
Many of which are built into the system,
some of which we load afterwards or

51
00:02:11.330 --> 00:02:13.620
include it with the system- there
are different things that happen there.

52
00:02:13.620 --> 00:02:16.530
But these commands are us
interacting with the system.

53
00:02:16.530 --> 00:02:19.450
And you just type whatever
that command name is.

54
00:02:19.450 --> 00:02:21.845
If it's a simple command like
the date command, right?

55
00:02:21.845 --> 00:02:23.098
D-A-T-E.

56
00:02:23.098 --> 00:02:26.070
I can type date, and there's today's date.

57
00:02:26.070 --> 00:02:27.910
It's just a simple command.

58
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:29.270
You issue one word.

59
00:02:29.270 --> 00:02:30.890
It issues a response.

60
00:02:30.890 --> 00:02:33.660
And that's the most basic type
of command you've got, right?

61
00:02:33.660 --> 00:02:34.930
One command, one response.

62
00:02:34.930 --> 00:02:36.590
In and out, done.

63
00:02:36.590 --> 00:02:38.570
There's plenty of commands
that are like that,

64
00:02:38.570 --> 00:02:43.030
commands like pwd, which is short for
the present working directory.

65
00:02:43.030 --> 00:02:46.100
So show me what folder I'm
in in the file system.

66
00:02:46.100 --> 00:02:50.070
You run the one command, it tells you
the folder, I'm in /home/dpezet, right?

67
00:02:50.070 --> 00:02:51.250
So there we go, very exciting.

68
00:02:52.250 --> 00:02:55.860
Hostname I tell it hey,
what's the name of my computer?

69
00:02:55.860 --> 00:02:58.110
It returns you're on Don's laptop, right?

70
00:02:58.110 --> 00:02:59.490
One command, one response.

71
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:00.820
That's basic command.

72
00:03:00.820 --> 00:03:05.460
Now if I type it in all CAPS,
command not found.

73
00:03:05.460 --> 00:03:08.580
Or even one letter, command not found.

74
00:03:08.580 --> 00:03:10.450
Right?
Now in a Ubuntu it does this nice thing

75
00:03:10.450 --> 00:03:13.010
where it tries to figure out what
command you were trying to do, right?

76
00:03:13.010 --> 00:03:14.880
Like, well you screwed up,
what were you trying to do?

77
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:16.040
And it tries to find it.

78
00:03:16.040 --> 00:03:17.600
But it still doesn't run it for you,

79
00:03:17.600 --> 00:03:20.570
you have to type it in the proper
case which s all lower case.

80
00:03:20.570 --> 00:03:24.700
So in the Linux world, just do your
commands in all lower case, there's

81
00:03:24.700 --> 00:03:29.450
exceptions we'll see later but most part
everything is done in all lower case.

82
00:03:29.450 --> 00:03:34.600
All right now, simple commands only get
you so far, right, like the list command,

83
00:03:34.600 --> 00:03:38.760
ls, if I wanna see the files
in my directory I can type ls.

84
00:03:38.760 --> 00:03:43.160
And I'll see a list of the files,
okay so I see some stuff great, but

85
00:03:43.160 --> 00:03:46.330
what if I wanna change the way
that output is displayed?

86
00:03:46.330 --> 00:03:48.830
Right maybe I want more information,
I don't just want the names,

87
00:03:48.830 --> 00:03:51.260
I want the file sizes or
when they were modified.

88
00:03:51.260 --> 00:03:54.840
Maybe I want to alphabetize the list and
change that.

89
00:03:54.840 --> 00:03:56.550
We can start to manipulate that.

90
00:03:56.550 --> 00:04:00.260
Most commands support
command line arguments.

91
00:04:00.260 --> 00:04:02.750
A command line argument
is like a modifier,

92
00:04:02.750 --> 00:04:05.480
something that changes
the way the command works.

93
00:04:05.480 --> 00:04:08.110
And you will find that
majority of commands do that.

94
00:04:08.110 --> 00:04:12.450
That if you just run a command by itself,
like date, and you run that.

95
00:04:12.450 --> 00:04:15.090
There is my upward or
alias, I get my upward.

96
00:04:15.090 --> 00:04:22.260
But if I do "ls" and
then a space followed by a dash.

97
00:04:22.260 --> 00:04:25.950
I can then provide command line arguments
that change the way it behaves.

98
00:04:25.950 --> 00:04:28.860
And there's two different ways to
provide command line arguments:

99
00:04:28.860 --> 00:04:32.060
there is the Unix way and the BSD way.

100
00:04:32.060 --> 00:04:34.570
The Unix way uses individual letters.

101
00:04:34.570 --> 00:04:37.770
So if i wanna see everything
that's in this folder,

102
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:42.740
even hidden files I can do ls -a,
a is short for all, right?

103
00:04:42.740 --> 00:04:46.170
So, I want it to show me all
of the stuff in this folder.

104
00:04:46.170 --> 00:04:47.430
And when I run ls -a,

105
00:04:47.430 --> 00:04:50.960
you'll see a lot more of my home
folder than what we saw a moment ago.

106
00:04:50.960 --> 00:04:54.510
All these files that start with a dot or
even the folders that start with a dot-

107
00:04:54.510 --> 00:04:58.080
those are hidden by default,
so -a told it to show all.

108
00:04:58.080 --> 00:05:04.580
Well, in the bsd notation,
what we would say is we would say ls--all.

109
00:05:04.580 --> 00:05:05.360
The word all.

110
00:05:05.360 --> 00:05:08.300
Right?
Instead of one dash, we do two dashes.

111
00:05:08.300 --> 00:05:09.680
And that's important.

112
00:05:09.680 --> 00:05:11.710
Because when I say dash dash,

113
00:05:11.710 --> 00:05:16.020
that's the indicator that tells it I'm
about to give you a word not a letter

114
00:05:16.020 --> 00:05:19.630
If it was just a single dash, we'd assume
that I was about to give it a letter.

115
00:05:19.630 --> 00:05:22.630
And I might not get the behavior
that I expect, right.

116
00:05:22.630 --> 00:05:24.120
Things can go a little weird.

117
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:31.790
If I run ls -- all, I get the same output
that I did when I ran ls- a, right.

118
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:38.570
But if I run ls- o like that, and
run it things look really different.

119
00:05:38.570 --> 00:05:40.420
Okay, why is that?

120
00:05:40.420 --> 00:05:45.600
Well, instead of looking at it as a word,
it looked at it as letters, and

121
00:05:45.600 --> 00:05:48.010
each letter means something
a little different.

122
00:05:48.010 --> 00:05:53.459
So for example, if I do ls -a, that
means show all files, even hidden ones.

123
00:05:53.459 --> 00:05:58.233
And if I do -l, that means give me the
long output, the long output is the file

124
00:05:58.233 --> 00:06:02.810
name with the modification date,
the permissions, and the file size.

125
00:06:02.810 --> 00:06:05.650
So it's adding all of that right?

126
00:06:05.650 --> 00:06:10.390
And so when I do ls-al I get that output.

127
00:06:10.390 --> 00:06:15.480
So when I ran ls-all like that.

128
00:06:15.480 --> 00:06:16.706
It said these are letters.

129
00:06:16.706 --> 00:06:21.600
I mean -a, I mean -l and
I mean -l again which is the same thing.

130

especially when you're getting files from

575
00:29:44.620 --> 00:29:45.750
people in Windows and

576
00:29:45.750 --> 00:29:48.740
stuff with spaces all over the place,
then you gotta escape things.

577
00:29:48.740 --> 00:29:50.900
Most Unix systems are really good, or

578
00:29:50.900 --> 00:29:54.200
most developers,
about using underscores instead.

579
00:29:54.200 --> 00:29:57.300
That saves you from that trouble but
in this case I had a space.

580
00:29:59.130 --> 00:30:01.690
Now let's say you wanna really go crazy.

581
00:30:01.690 --> 00:30:06.512
I had a long command, I ran it and
maybe it didn't work and I wanna edit it.

582
00:30:06.512 --> 00:30:10.150
I wanna change it or
maybe even a range of commands, right?

583
00:30:10.150 --> 00:30:12.231
You can use another command called fc.

584
00:30:12.231 --> 00:30:17.670
And what fc let's you do, is edit
the commands in a full screen editor.

585
00:30:17.670 --> 00:30:22.700
So, for example, my set command that I
ran earlier was the wrong command, right?

586
00:30:22.700 --> 00:30:27.430
So when I look at it, maybe I had
a typo in it, and I just wanna go and

587
00:30:27.430 --> 00:30:29.610
fix the typo, but
the typo's in the middle.

588
00:30:29.610 --> 00:30:34.715
So it's not like I can do !!, or
I think you call those bangs, right?

589
00:30:34.715 --> 00:30:36.870
>> Mm-hm.
>> Bang, bang, followed by whatever.

590
00:30:36.870 --> 00:30:39.810
I can't do that, but I could do fc,

591
00:30:41.290 --> 00:30:44.890
followed by the history
number of that command.

592
00:30:44.890 --> 00:30:51.280
So I want to do fc 49, and
it's gonna bring up a full screen editor.

593
00:30:51.280 --> 00:30:54.290
And I can go in and
edit this however I want.

594
00:30:54.290 --> 00:30:56.960
And so maybe I spelled the word
path wrong, so I could come in and

595
00:30:56.960 --> 00:31:01.820
I could fix the word path and
get that correct, okay?

596
00:31:01.820 --> 00:31:04.640
And once it's done,
I know why that command didn't work.

597
00:31:04.640 --> 00:31:06.330
I didn't actually create the bin folder.

598
00:31:06.330 --> 00:31:07.940
So you can't add a folder
that doesn't exist..

599
00:31:07.940 --> 00:31:08.990
So I need to add that.

600
00:31:08.990 --> 00:31:13.953
Well, funny thing, though,
is I could actually come in here and say,

601
00:31:13.953 --> 00:31:18.306
you know what,
let me make /home/depossess/bin folder.

602
00:31:18.306 --> 00:31:20.544
I'll go ahead and make that folder and
then execute it, so

603
00:31:20.544 --> 00:31:21.449
now it's gonna do both.

604
00:31:21.449 --> 00:31:25.738
And when I hit Ctrl + X, it's gonna
ask me to save, I'll save it and

605
00:31:25.738 --> 00:31:28.320
then it runs those two commands.

606
00:31:28.320 --> 00:31:29.670
So it just ran them and

607
00:31:29.670 --> 00:31:34.920
if I look in my home directory, I now
have a bin folder, there it is, right?

608
00:31:34.920 --> 00:31:38.160
And let's see if my path actually
updated this time or not.

609
00:31:38.160 --> 00:31:39.874
And it is still not there.

610
00:31:39.874 --> 00:31:43.590
All right, we'll sort that out later,
but now it ran that.

611
00:31:43.590 --> 00:31:47.317
The fc command's really powerful
because I could actually come in and

612
00:31:47.317 --> 00:31:49.220
maybe I ran three or four commands.

613
00:31:49.220 --> 00:31:52.888
And so
maybe I wanna get commands 63 through 66.

614
00:31:52.888 --> 00:31:59.500
So I can say fc 63, 66, and it's gonna
open up and there's all those commands.

615
00:31:59.500 --> 00:32:02.470
And I can edit them however I need.

616
00:32:02.470 --> 00:32:06.030
And when I exit and
choose save, it'll run them.

617
00:32:06.030 --> 00:32:07.970
If I exit and choose discard,
it doesn't run them.

618
00:32:07.970 --> 00:32:09.200
So I can just give up.

619
00:32:09.200 --> 00:32:12.060
But if I wanted to run them,
I can just hit Ctrl + X,

620
00:32:12.060 --> 00:32:13.490
it'll save and then they'll run.

621
00:32:13.490 --> 00:32:15.100
And you can add more and change it and so

622
00:32:15.100 --> 00:32:18.290
that's another really powerful
way to re-execute commands.

623
00:32:18.290 --> 00:32:19.790
In the early days when
you're just learning,

624
00:32:19.790 --> 00:32:21.520
you're gonna make a lot of mistakes.

625
00:32:21.520 --> 00:32:26.190
And so it's important that you have a way
to retrieve that history, to look for

626
00:32:26.190 --> 00:32:27.390
typos, to correct them.

627
00:32:27.390 --> 00:32:33.030
So remember, the !!, because that
pulls your previous command back.

628
00:32:33.030 --> 00:32:36.180
And remember fc, that lets you go in and

629
00:32:36.180 --> 00:32:40.060
retrieve this, and
execute those commands, and pull them up.

630
00:32:40.060 --> 00:32:43.440
If you just run fc by itself,
it just pulls your last command.

631
00:32:43.440 --> 00:32:46.877
So another kind of easy way to
get in there and do that so

632
00:32:46.877 --> 00:32:51.350
that you can kind of just really quick
pull that up, edit it, and go on.

633
00:32:52.770 --> 00:32:56.580
!!, runs your last command,
fc edits it and then runs it.

634
00:32:56.580 --> 00:32:58.794
So that's a way that we
can modify while running.

635
00:32:58.794 --> 00:33:00.940
>> All right, Don,
lots of great stuff there.

636
00:33:00.940 --> 00:33:04.395
Well, on our way to becoming
a power user in Linux.

637
00:33:04.395 --> 00:33:05.760
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we thank you for that.

638
00:33:05.760 --> 00:33:08.350
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

639
00:33:08.350 --> 00:33:11.580
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

640
00:33:11.580 --> 00:33:12.450
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

641
00:33:12.450 --> 00:33:14.617
>> And we'll see you next time.

642
00:33:14.617 --> 00:33:20.600
[MUSIC]

643
00:33:20.600 --> 00:33:21.970
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike continue to look at executing commands. They demonstrate using the tab autocomplete feature, piping commands, sequential commands, and expanding commands. They finish by demonstrating creating and using shell variables.
episodes.title: Executing Commands Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.300
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.300 --> 00:00:03.585
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.585 --> 00:00:06.120
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.120 --> 00:00:08.293
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.293 --> 00:00:12.580
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:12.580 --> 00:00:15.140
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.140 --> 00:00:20.190
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our Become a Linux Power User.

8
00:00:20.190 --> 00:00:21.380
Specifically, in this episode,

9
00:00:21.380 --> 00:00:24.500
we are actually doing a part
two on executing commands.

10
00:00:24.500 --> 00:00:27.720
Part one we took a look at
executing some simple commands.

11
00:00:27.720 --> 00:00:30.720
We also took a look at how to look
back at the commands we've executed,

12
00:00:30.720 --> 00:00:33.770
pull up our history and
even re-run some of those commands.

13
00:00:33.770 --> 00:00:35.090
Today we're gonna take
it a step further and

14
00:00:35.090 --> 00:00:38.090
get a little more advanced
with our command execution.

15
00:00:38.090 --> 00:00:40.380
And here to show us the way Is Mr.
Don Pezet.

16
00:00:40.380 --> 00:00:42.570
Welcome, Don.
>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Mike.

17
00:00:42.570 --> 00:00:45.170
And, you know, like you said,
we're going to be continuing what we did.

18
00:00:45.170 --> 00:00:46.810
We saw some basic commands, right?

19
00:00:46.810 --> 00:00:48.170
We saw some kinda neat things.

20
00:00:48.170 --> 00:00:49.850
We started to get our feet wet.

21
00:00:49.850 --> 00:00:52.150
So here in this episode we're
just gonna continue on with that.

22
00:00:52.150 --> 00:00:54.550
We're going to take a look at some other
things we can do from the command line.

23
00:00:54.550 --> 00:00:58.010
And I want to show you guys some
advanced commands where we actually

24
00:00:58.010 --> 00:01:01.110
can execute more than one command,
either simultaneously,

25
00:01:01.110 --> 00:01:05.720
or as one serving as input to another and
they all start to build off each other.

26
00:01:05.720 --> 00:01:09.620
It gets kind of complex fast, but you'll
see how incredibly useful this can be as

27
00:01:09.620 --> 00:01:11.730
we go through and
take a look at some of the examples.

28
00:01:11.730 --> 00:01:14.070
That's what we've got lined up,
right here in this episode.

29
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:15.140
>> Fantastic, all right.

30
00:01:15.140 --> 00:01:17.110
Well, what's first on our list, Don?

31
00:01:17.110 --> 00:01:19.600
>> The first thing I want to talk about
is something I should have mentioned in

32
00:01:19.600 --> 00:01:23.390
the last episode and didn't,
which is Tab auto complete.

33
00:01:23.390 --> 00:01:26.180
Remembering commands is hard, right?

34
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:30.861
It's a difficult thing for somebody,
well, at least somebody my age, I guess.

35
00:01:30.861 --> 00:01:31.994
>> [LAUGH]
>> But for most of us,

36
00:01:31.994 --> 00:01:34.150
we have a hard time remembering commands.

37
00:01:34.150 --> 00:01:38.752
Fortunately in most Linux distributions,
we don't have to remember the commands

38
00:01:38.752 --> 00:01:42.182
completely, we can use something
called Tab auto complete.

39
00:01:42.182 --> 00:01:45.133
If you can type the first couple
of characters in a command name,

40
00:01:45.133 --> 00:01:47.720
you can hit Tab and
it'll finish it off for you, right?

41
00:01:47.720 --> 00:01:52.550
So for example let me show you,
the ifconfig command, right?

42
00:01:52.550 --> 00:01:54.400
That's the interface
configuration command.

43
00:01:54.400 --> 00:01:56.060
That let's me configure network adapters.

44
00:01:56.060 --> 00:01:59.535
It's actually being replaced by a new
command that's part of the IP address

45
00:01:59.535 --> 00:02:02.100
command, but for
right now ifconfig is pretty common.

46
00:02:02.100 --> 00:02:05.010
It's located on most Linux distros and
if you run it,

47
00:02:05.010 --> 00:02:10.070
you see your network adapters and what
they're set up to do and all that, right?

48
00:02:10.070 --> 00:02:12.300
Well, if I don't want to type all that.

49
00:02:12.300 --> 00:02:14.850
Maybe because I can't remember or
maybe because I am a lazy typer,

50
00:02:14.850 --> 00:02:16.170
which is usually my story.

51
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:17.218
>> That's me.

52
00:02:17.218 --> 00:02:20.460
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] so I can type just
the first couple of characters like I-F-C,

53
00:02:20.460 --> 00:02:24.320
and then when I hit Tab,
see how it finished that out.

54
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:26.140
I just hit Tab on my keyboard.

55
00:02:26.140 --> 00:02:29.590
Now, interesting thing about this,
it saves you a lot of time.

56
00:02:29.590 --> 00:02:30.828
Instead of having to
type the whole command,

57
00:02:30.828 --> 00:02:33.126
I just type the first couple of
characters and hit Tab and there it is.

58
00:02:33.126 --> 00:02:36.929
But if I can't remember
exactly the command,

59
00:02:36.929 --> 00:02:41.410
it can also help us find commands, right?

60
00:02:41.410 --> 00:02:44.990
I showed in the last episode
the which command and

61
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:49.840
how if I say which ifconfig it
tells me where it's located.

62
00:02:49.840 --> 00:02:54.190
But I have to know the name of
the command if I say which I-F-C-O,

63
00:02:54.190 --> 00:02:55.800
it doesn't find anything, right?

64
00:02:55.800 --> 00:02:58.820
So I have to know the name
of the command to do that.

65
00:02:58.820 --> 00:03:03.100
But with the Tab autocomplete, I just
need to know the first couple of letters.

66
00:03:03.100 --> 00:03:06.900
But it does get a little tricky because
if I don't type enough characters, right?

67
00:03:06.900 --> 00:03:08.820
So I-F-C, that was fine.

68
00:03:08.820 --> 00:03:13.100
If I do I-F and hit Tab, I get a beep.

69
00:03:13.100 --> 00:03:17.040
Okay, now two things happened and
let me explain what I just did.

70
00:03:17.040 --> 00:03:21.930
First off, I typed I-F and
hit Tab and my computer beeped at me.

71
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:26.891
And that lets me know that I didn't type
enough characters to uniquely identify

72
00:03:26.891 --> 00:03:27.861
that command.

73
00:03:27.861 --> 00:03:30.980
That means there's more than one
command that starts with I-F.

74
00:03:30.980 --> 00:03:36.235
And so if I hit Tab again it shows me
all of the commands that start with I-F.

75
00:03:36.235 --> 00:03:37.987
And where are these commands?

76
00:03:37.987 --> 00:03:39.945
Well they can be in
several different places.

77
00:03:39.945 --> 00:03:42.373
We talked about the path
in the last episode.

78
00:03:42.373 --> 00:03:44.927
The path that it searches the file
system to find these commands.

79
00:03:44.927 --> 00:03:52.500
So if I were to take like if and
whoops, there we go.

80
00:03:52.500 --> 00:03:53.605
If doesn't exist.

81
00:03:53.605 --> 00:03:55.690
Well, that means it's a built-in,
it's a part of the shell.

82
00:03:55.690 --> 00:03:58.000
It's not actually a binary
file on the hard drive.

83
00:03:58.000 --> 00:04:02.460
If I do which ifconfig,
it's in /sbin/ifconfig.

84
00:04:02.460 --> 00:04:06.940
If I do which ifdown, it's in /sbin also.

85
00:04:06.940 --> 00:04:09.970
If I do ifquery,
it's probably in sbin, also.

86
00:04:09.970 --> 00:04:12.720
Yep, so each of those are in sbin.

87
00:04:12.720 --> 00:04:17.290
Except for I-F which is actually a
built-in, cuz it's a programming language.

88
00:04:17.290 --> 00:04:19.140
It's for an if then else loop, right?

89
00:04:19.140 --> 00:04:20.170
That's what that if is.

90
00:04:20.170 --> 00:04:22.180
So that's a different type of thing.

91
00:04:22.180 --> 00:04:26.650
So it's looking across all of those though
to show me commands that start with I-F.

92
00:04:26.650 --> 00:04:30.350
And the idea is that I type I-F,
I hit Tab.

93
00:04:30.350 --> 00:04:33.350
I hit Tab again and
get a list and I say ifconfig.

94
00:04:33.350 --> 00:04:34.820
That's the one I wanted.

95
00:04:34.820 --> 00:04:37.810
And I type enough letters
to make it unique.

96
00:04:37.810 --> 00:04:42.087
No other command starts with I-F-C,
so I can type I-F-C, hit Tab and

97
00:04:42.087 --> 00:04:44.070
it finishes, right?

98
00:04:44.070 --> 00:04:50.890
And it's even gracious enough that once I
do that, it retypes the letters for me.

99
00:04:50.890 --> 00:04:53.240
So I don't have type them again and
I can now add on to it.

100
00:04:53.240 --> 00:04:55.920
Yeah, it's helpful,
although I forget about it sometimes.

101
00:04:55.920 --> 00:04:57.340
Which is why I got this error up here,

102
00:04:57.340 --> 00:05:00.650
where I forget that I-F was already
written and I issued another command.

103
00:05:00.650 --> 00:05:02.320
I do that a lot.

104
00:05:02.320 --> 00:05:03.600
>> I love this feature.

105
00:05:03.600 --> 00:05:04.890
Coming from a Windows environment,

106
00:05:04.890 --> 00:05:10.050
sometimes the case sensitive part of
working in a shell like this gets to me.

107
00:05:10.050 --> 00:05:13.440
And I know that with the Tab autofill,
it'll fix a lot of that for me.

108
00:05:13.440 --> 00:05:14.630
If there's a second or

109
00:05:14.630 --> 00:05:17.700
third word that has a capital first
letter, it takes care of that.

110
00:05:17.700 --> 00:05:18.740
I don't have to worry about that.

111
00:05:18.740 --> 00:05:20.420
>> And this is pretty common, right?

112
00:05:20.420 --> 00:05:24.140
Windows, MacOS,
even Cisco routers use Tab autocomplete.

113
00:05:24.140 --> 00:05:26.977
In fact, I think Cisco routers are one
of the first places that I used Tab

114
00:05:26.977 --> 00:05:28.250
autocomplete.

115
00:05:28.250 --> 00:05:32.090
So that is a common feature to have and
it helps you find those commands.

116
00:05:32.090 --> 00:05:35.100
>> I think Windows is
one of the last ones,

117
00:05:35.100 --> 00:05:37.195
they finally brought it in in Powershell.

118
00:05:37.195 --> 00:05:40.010
>> Yeah, absolutely and
it is incredibly useful.

119
00:05:40.010 --> 00:05:44.820
Now, the Tab auto complete is nice,
that helps us find commands.

120
00:05:44.820 --> 00:05:49.540
We run a command, in the last episode
I was always just running one command.

121
00:05:49.540 --> 00:05:52.570
I was showing you command line
arguments and modifiers but

122
00:05:52.570 --> 00:05:55.030
always running one
command to do something.

123
00:05:55.030 --> 00:05:59.240
But oftentimes,
we want to run more than one command.

124
00:05:59.240 --> 00:06:02.930
And you can do that, you can run them
one at a time, one after the other.

125
00:06:02.930 --> 00:06:07.900
But there's times where you
want the output of one command

126
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:11.470
to serve as the input for
another command, right?

127
00:06:11.470 --> 00:06:14.020
So let me give you an example.

128
00:06:14.020 --> 00:06:17.040
Whoops, let me fix that, there we go.

129
00:06:17.040 --> 00:06:21.390
The dmesg command,
dmesg is a command that shows you

130
00:06:21.390 --> 00:06:24.830
all the hardware detection that
happens when your system boots up.

131
00:06:24.830 --> 00:06:27.520
So if I run dmesg, it's going to run and

132
00:06:27.520 --> 00:06:31.360
here's all the hardware messages
that came when my system booted up.

133
00:06:31.360 --> 00:06:36.360
And if I scroll to the top of it,
well, it's a lot of information.

134
00:06:36.360 --> 00:06:38.380
I'm scrolling and scrolling and scrolling.

135
00:06:38.380 --> 00:06:41.800
Eventually, I'm going to hit my scroll
back buffer which I'm set at 1000 lines,

136
00:06:41.800 --> 00:06:43.700
which sounds like a lot, but

137
00:06:43.700 --> 00:06:47.502
as I scroll back, boy I got a lot
of these warning events here.

138
00:06:47.502 --> 00:06:49.440
[LAUGH], [INAUDIBLE] have that many.

139
00:06:49.440 --> 00:06:53.260
But basically I'm scrolling back and
that's just a lot.

140
00:06:54.520 --> 00:06:59.518
So when I look at something like this,
I might want to see it with pagination,

141
00:06:59.518 --> 00:07:03.122
right, where it pauses every 24 lines or
whatever.

142
00:07:03.122 --> 00:07:06.240
Well, there's a couple of commands
that do that, like the more command.

143
00:07:06.240 --> 00:07:10.840
More will make it show with pagination or
less is very similar.

144
00:07:10.840 --> 00:07:13.250
It lets you have pagination, but
gives you a little bit more power.

145
00:07:13.250 --> 00:07:17.070
So I might want to take
the output of dmesg and

146
00:07:17.070 --> 00:07:20.300
use it as the input to the more command.

147
00:07:20.300 --> 00:07:23.400
And we can do that by doing
what's called pipelining.

148
00:07:23.400 --> 00:07:26.600
And pipelining is incredibly useful.

149
00:07:26.600 --> 00:07:31.320
You take the output from one command and
use it as the input for another.

150
00:07:31.320 --> 00:07:33.760
So for example if I run dmesg itself,

151
00:07:33.760 --> 00:07:37.240
the default output is
what's called standard out.

152
00:07:37.240 --> 00:07:38.020
S-T-D out.

153
00:07:38.020 --> 00:07:39.640
Standard out is your screen.

154
00:07:39.640 --> 00:07:42.181
So when you run the command
it outputs to the screen.

155
