we'll put, 2007, there we go.

382
00:20:17.730 --> 00:20:22.714
And so now what I'm saying is I
am 2017 minus 2007 years old.

383
00:20:22.714 --> 00:20:27.290
And it'll run that and
we run it, I'm 10 years old.

384
00:20:27.290 --> 00:20:30.350
It didn't just display that texturing,
it actually did the math.

385
00:20:30.350 --> 00:20:32.140
And it's the dollar sign
that's telling you.

386
00:20:32.140 --> 00:20:34.248
When it sees that dollar sign,
it says, wait,

387
00:20:34.248 --> 00:20:36.060
[SOUND] this isn't normal text anymore.

388
00:20:36.060 --> 00:20:39.660
This is something special,
I need to expand it, and fill it out here.

389
00:20:39.660 --> 00:20:43.530
Now I put it in square brackets
instead of regular parenthesis

390
00:20:43.530 --> 00:20:46.820
because it's inside of
quote marks like this.

391
00:20:46.820 --> 00:20:49.450
Because it's already kind of enveloped.

392
00:20:49.450 --> 00:20:53.690
So we we need to do that but otherwise
like pillar I use the parenthesis cuz

393
00:20:53.690 --> 00:20:55.180
we're just a regular command and

394
00:20:55.180 --> 00:20:58.666
I didn't have quotes around it so
that's why it's a little bit different.

395
00:20:58.666 --> 00:20:59.413
>> Awesome Don.

396
00:20:59.413 --> 00:21:03.000
And I notice in this one you use
brackets instead of parenthesis there is

397
00:21:03.000 --> 00:21:03.540
reason for that.

398
00:21:03.540 --> 00:21:06.680
You know it is something that I should
have explained while I was doing it.

399
00:21:06.680 --> 00:21:11.080
The big difference here is
that we're doing arithmetic.

400
00:21:11.080 --> 00:21:13.820
When you're doing commands,
you wanna use parenthesis.

401
00:21:13.820 --> 00:21:16.650
When you're doing arithmetic,
you'll use the square brackets.

402
00:21:16.650 --> 00:21:22.460
So I'm not saying run a command 2017 or
run a command minus, run a command 2007.

403
00:21:22.460 --> 00:21:24.720
Those aren't commands.

404
00:21:24.720 --> 00:21:27.695
Versus up here, here,
which is a command and

405
00:21:27.695 --> 00:21:30.785
bash is simply the input to the command.

406
00:21:30.785 --> 00:21:35.325
So that's how we differentiate whether
we're giving it an arithmetic string or

407
00:21:35.325 --> 00:21:37.455
if we're giving it a command to execute.

408
00:21:37.455 --> 00:21:41.750
So for example,
if I wanna do something like here.

409
00:21:41.750 --> 00:21:45.340
I want to count the amount of
files that are in this folder.

410
00:21:45.340 --> 00:21:47.600
And I want it to output the amount
of files that are in here.

411
00:21:47.600 --> 00:21:51.800
Well, you've got a couple of different
commands you can use for that, but

412
00:21:51.800 --> 00:21:52.550
I'll use the WC command.

413
00:21:52.550 --> 00:21:54.589
WC is word count.

414
00:21:54.589 --> 00:21:55.907
And so
you can feed a text file into it, and

415
00:21:55.907 --> 00:21:57.318
it will tell you how
many words are in there.

416
00:21:57.318 --> 00:21:59.341
But you can also have it
tell you how many lines.

417
00:21:59.341 --> 00:22:02.820
Well if I run the LS command,
each line would represent a file.

418
00:22:02.820 --> 00:22:04.790
So I could just count the amount
of lines of output at that and

419
00:22:04.790 --> 00:22:08.100
it will give me a basic count
of how many files I've got.

420
00:22:08.100 --> 00:22:11.670
So we can use the WC command
to do that which is funny for

421
00:22:11.670 --> 00:22:14.996
our British viewers where
the WC is the bathroom.

422
00:22:14.996 --> 00:22:16.640
[LAUGH] So I will.

423
00:22:16.640 --> 00:22:19.910
Echo and just say something like- whoops.

424
00:22:19.910 --> 00:22:21.080
Screw it up.

425
00:22:21.080 --> 00:22:29.180
So I'll say, echo and then there
are dollar sign and open parenthesis.

426
00:22:29.180 --> 00:22:31.100
I'm going back to parentheses cuz
I'm going to issue a command.

427
00:22:31.100 --> 00:22:34.386
And my command is gonna be ls and
let's go crazy.

428
00:22:34.386 --> 00:22:39.214
I'm gonna pipeline that, so I'm taking
the output of ls and piping that into

429
00:22:39.214 --> 00:22:44.750
the wc command, where it will count
the amount of lines that come out, right?

430
00:22:44.750 --> 00:22:47.180
And I'll close
the parentheses on that one.

431
00:22:47.180 --> 00:22:49.690
Files in this directory.

432
00:22:51.180 --> 00:22:53.540
So if you take a look at
that we're combining both.

433
00:22:53.540 --> 00:22:57.560
I've got a command with
a pipeline right here.

434
00:22:57.560 --> 00:23:01.330
And it's being expanded
thanks to our dollar sign.

435
00:23:01.330 --> 00:23:04.993
And what this should result in,
unless I've screwed it up, is,

436
00:23:04.993 --> 00:23:07.269
there are 18 files in this directory.

437
00:23:07.269 --> 00:23:08.555
>> Very cool.

438
00:23:08.555 --> 00:23:13.126
>> Now I may have done some bad things
here because I don't know if that counts

439
00:23:13.126 --> 00:23:14.980
the header row up here or not.

440
00:23:14.980 --> 00:23:16.950
So you have to be aware
of stuff like that.

441
00:23:16.950 --> 00:23:19.790
WC probably counted that little
header row up at the top and so

442
00:23:19.790 --> 00:23:22.290
there's probably 17 files
in this directory, not 18.

443
00:23:22.290 --> 00:23:25.510
So you've got to do a little bit
of work to get the right commands.

444
00:23:25.510 --> 00:23:28.300
But it is neat to see that.

445
00:23:28.300 --> 00:23:30.730
That it'll just expand that out and

446
00:23:30.730 --> 00:23:34.850
you end up with,
basically the straight syntax right there.

447
00:23:34.850 --> 00:23:38.660
It's almost like programming.

448
00:23:38.660 --> 00:23:41.050
You're just issuing commands and
handling the output.

449
00:23:41.050 --> 00:23:42.970
This is stuff you can easily
do from the command line.

450
00:23:42.970 --> 00:23:46.897
And when you're scripting and automating,
you can really do some impressive things.

451
00:23:46.897 --> 00:23:51.206
Now, what we're actually doing
here when we work with expansion.

452
00:23:51.206 --> 00:23:53.079
Is we're working with variables.

453
00:23:53.079 --> 00:23:56.761
And even with pipelining commands in
a way, the output is being temporarily

454
00:23:56.761 --> 00:24:00.970
stored in memory while it serves as
in the input from another command.

455
00:24:00.970 --> 00:24:01.850
That's called Variable Data.

456
00:24:01.850 --> 00:24:04.360
Variable data cuz we don't
know what it is, right?

457
00:24:04.360 --> 00:24:05.986
It's being generated in real time,

458
00:24:05.986 --> 00:24:08.669
so we don't know what the data
is until it actually appears.

459
00:24:08.669 --> 00:24:11.550
The other reason it's variable
is it comes and goes.

460
00:24:11.550 --> 00:24:12.321
It's not gonna be there forever.

461
00:24:12.321 --> 00:24:15.103
And if I reboot the computer
the data is gone.

462
00:24:15.103 --> 00:24:18.760
So it's very, very temporary in nature.

463
00:24:18.760 --> 00:24:21.237
Those variables are very,
very powerful and

464
00:24:21.237 --> 00:24:23.330
there are a lot of them in your system.

465
00:24:23.330 --> 00:24:28.270
We're gonna use them in a number of
episodes here in the power user course.

466
00:24:28.270 --> 00:24:32.139
But if you stay on with us,
I think it's a month or two from now,

467
00:24:32.139 --> 00:24:37.180
we're doing the shell scripting episodes
and we use variable everywhere there.

468
00:24:37.180 --> 00:24:39.300
But even if you don't
think you use variables,

469
00:24:39.300 --> 00:24:41.210
there's plenty of them that are built in.

470
00:24:41.210 --> 00:24:43.860
And we already saw one, we talk about
the PATH in our last episode, right?

471
00:24:43.860 --> 00:24:48.019
So I did echo $PATH,
there's that dollar sign again saying,

472
00:24:48.019 --> 00:24:51.300
something special's about to happen.

473
00:24:51.300 --> 00:24:54.073
But instead of giving it a command or
arithmetic to do,

474
00:24:54.073 --> 00:24:56.743
I didn't do any parentheses,
I just gave it a word.

475
00:24:56.743 --> 00:25:00.154
And that's saying hey there must be
a variable that's storing some data and

476
00:25:00.154 --> 00:25:01.850
that variable must be named PATH.

477
00:25:01.850 --> 00:25:06.692
So we'll just take that and expand it
into the string that appears right here.

478
00:25:06.692 --> 00:25:10.670
And so now it's echo followed
by whatever that string is.

479
00:25:10.670 --> 00:25:12.386
In this case it's our PATH, right?

480
00:25:12.386 --> 00:25:14.880
And there are a lot of
variables like that.

481
00:25:14.880 --> 00:25:18.710
Like, I think we did the whoamI
command in an earlier episode.

482
00:25:18.710 --> 00:25:22.150
If not, here's the whoamI command,
if you forget your username.

483
00:25:22.150 --> 00:25:24.978
First off, it's in my command prompts so
pretty hard to forget that one.

484
00:25:24.978 --> 00:25:28.345
But I can run whoamI and
there is my username, right?

485
00:25:28.345 --> 00:25:31.930
But I can also do echo $USER.

486
00:25:31.930 --> 00:25:36.590
There's a variable called $USER and
I can query that, and there it is.

487
00:25:36.590 --> 00:25:38.170
It contains my user name.

488
00:25:38.170 --> 00:25:39.719
When I run whoami,
that's really all it's doing.

489
00:25:39.719 --> 00:25:42.272
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's looking at that variable,

490
00:25:42.272 --> 00:25:45.669
it's a nice little, like an alias for
pulling out that variable data.

491
00:25:45.669 --> 00:25:48.075
There's a ton of variables.

492
00:25:48.075 --> 00:25:50.825
And if you ever wanna see them,
you can just run the set command and

493
00:25:50.825 --> 00:25:52.327
they'll be output on your screen.

494
00:25:52.327 --> 00:25:58.600
Now, a lot of these variables
are built around functions.

495
00:25:58.600 --> 00:26:01.895
And so when you run set, you'll see
a bunch a functions here like the services

496
00:26:01.895 --> 00:26:04.343
function, and
those are not the variables themselves.

497
00:26:04.343 --> 00:26:07.944
A lot of these are the functions that
tell it how to populate the variable,

498
00:26:07.944 --> 00:26:09.760
how to put information in it.

499
00:26:09.760 --> 00:26:14.710
So for example, here you've got where
it's defining some kind of modification

500
00:26:14.710 --> 00:26:17.199
to the PATH when being run as a root user.

501
00:26:17.199 --> 00:26:20.529
Because the root user has a different
path than regular users do, and so

502
00:26:20.529 --> 00:26:21.540
that's a function.

503
00:26:21.540 --> 00:26:24.186
But if you scroll up towards
the top of this file and

504
00:26:24.186 --> 00:26:26.330
I probably should have set it into less.

505
00:26:26.330 --> 00:26:32.410
You'll actually find where these
things are defined somewhere in here.

506
00:26:32.410 --> 00:26:34.730
I'm about to hit my scroll back limit.

507
00:26:34.730 --> 00:26:37.530
Yeah, there's some good stuff in here,
here they are.

508
00:26:37.530 --> 00:26:40.831
Here's the list of all the variable
that were created in this system and

509
00:26:40.831 --> 00:26:42.271
I didn't make these, right?

510
00:26:42.271 --> 00:26:44.780
These were ones that were already there.

511
00:26:44.780 --> 00:26:49.343
So if look in here for
USER for example, right there.

512
00:26:49.343 --> 00:26:53.250
There it is, that's what I queried
a minute ago, user = dpezet.

513
00:26:53.250 --> 00:26:58.679
Or PATH, PATH will be in here, too,
where it was defined right there.

514
00:26:58.679 --> 00:27:02.495
And, funny enough,
remember in the last episode,

515
00:27:02.495 --> 00:27:04.689
I guess it was,
>> A couple episodes ago.

516
00:27:04.689 --> 00:27:07.946
>> Where I tried to update the PATH
variable and it wasn't working?

517
00:27:07.946 --> 00:27:10.310
Well, I needed to log out and
log back in again.

518
00:27:10.310 --> 00:27:13.070
And, sure enough,
there it is /home/deepslide/manage,

519
00:27:13.070 --> 00:27:14.170
it's added to the path.

520
00:27:14.170 --> 00:27:14.720
>> Right.

521
00:27:14.720 --> 00:27:18.043
>> So when I didn't know why my
command didn't work it actually did

522
00:27:18.043 --> 00:27:18.750
>> It was working

523
00:27:18.750 --> 00:27:20.035
>> Yeah I just didn't log out and back in.

524
00:27:20.035 --> 00:27:22.700
So anyhow you can start to see that.

525
00:27:22.700 --> 00:27:26.765
You can see that information all starting
and there's neat stuff like old PWD.

526
00:27:26.765 --> 00:27:31.457
Old PWD means what directory was I in, in
the file system before the directory I'm

527
00:27:31.457 --> 00:27:34.930
in right now, where did I come from And
so, it tracks there.

528
00:27:34.930 --> 00:27:37.537
So it knows how to get me back
there if I try and go back to it.

529
00:27:37.537 --> 00:27:40.604
It's got all sorts of interesting
stuff that's stored in here and

530
00:27:40.604 --> 00:27:42.421
you can query these whenever you want.

531
00:27:42.421 --> 00:27:46.018
You can use them in scripts or you can
just use them for your own information.

532
00:27:46.018 --> 00:27:51.290
Some of it is really pretty handy,
like pulling up the Bash version.

533
00:27:51.290 --> 00:27:54.805
Look at this one, I'm running Bash and
if I ever wanna know what version of Bash,

534
00:27:54.805 --> 00:27:56.837
well that's a little bit tricky, isn't it?

535
00:27:56.837 --> 00:27:59.481
Well they know, and so
they go through here, and

536
00:27:59.481 --> 00:28:01.685
they map all that out into these values.

537
00:28:01.685 --> 00:28:04.835
This is actually an array that
is building that stores this so

538
00:28:04.835 --> 00:28:07.690
that I can pull the major version,
the minor version.

539
00:28:07.690 --> 00:28:11.366
I can pull the architecture,
you can pull the individual components.

540
00:28:11.366 --> 00:28:14.860
That's why theres these little
sub values 0, 1, 2, 3, and so on.

541
00:28:14.860 --> 00:28:17.555
That's a matrix that it's building and
storing in this variable.

542
00:28:17.555 --> 00:28:21.670
So you can have a table of data
stored inside of a variable.

543
00:28:21.670 --> 00:28:22.847
It's pretty neat stuff.

544
00:28:22.847 --> 00:28:25.720
And all of this is easily updatable.

545
00:28:25.720 --> 00:28:28.212
So if anything changes,
these variables change with them.

546
00:28:28.212 --> 00:28:31.496
That makes it where we can
programmatically query them and

547
00:28:31.496 --> 00:28:33.783
find out what has changed in the system.

548
00:28:33.783 --> 00:28:37.410
So it's pretty neat to be
able to see that stuff.

549
00:28:37.410 --> 00:28:41.516
The shell one is a pretty handy one,
because if we've changed the shell that

550
00:28:41.516 --> 00:28:44.291
we're using there's not
an easy way to spot that.

551
00:28:44.291 --> 00:28:50.170
And so you can always do echo $SHELL, and
it'll tell you which shell that you're in.

552
00:28:50.170 --> 00:28:54.338
Assuming that value has been updated,
a lot of times they don't get updated,

553
00:28:54.338 --> 00:28:56.877
like if I run dash and
now I'm in the dash shell.

554
00:28:56.877 --> 00:28:58.319
And I run echo SHELL,

555
00:28:58.319 --> 00:29:03.217
it still shows /bin/bash because
the variable hasn't been updated.

556
00:29:03.217 --> 00:29:06.520
Something has to trigger
updating that variable.

557
00:29:06.520 --> 00:29:10.024
And with bash when you log in
is what triggers it, right?

558
00:29:10.024 --> 00:29:13.193
So if you're just sitting there
running it's not updating and

559
00:29:13.193 --> 00:29:16.971
that's why my path wasn't reflecting
the change in the earlier episode.

560
00:29:16.971 --> 00:29:20.333
Just be aware that variables
are not always accurate, so

561
00:29:20.333 --> 00:29:23.073
you've always gotta kinda check and
verify.

562
00:29:23.073 --> 00:29:24.920
>> All right Don, great stuff there.

563
00:29:24.920 --> 00:29:28.928
Really getting a little deeper when we
look at executing commands in our shell

564
00:29:28.928 --> 00:29:29.490
in Linux.

565
00:29:29.490 --> 00:29:32.789
So we took a look at tab autocomplete,
piping commands,

566
00:29:32.789 --> 00:29:37.000
executing sequential commands as
well as expanding commands, right?

567
00:29:37.000 --> 00:29:39.139
Running commands within commands.

568
00:29:39.139 --> 00:29:43.420
So fantastic stuff and I know we have
more to do with executing commands.

569
00:29:43.420 --> 00:29:46.290
But unfortunately, we're out of time for
this particular episode.

570
00:29:46.290 --> 00:29:48.945
Anything you want to leave with
them as our parting words?

571
00:29:48.945 --> 00:29:51.746
>> All right, I definitely wanna show you
some other things like how we can modify

572
00:29:51.746 --> 00:29:54.225
variables and make it permanent,
which goes into our user profile.

573
00:29:54.225 --> 00:29:57.593
So that's probably what we'll start in the
next episode if you stay tuned for that.

574
00:29:57.593 --> 00:29:59.685
But we do have a handful
of other commands, and

575
00:29:59.685 --> 00:30:03.400
I still haven't gotten to the really
juicy stuff, which is, the manual system.

576
00:30:03.400 --> 00:30:05.475
Inside of Linux, there's all the
documentation where we get all the help.

577
00:30:05.475 --> 00:30:09.270
So we're gonna tackle that, too, that's
all coming up, so stay tuned for that.

578
00:30:09.270 --> 00:30:10.178
>> All right, looking forward to that.

579
00:30:10.178 --> 00:30:11.690
I hope you guys are, as well.

580
00:30:11.690 --> 00:30:14.218
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

581
00:30:14.218 --> 00:30:15.230
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

582
00:30:15.230 --> 00:30:15.851
>> And we'll see you next time.

00:24:35.070 --> 00:24:37.700
I can see how it's defined,
and I can modify it.

469
00:24:37.700 --> 00:24:40.490
And it's in .bashrc, so
it's loaded every time we boot.

470
00:24:40.490 --> 00:24:43.510
So variables Aliases,
you put them in bashrc,

471
00:24:43.510 --> 00:24:45.460
they'll be there every time you boot.

472
00:24:45.460 --> 00:24:46.270
They can change the prompt,

473
00:24:46.270 --> 00:24:49.440
they can change all sorts of behavior
in the system, it's really neat stuff.

474
00:24:49.440 --> 00:24:52.630
And you can create a system that gives
you the information that you need,

475
00:24:52.630 --> 00:24:53.740
to be able to work with it.

476
00:24:53.740 --> 00:24:56.587
Now like I said, this prompt is crazy,
I don't normally go this way,

477
00:24:56.587 --> 00:24:58.637
I usually [CROSSTALK]
>> I'm surprised you made it this long

478
00:24:58.637 --> 00:24:59.571
without changing it back.

479
00:24:59.571 --> 00:25:00.975
[LAUGH]
>> It is annoying me.

480
00:25:00.975 --> 00:25:03.480
But I normally try and
keep these things as simple as possible.

481
00:25:03.480 --> 00:25:06.110
But do remember, everything that
we're doing here ties to bash.

482
00:25:06.110 --> 00:25:08.890
And not dash or csh or
any of the other guys.

483
00:25:08.890 --> 00:25:11.727
So if you switch shells,
they have their own configuration files,

484
00:25:11.727 --> 00:25:13.387
you'll need to put things in for them.

485
00:25:13.387 --> 00:25:15.585
All right, Mike,
I didn't get to help files.

486
00:25:15.585 --> 00:25:18.672
But I think we can tackle that in yet
another part-

487
00:25:18.672 --> 00:25:19.346
>> Save it for another part?

488
00:25:19.346 --> 00:25:20.043
>> On this thing, yeah.

489
00:25:20.043 --> 00:25:21.867
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, we'll do that then.

490
00:25:21.867 --> 00:25:23.352
We'll save help for the next part.

491
00:25:23.352 --> 00:25:25.581
Hope you enjoyed watching this one,
I know I did.

492
00:25:25.581 --> 00:25:27.692
And we talked a lot about
Aliases variables and

493
00:25:27.692 --> 00:25:29.597
how to make them a little more permanent.

494
00:25:29.597 --> 00:25:32.838
But more useful so you don't have
to define them every single time.

495
00:25:32.838 --> 00:25:35.819
And then how to change our prompt,
customize it to where when we're

496
00:25:35.819 --> 00:25:38.870
in our shell we get the information
we need right there on our prompt.

497
00:25:38.870 --> 00:25:40.250
It's looking the way we want to.

498
00:25:40.250 --> 00:25:41.450
So we thank you for that, Don.

499
00:25:41.450 --> 00:25:43.850
Hope everybody, again,
out there enjoyed watching this one.

500
00:25:43.850 --> 00:25:46.790
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

501
00:25:46.790 --> 00:25:48.858
>> And I'm Don Pezet.
>> And we'll see you next time.

502
00:25:48.858 --> 00:25:55.966
[MUSIC]

503
00:25:55.966 --> 00:25:58.040
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike show how to find help with commands. They demonstrate using the -h and --help options available with most commands. They also look at how to use the man pages to get more detailed help on a command.
episodes.title: Getting Help
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.651
Welcome ITProTV I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.651 --> 00:00:06.358
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.358 --> 00:00:08.204
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.204 --> 00:00:10.092
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.092 --> 00:00:12.190
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:12.190 --> 00:00:15.436
>> Hello and welcome to another
exiting episode here at ITProTV,

7
00:00:15.436 --> 00:00:19.735
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our become a Linux power user.

8
00:00:19.735 --> 00:00:24.432
And in this episode, really focusing on
how we can get help within Linux, and

9
00:00:24.432 --> 00:00:27.480
here to show us how we can do that is Mr.
Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.480 --> 00:00:28.264
Welcome back Don.

11
00:00:28.264 --> 00:00:29.841
>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Mike.

12
00:00:29.841 --> 00:00:32.676
And this is a pretty
important episode I think.

13
00:00:32.676 --> 00:00:36.313
We've seen a lot of cool commands, we've
seen a lot of neat stuff that you can do,

14
00:00:36.313 --> 00:00:37.390
and that's all great.

15
00:00:37.390 --> 00:00:40.620
But when you get out there in
the real world, what you'll find is

16
00:00:40.620 --> 00:00:42.565
it's hard to remember, [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:42.565 --> 00:00:44.641
>> And a lot of these commands have so

18
00:00:44.641 --> 00:00:46.346
many options and tweaks and

19
00:00:46.346 --> 00:00:50.437
things that you can change that
it's too much to memorize it all.

20
00:00:50.437 --> 00:00:52.566
If it is a command you use
every single day, yeah,

21
00:00:52.566 --> 00:00:54.910
you'll remember the options that's great.

22
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:59.427
But if it's a command you don't use every
day, it's hard to remember the syntax and

23
00:00:59.427 --> 00:01:02.431
the stuff that we use to make
the command do what we want.

24
00:01:02.431 --> 00:01:05.827
Or sometimes there might be a very
traditional way we use the command but

25
00:01:05.827 --> 00:01:09.394
then you wanna to use it a little
differently and now you can't remember and

26
00:01:09.394 --> 00:01:11.670
that's where things
really get challenging.

27
00:01:11.670 --> 00:01:14.770
So I wanna show you guys how to pull
up a help on a command to learn

28
00:01:14.770 --> 00:01:19.030
how to use it there's more than one system
in place in Linux to help you learn it.

29
00:01:19.030 --> 00:01:21.654
So it's good to know all
the different methods available so

30
00:01:21.654 --> 00:01:24.970
that we can make sure that we're able
to use the commands when we need them.

31
00:01:24.970 --> 00:01:28.211
>> Fantastic, all right how do we get
started looking for help in Linux?

32
00:01:28.211 --> 00:01:32.771
>> All right well, sometimes the help
is really easy, for example I might

33
00:01:32.771 --> 00:01:38.280
wanna create a file And I know that I can
use the touch command to create a file.

34
00:01:38.280 --> 00:01:40.851
But I might not remember the syntax for
the touch command.

35
00:01:40.851 --> 00:01:43.280
So on some commands,
you can just type the commands.

36
00:01:43.280 --> 00:01:46.830
Like here, if I just type touch and
I press Enter.

37
00:01:46.830 --> 00:01:49.215
It says hey,
you're missing a file operand.

38
00:01:49.215 --> 00:01:52.887
In other words, I didn't give it all
the information it needed to run, and

39
00:01:52.887 --> 00:01:55.585
then it says try touch--help for
more information.

40
00:01:55.585 --> 00:01:56.259
>> Isn't that nice.

41
00:01:56.259 --> 00:01:57.669
>> So, it's giving me a hint here, like,

42
00:01:57.669 --> 00:01:59.985
you probably should have typed
a little more, all right?

43
00:01:59.985 --> 00:02:03.448
Some commands, like tar,
if you just type tar,

44
00:02:03.448 --> 00:02:08.263
you must specify one of
the -A-C-D-T-R-U-X or --delete or

45
00:02:08.263 --> 00:02:12.581
--test-label options In order for
it to run, all right?

46
00:02:12.581 --> 00:02:16.776
But if you don't know what those are, you
can try tar --help, or tar --usage, and

47
00:02:16.776 --> 00:02:18.980
you'll get some information, all right?

48
00:02:18.980 --> 00:02:21.091
So it's giving me hints.

49
00:02:21.091 --> 00:02:26.600
But not every command does that,
some of them, like passwd right?

50
00:02:26.600 --> 00:02:28.479
I can use that to change my password.

51
00:02:28.479 --> 00:02:32.500
And if I just run it, I can actually
give it right here the command line.

52
00:02:32.500 --> 00:02:34.610
And I can tell the user I wanna
reset the password for it,

53
00:02:34.610 --> 00:02:37.210
and even what the password should be if
I want right here in the command line.

54
00:02:37.210 --> 00:02:40.080
But if I just run it, it says,
you forgot some stuff.

55
00:02:40.080 --> 00:02:41.965
So I'll just prompt you for them okay.

56
00:02:41.965 --> 00:02:43.390
Whose password do you wanna change?

57
00:02:43.390 --> 00:02:44.775
Do you wanna change your own?

58
00:02:44.775 --> 00:02:46.150
You can do it, right?

59
00:02:46.150 --> 00:02:48.408
Or I can type in a different user,
I can try and

60
00:02:48.408 --> 00:02:52.512
type in a different user, I'm sorry,
its asked me for my current password,

61
00:02:52.512 --> 00:02:56.635
it is changing my password, this is soon
my user, changing password for dpezet.

62
00:02:56.635 --> 00:02:59.474
And it wants to know my current
password and so I can punch that in

63
00:02:59.474 --> 00:03:03.350
which I've already screwed up I think, and
now what I want my new password to be.

64
00:03:03.350 --> 00:03:05.810
So it's just prompting me for
those things.

65
00:03:05.810 --> 00:03:07.000
Some commands do that and

66
00:03:07.000 --> 00:03:11.900
that's pretty handy because I
don't have to remember the syntax.

67
00:03:11.900 --> 00:03:13.213
We can just do it this way.

68
00:03:13.213 --> 00:03:17.840
The only negative of doing it this
way is that it doesn't work for

69
00:03:17.840 --> 00:03:21.005
non-interactive commands, right?

70
00:03:21.005 --> 00:03:22.723
And boy it is just not
gonna let me cancel that,

71
00:03:22.723 --> 00:03:24.232
it's gonna make me change my password.

72
00:03:24.232 --> 00:03:25.653
>> [LAUGH]
>> It doesn't work for

73
00:03:25.653 --> 00:03:28.440
non-interactive commands,
which means if I'm writing a script,

74
00:03:28.440 --> 00:03:30.715
a script,
you can't prompt the script for imput.

75
00:03:30.715 --> 00:03:33.535
The script needs to be able
to provide the input right

76
00:03:33.535 --> 00:03:34.985
off the bat without messing with anything.

77
00:03:36.030 --> 00:03:40.415
So, this type of a solution is not
necessarily the greatest for a script.

78
00:03:40.415 --> 00:03:45.216
I might need to find out what that
actual syntax is in order to provide

79
00:03:45.216 --> 00:03:49.693
the right values and get the run
in my script the way that I want.

80
00:03:49.693 --> 00:03:55.240
So on some commands,
you can issue things like, passwd?, right?

81
00:03:55.240 --> 00:03:58.220
And that question mark will
trigger it to show a help file.

82
00:03:58.220 --> 00:04:00.750
But more and
more commands have moved away from than.

83
00:04:00.750 --> 00:04:02.310
It's a very old syntax.

84
00:04:02.310 --> 00:04:03.481
We don't normally see it anymore.

85
00:04:03.481 --> 00:04:09.264
Instead, most of them have switched
to using -h or --help right.

86
00:04:09.264 --> 00:04:13.224
-h though, is getting to be less and
less common, because there's so

87
00:04:13.224 --> 00:04:14.947
many letters in the alphabet.

88
00:04:14.947 --> 00:04:18.730
And there's some commands
that have a ton of options.

89
00:04:18.730 --> 00:04:22.590
They need that h to represent something,
so they use the word notation.

90
00:04:22.590 --> 00:04:24.820
And this is usually the safer one, right?

91
00:04:24.820 --> 00:04:26.911
Let me give you an example of ls, right?

92
00:04:26.911 --> 00:04:30.780
If I just run ls by itself,
It actually is a default set of options.

93
00:04:30.780 --> 00:04:32.245
And so it's gonna run the command.

94
00:04:32.245 --> 00:04:34.715
Might not prompt me for help or
anything like that, it actually runs it.

95
00:04:34.715 --> 00:04:38.010
>> All right and we've made an alias for
that last episode, right?

96
00:04:38.010 --> 00:04:38.746
>> Right, fair enough, right.

97
00:04:38.746 --> 00:04:40.330
So an alias can break the help too.

98
00:04:40.330 --> 00:04:42.160
So let's just unalias that real quick.

99
00:04:42.160 --> 00:04:43.640
So I'll unalias ls.

100
00:04:43.640 --> 00:04:45.526
And now when I run it there it is, right?

101
00:04:45.526 --> 00:04:48.730
It's a default set of
options that it uses.

102
00:04:48.730 --> 00:04:51.999
So it's not gonna say,
you can type --help.

103
00:04:51.999 --> 00:04:52.808
It's not gonna tell you that.

104
00:04:52.808 --> 00:04:56.268
And if I do ls-h, well -h for ls is,

105
00:04:56.268 --> 00:05:01.090
show the file sizes in
a human readable format.

106
00:05:01.090 --> 00:05:03.575
Well, I'm not even showing
file sizes here so

107
00:05:03.575 --> 00:05:05.120
-h doesn't really do an anything, right?

108
00:05:05.120 --> 00:05:09.600
I'd have to do ls-l and
now I see those long file sizes, and

109
00:05:09.600 --> 00:05:11.380
then if you throw the h, and it is.

110
00:05:11.380 --> 00:05:13.380
So h isn't help, right?

111
00:05:13.380 --> 00:05:18.384
But if I do --help, and
I use that word, there it is.

112
00:05:18.384 --> 00:05:20.416
Now I get the help for that command.

113
00:05:20.416 --> 00:05:23.370
So the key one to remember
here is really --help.

114
00:05:23.370 --> 00:05:27.031
And I know that's the Is
the BSD notation for help,

115
00:05:27.031 --> 00:05:29.682
when use the longer words like that.

116
00:05:29.682 --> 00:05:32.598
But so many programs actually use -h for

117
00:05:32.598 --> 00:05:36.470
something other than help
that it's pretty common.

118
00:05:36.470 --> 00:05:40.951
So if you only remember one option,
--help is probably the best one.

119
00:05:40.951 --> 00:05:46.282
And you'll find that most commands have
that, so if I do passwd --help, and I run

120
00:05:46.282 --> 00:05:52.760
that there, I get the help output, instead
of it prompting me to change my password.

121
00:05:52.760 --> 00:05:56.288
We can do,
what was the other command I did touch,

122
00:05:56.288 --> 00:05:59.742
touch --help, and
I can see it's in tags too.

123
00:05:59.742 --> 00:06:02.757
>> So even if a command supports
a -h to pull up the help,

124
00:06:02.757 --> 00:06:06.588
you can still do a --help, and
that way you know it's gonna work?

125
00:06:06.588 --> 00:06:10.800
>> Right, yeah,
--help works in almost every situation.

126
00:06:10.800 --> 00:06:13.640
The reality is that Linux
is an open source project.

127
00:06:13.640 --> 00:06:17.170
And anybody who writes a program
can choose to support whatever

128
00:06:17.170 --> 00:06:18.480
command arguments they want, right.

129
00:06:18.480 --> 00:06:20.590
So they may choose not to support .--help.

130
00:06:20.590 --> 00:06:23.145
But it is pretty standard for
--help to be there.

131
00:06:23.145 --> 00:06:25.590
That's the one that I usually try first.

132
00:06:25.590 --> 00:06:28.603
Now the help screen that you see may or
may not be incredibly useful.

133
00:06:28.603 --> 00:06:30.745
Because, again,
it's an open-source project, so

134
00:06:30.745 --> 00:06:33.390
sometimes people have written
really good help documentation.

135
00:06:33.390 --> 00:06:34.605
Sometimes it's garbage, right.

136
00:06:34.605 --> 00:06:36.700
That's just the reality of it.

137
00:06:36.700 --> 00:06:39.715
Most developers are not
good documentarians, right.

138
00:06:39.715 --> 00:06:41.731
>> [LAUGH]
>> So when I look at touch's help,

139
00:06:41.731 --> 00:06:46.449
touch --help I can see some basic
information here on the file command line

140
00:06:46.449 --> 00:06:50.280
arguments that I can use -h means,
don't create a new file,

141
00:06:50.280 --> 00:06:52.511
just change the access time right?

142
00:06:52.511 --> 00:06:56.511
So I'm taking an existing file and
updating i's time stamp to show it was

143
00:06:56.511 --> 00:06:59.600
modified even thought I
didn't actually modify it.

144
00:06:59.600 --> 00:07:04.547
-c means I don't wanna create a file,
I want to touch an existing file or

145
00:07:04.547 --> 00:07:09.186
not do anything, so you're looking for
the existence of the file.

146
00:07:09.186 --> 00:07:12.822
-d I can give a text
sting to change the date,

147
00:07:12.822 --> 00:07:17.799
you can actually modify the date
of something -f is ignored,

148
00:07:17.799 --> 00:07:22.040
-f does not even do anything so
why is -f even here?

149
00:07:22.040 --> 00:07:25.120
Well that is likely some deprecated
feature that is gone now and so

150
00:07:25.120 --> 00:07:28.705
they leave it in there so you know that
is it actually not supported anymore.

151
00:07:28.705 --> 00:07:31.890
Each of these is performing
a different function.

152
00:07:31.890 --> 00:07:35.240
This one doesn't actually have
a whole heck of a lot of options.

153
00:07:35.240 --> 00:07:38.541
And so when you look at it,
it is a fairly small help file.

154
00:07:38.541 --> 00:07:43.650
But if you take other commands like tar,
tar has a lot of options.

155
00:07:43.650 --> 00:07:46.343
And so when we start to look at it,
It's a little daunting.

156
00:07:46.343 --> 00:07:48.280
How much documentation is in there.

157
00:07:48.280 --> 00:07:50.850
In fact, I'm still in tar, there we go.

158
00:07:50.850 --> 00:07:51.880
That's where it started.

159
00:07:51.880 --> 00:07:54.076
And there's a good eight or
nine pages of syntax here.

160
00:07:54.076 --> 00:07:57.291
Tar is a very powerful and
it's the tape archive utility.

161
00:07:57.291 --> 00:08:00.741
It lets you combine multiple files into
a single file, which is really handy.

162
00:08:00.741 --> 00:08:04.246
For backups, so I know I used tar a lot.

163
00:08:04.246 --> 00:08:09.265
And when I use it,
I always say, tar xvzf and

164
00:08:09.265 --> 00:08:15.825
then a file name,
I usually do a dash cuz I like it to work.

165
00:08:15.825 --> 00:08:20.460
[LAUGH] What this does is it
takes a tarred gzip file, a TGZ.

166
00:08:20.460 --> 00:08:24.720
It unzips it, untars it,
does verbose output on the screens so

167
00:08:24.720 --> 00:08:25.300
I can see everything.

168
00:08:25.300 --> 00:08:26.880
It dumps the files out, right?

169
00:08:26.880 --> 00:08:28.390
That's how I use it.

170
00:08:28.390 --> 00:08:29.520
So I've got that memorized.

171
00:08:29.520 --> 00:08:32.240
I know those four letters, X, V, Z, F.

172
00:08:32.240 --> 00:08:37.650
But what if I want to not unzip something,
but zip it and tar it?

173
00:08:37.650 --> 00:08:41.460
I don't remember those and so I'll have to
pull up the help and come in here and find

174
00:08:41.460 --> 00:08:46.350
that and the X that I specified and there
is one that actually stands for extract.

175
00:08:46.350 --> 00:08:48.050
I'm extracting the files.

176
00:08:48.050 --> 00:08:53.350
Well, if you leave it off, the default
is to combine the files to tar them.

177
00:08:53.350 --> 00:08:57.637
And so, basically, we leave the X off and
you basically go through here and read.

178
00:08:57.637 --> 00:09:01.360
And some of them do this, this is my
favorite, will they give you examples.

179
00:09:01.360 --> 00:09:04.200
If you're just trying to
create a tar archive,

180
00:09:04.200 --> 00:09:08.730
do tar -cf, the name of the archive and
then all of files you wanna stick in it.

181
00:09:08.730 --> 00:09:10.230
There you go.
There's a great example.

182
00:09:10.230 --> 00:09:12.350
But they don't always
give examples like that.

183
00:09:12.350 --> 00:09:14.870
When they do, though,
it is pretty beneficial.

184
00:09:14.870 --> 00:09:18.856
Now, this help is coming
from the command itself and

185
00:09:18.856 --> 00:09:22.852
it's up to the author of
the command to create that.

186
00:09:22.852 --> 00:09:26.802
And if you come along and you find some
help documentation like that as garbage

187
00:09:26.802 --> 00:09:28.701
and you say I'm gonna rewrite that.

But anyhow, so you can jump in,
you can find that information.

416
00:21:33.660 --> 00:21:35.330
Definitely a handy thing to do.

417
00:21:35.330 --> 00:21:36.790
Don't shy away from these man pages.

418
00:21:36.790 --> 00:21:40.690
As you're learning all these commands,
these are incredibly useful,

419
00:21:40.690 --> 00:21:42.110
it's really gonna help out.

420
00:21:42.110 --> 00:21:45.150
If you're just in a hurry,
you can try --help, and

421
00:21:45.150 --> 00:21:48.780
you might find exactly what you want right
there, but it's not gonna be exhaustive.

422
00:21:48.780 --> 00:21:53.760
If you wanna really learn how a command
works, the manual pages are the way to go.

423
00:21:53.760 --> 00:21:56.821
And oftentimes, when you go to
the various websites for register,

424
00:21:56.821 --> 00:22:00.582
you won't find great documentation because
they know the man pages are there, and

425
00:22:00.582 --> 00:22:04.010
they've got a ton of data
tucked away inside of them.

426
00:22:04.010 --> 00:22:05.860
>> All right, Don,
that's great stuff there.

427
00:22:05.860 --> 00:22:10.100
How I can get help with commands and
everything else within Linux.

428
00:22:10.100 --> 00:22:12.180
I've got you here, I'm lucky.

429
00:22:12.180 --> 00:22:15.460
When you're not around though, now I
know I can go into my man commands and

430
00:22:15.460 --> 00:22:17.380
pull out those man pages.

431
00:22:17.380 --> 00:22:20.640
We appreciate that, Don, we hope
everyone out there enjoyed this one.

432
00:22:20.640 --> 00:22:23.520
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Mike Roderick.

433
00:22:23.520 --> 00:22:24.096
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

434
00:22:24.096 --> 00:22:26.433
>> And we'll see you next time.

435
00:22:26.433 --> 00:22:32.422
[MUSIC]

436
00:22:32.422 --> 00:22:35.126
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike take a look at the Linux filesystem hierarchy. They look at the key folders and explain there purpose.
episodes.title: Filesystem Hierarchy
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.078
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.078 --> 00:00:02.311
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.311 --> 00:00:06.705
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.705 --> 00:00:08.425
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.425 --> 00:00:12.258
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.258 --> 00:00:15.928
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.928 --> 00:00:20.200
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we/re doing become a Linux power user.

8
00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:24.442
Specifically in this episode, we're gonna
be taking a look at the file system

9
00:00:24.442 --> 00:00:27.020
hierarchy in a Linux operating system.

10
00:00:27.020 --> 00:00:31.280
Here to guide us through this
incredible maze is Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:31.280 --> 00:00:32.110
Welcome, Don.

12
00:00:32.110 --> 00:00:35.540
>> Hey, thank you, Mike, and
it is a good bit of a maze.

13
00:00:35.540 --> 00:00:38.410
The way that Unix and
Linux file system is defined

14
00:00:38.410 --> 00:00:43.242
has not really changed all that much from
how it was defined back in the 1970s.

15
00:00:43.242 --> 00:00:47.550
And that's not really user friendly.

16
00:00:47.550 --> 00:00:50.215
And so a lot distributions have
done things to improve that,

17
00:00:50.215 --> 00:00:51.791
to make it easier for people to use.

18
00:00:51.791 --> 00:00:55.125
But as soon as you get out from
under the shield of your distro,

19
00:00:55.125 --> 00:00:57.946
you'll see there's a lot of random,
I say random,

20
00:00:57.946 --> 00:01:02.290
what appears to be random stuff on
the hard drive that's actually important.

21
00:01:02.290 --> 00:01:03.750
That serves a particular purpose.

22
00:01:03.750 --> 00:01:07.460
So we're going to basically run through
some of that directory structure and let

23
00:01:07.460 --> 00:01:12.140
you guys know what exactly each piece does
and why it's there, and when it gets used.

24
00:01:12.140 --> 00:01:14.080
That's all good information to know.

25
00:01:14.080 --> 00:01:17.600
As opposed to just trying to guess based
on some weird combination of letters-

26
00:01:17.600 --> 00:01:18.460
>> [LAUGH] Right?

27
00:01:18.460 --> 00:01:20.575
>> Somebody picked in 1979,
which happens all too often.

28
00:01:20.575 --> 00:01:22.222
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's our plan for this episode.

29
00:01:22.222 --> 00:01:23.816
[LAUGH]
>> All right, sounds good.

30
00:01:23.816 --> 00:01:27.750
So it's a little different from
if you're a Windows person.

31
00:01:27.750 --> 00:01:30.250
It's really not arranged the same way,
is it?

32
00:01:30.250 --> 00:01:31.020
>> Yeah, you know what?

33
00:01:31.020 --> 00:01:35.106
On a Windows hard drive you have,
what, two folders that are important,

34
00:01:35.106 --> 00:01:37.350
C:/Windows and C:/Program Files.

35
00:01:37.350 --> 00:01:39.780
Everything else you can delete and
it doesn't really matter.

36
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:41.147
Well, in the Unix world,
it's not like that.

37
00:01:41.147 --> 00:01:42.810
We've got a ton of stuff.

38
00:01:42.810 --> 00:01:47.990
First off, there is no C:, so
hard drives aren't given letters at all.

39
00:01:47.990 --> 00:01:50.360
Everything is just represented as a file.

40
00:01:50.360 --> 00:01:54.050
And that's actually one of the tenats of
Unix that goes way back to the 1970s,

41
00:01:54.050 --> 00:01:57.300
is that when they created
the original Unix,

42
00:01:57.300 --> 00:02:02.160
they wanted everything to be
addressable as a file, right?

43
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:04.880
That means if you have a file,
it's a file.

44
00:02:04.880 --> 00:02:06.980
If you have a folder,
it shows up as a file.

45
00:02:06.980 --> 00:02:10.850
If you have a sound card or
a video card, it shows up as a file.

46
00:02:10.850 --> 00:02:14.030
If there's a running process,
it shows up as a file.

47
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:15.613
Everything shows up as a file.

48
00:02:15.613 --> 00:02:16.960
Well, not everything.

49
00:02:16.960 --> 00:02:19.420
Certain things like memory blocks,
they don't show up as files.

50
00:02:19.420 --> 00:02:23.080
There's another operating system out there
called Plan 9, which is actually from

51
00:02:23.080 --> 00:02:29.010
Bell Labs also, that they went extreme and
literally everything shows up as a file.

52
00:02:29.010 --> 00:02:31.230
But in Unix most things do.

53
00:02:31.230 --> 00:02:33.520
And because most things
are showing up as a file,

54
00:02:33.520 --> 00:02:36.370
that's what creates
the complexity in our file system.

55
00:02:36.370 --> 00:02:38.690
A regular user is shielded from this,
right?

56
00:02:38.690 --> 00:02:41.150
Let me show you my user account.

57
00:02:41.150 --> 00:02:43.022
So if I go into my computer, and

58
00:02:43.022 --> 00:02:46.890
I fire up my file manager,
It takes me to my home directory.

59
00:02:46.890 --> 00:02:51.080
Into my home directory, I see, well some
of the junk I put in there, I guess.

60
00:02:51.080 --> 00:02:54.208
But I see some standard things
like desktop, documents,

61
00:02:54.208 --> 00:02:57.635
downloads, examples,
music, pictures, public.

62
00:02:57.635 --> 00:02:58.715
That stuff makes sense.

63
00:02:59.865 --> 00:03:02.055
Music, I wonder what's in that folder?

64
00:03:02.055 --> 00:03:03.005
We understand.

65
00:03:03.005 --> 00:03:04.285
We know what those things are.

66
00:03:04.285 --> 00:03:05.705
It's not a big deal.

67
00:03:05.705 --> 00:03:10.747
And they're even written nicely,
with the capital first letter.

68
00:03:10.747 --> 00:03:13.433
And in the Unix world,
everything's normally lower case, so

69
00:03:13.433 --> 00:03:16.510
that's not what you normally see,
these capital letters.

70
00:03:16.510 --> 00:03:18.870
That's written as kid gloves, right.

71
00:03:18.870 --> 00:03:22.530
They're protecting the end user from
the complexity behind the system.

72
00:03:22.530 --> 00:03:24.030
They wanna make it easy.

73
00:03:24.030 --> 00:03:28.250
But if you just browse outside of that, if
you browse outside of your home folders.

74
00:03:28.250 --> 00:03:30.860
So for example,
if I go to other locations and

75
00:03:30.860 --> 00:03:36.300
I'll browse right into my computer,
now I'm in the root of my computer.

76
00:03:36.300 --> 00:03:41.280
And in the root, you can see all
sorts of really interesting folders

77
00:03:41.280 --> 00:03:43.210
that are meaningless to most people,
right?

78
00:03:43.210 --> 00:03:45.700
Most people look at it and they see dev.

79
00:03:45.700 --> 00:03:46.560
What is that?

80
00:03:46.560 --> 00:03:49.658
Boot, CDROM, I don't even have
a CDROM in this computer, right?

81
00:03:49.658 --> 00:03:53.010
And you see these folders and
they don't mean anything.

82
00:03:53.010 --> 00:03:54.350
But they are important.

83
00:03:54.350 --> 00:03:55.620
It's not that they're unimportant.

84
00:03:55.620 --> 00:03:59.810
They all serve a purpose
if you know what it is.

85
00:03:59.810 --> 00:04:02.140
And a regular user doesn't have to
mess with them, but as a power user,

86
00:04:02.140 --> 00:04:05.060
there will be times you've got to go into
these folders and tinker around a bit.

87
00:04:05.060 --> 00:04:07.900
So we'll kind of browse through and
take a look at these.

88
00:04:07.900 --> 00:04:11.420
But the majority of these
are created automatically.

89
00:04:11.420 --> 00:04:18.778
They're created as part of the Linux
Filesystem Hierarchy Standard, the FHS.

90
00:04:18.778 --> 00:04:22.740
And Red Hat, Ubuntu, Debian,
several distros are all

91
00:04:22.740 --> 00:04:26.520
part of this alliance that says, we're
gonna follow this filesystem hierarchy.

92
00:04:26.520 --> 00:04:28.610
And it's important they do.

93
00:04:28.610 --> 00:04:30.810
Because let's say you're a developer and
you wanna write a program.

94
00:04:30.810 --> 00:04:34.160
And your program needs to store
configuration files somewhere.

95
00:04:34.160 --> 00:04:37.030
Well, you don't wanna it to go out and
research 80 different distros to

96
00:04:37.030 --> 00:04:39.080
figure out where they all store
their different config files, and

97
00:04:39.080 --> 00:04:41.970
so what would happen is those
developers would say forget it.

98
00:04:41.970 --> 00:04:45.540
I'm just gonna support the most
popular distro and that's it, right?

99
00:04:45.540 --> 00:04:50.915
And that hurts innovation, right, it
hurts new distros that are just starting.

100
00:04:50.915 --> 00:04:55.175
So by following a standard file system
hierarchy, now a developer can write

101
00:04:55.175 --> 00:04:59.395
an application once and know, hey, if I
put my config files in /etc, that's gonna

102
00:04:59.395 --> 00:05:04.665
exist on all these other distros out there
.And it makes things work a lot nicer.

103
00:05:04.665 --> 00:05:07.515
So in Linux,
you've got the freedom to change.

104
00:05:07.515 --> 00:05:10.820
Any distro could choose not to
follow the file system hierarchy.

105
00:05:10.820 --> 00:05:11.350
But if they do,

106
00:05:11.350 --> 00:05:15.380
it's really gonna hurt their ability to
have developers writing software for them.

107
00:05:15.380 --> 00:05:17.680
So most of them follow
a standard hierarchy.

108
00:05:17.680 --> 00:05:21.980
So everything I'm about to show you
is going to be pretty much the same

109
00:05:21.980 --> 00:05:26.630
on Red Hat, Ubuntu, Debian, Mint, whatever
distro flavor of the day you're running.

110
00:05:26.630 --> 00:05:29.146
They all follow the same kind of standard.

111
00:05:29.146 --> 00:05:32.260
All right,
I am gonna dump out of the GUI, though.

112
00:05:32.260 --> 00:05:34.560
Let me get into my terminal, whoops,

113
00:05:34.560 --> 00:05:38.786
not that terminal, one of my
assorted collection of terminals.

114
00:05:38.786 --> 00:05:42.352
And I wanna kinda walk through the file
system and some of the files and

115
00:05:42.352 --> 00:05:45.565
folders that are important and
some that are less important.

116
00:05:45.565 --> 00:05:49.472
But if we just take a look at
our root directory, all right,

117
00:05:49.472 --> 00:05:51.680
we see a lot of stuff in here.

118
00:05:51.680 --> 00:05:55.823
Now I have got this colorized right now,
so you'll see a few things in light blue,

119
00:05:55.823 --> 00:05:58.781
those are files, and
I've got initrd.img and vmlinuz.

120
00:05:58.781 --> 00:06:02.779
There's .old versions of both of those
which just means that I've upgraded and

121
00:06:02.779 --> 00:06:04.970
it backed up the previous version, right?

122
00:06:04.970 --> 00:06:08.309
Initrd.img, that's the initial
boot loading image.

123
00:06:08.309 --> 00:06:11.371
When Ubuntu, for me, when it starts up,

124
00:06:11.371 --> 00:06:14.877
that initrd.img is
actually copied into RAM.

125
00:06:14.877 --> 00:06:18.244
And then it starts firing up all
the various services, and system.d, and

126
00:06:18.244 --> 00:06:21.220
all the other things that
power my distribution.

127
00:06:21.220 --> 00:06:26.142
And then vmlinuz over here is actually
what's tying into the Linux kernel.

128
00:06:26.142 --> 00:06:28.980
And it is the heart of the system's up and
running.

129
00:06:28.980 --> 00:06:30.780
And Ubuntu chooses to
stick those right here.

130
00:06:30.780 --> 00:06:33.060
Other distros stick them
inside of the boot folders, so

131
00:06:33.060 --> 00:06:36.510
they'll be kind of hidden away instead
of sitting here right in the root.

132
00:06:36.510 --> 00:06:40.880
Different distros handle that differently,
but the folders themselves,

133
00:06:40.880 --> 00:06:42.390
everything in dark blue,

134
00:06:42.390 --> 00:06:45.840
that's where we start getting the things
that are a lot more standard, okay?

135
00:06:45.840 --> 00:06:49.090
And they're listed here alphabetically, so
I'll kinda go that way, but I'm gonna skip

136
00:06:49.090 --> 00:06:52.420
around a bit cuz some of these files and
folders are related to each other.

137
00:06:52.420 --> 00:06:54.160
So I'll jump around a little bit.

138
00:06:54.160 --> 00:06:57.140
But starting right here at
the beginning is bin, right?

139
00:06:57.140 --> 00:07:02.250
So it would just be cd /bin for
the bin folder.

140
00:07:02.250 --> 00:07:03.850
Bin is short for binary.

141
00:07:03.850 --> 00:07:06.210
And binary usually means a program.

142
00:07:06.210 --> 00:07:07.240
And that's exactly what this means.

143
00:07:07.240 --> 00:07:10.970
This is a folder that's gonna store
programs, but not just any programs.

144
00:07:10.970 --> 00:07:14.020
These are programs that are installed
as part of the operating system and

145
00:07:14.020 --> 00:07:16.500
that are critical to
the operating system functioning.

146
00:07:16.500 --> 00:07:19.011
These are things that we really,
really need to have, right?

147
00:07:19.011 --> 00:07:23.339
And so if you browse into that folder and
you pull up a listing of what's in there,

148
00:07:23.339 --> 00:07:25.885
you'll see a lot of
really interesting stuff,

149
00:07:25.885 --> 00:07:28.510
a lot of commands that you
run on a regular basis.

150
00:07:28.510 --> 00:07:30.740
Like there's cp, the copy command.

151
00:07:30.740 --> 00:07:33.350
Just doing a basic copy or move.

152
00:07:33.350 --> 00:07:36.270
Most of our file system commands
are located right in here.

153
00:07:36.270 --> 00:07:39.330
The echo command that we've
been using in several episodes.

154
00:07:39.330 --> 00:07:42.670
Those are there, and they're considered
critical to the operating system working.

155
00:07:42.670 --> 00:07:44.870
I've got to have those.

156
00:07:44.870 --> 00:07:50.640
There is a similar folder to bin
which is called Sbin, all right?

157
00:07:50.640 --> 00:07:54.042
And Sbin also has binaries in it, right?

158
00:07:54.042 --> 00:07:55.985
So these are our support binaries.

159
00:07:55.985 --> 00:07:59.780
And if you take a look in here, you'll
see, again, a lot of interesting programs

160
00:07:59.780 --> 00:08:02.585
These are ones that are installed
as part of the system also,

161
00:08:02.585 --> 00:08:04.540
but they're not critical.

162
00:08:04.540 --> 00:08:05.800
I could get rid of some of these, and

163
00:08:05.800 --> 00:08:09.390
it might break something, but
the operating system would still work.

164
00:08:09.390 --> 00:08:14.800
So for example here, WPA, action,
CLI, and supplicant, those

165
00:08:14.800 --> 00:08:20.390
are all used when we connect to a wireless
network that uses WPA encryption or WPA2.

166
00:08:20.390 --> 00:08:25.900
Well, if I delete those I can join
a wireless network with WPA2, all right?

167
00:08:25.900 --> 00:08:27.620
But my operating system still works.

168
00:08:27.620 --> 00:08:29.810
I can still boot up,
I can still run programs, right?

169
00:08:29.810 --> 00:08:31.120
So it's not critical.

170
00:08:31.120 --> 00:08:34.610
It's important, but it's not critical,
and those things go into S bin.

171
00:08:35.650 --> 00:08:36.600
Now, slash bin and

172
00:08:36.600 --> 00:08:40.290
slash S bin will be fully populated
when you install your operating system.

173
00:08:40.290 --> 00:08:43.300
And you rarely if ever touch them right?

174
00:08:43.300 --> 00:08:45.640
Usually they only get touched when
you upgrade your operating system.

175
00:08:45.640 --> 00:08:49.100
So if I upgrade it might update those and
add some stuff to it.

176
00:08:49.100 --> 00:08:52.810
Or if I'm installing official
packages from my distribution.

177
00:08:52.810 --> 00:08:55.630
They'll add things in there occasionally,
but for

178
00:08:55.630 --> 00:08:58.940
the most part, /bin and /sbin don't
get messed with all that much, right.

179
00:09:00.890 --> 00:09:06.660
Instead, there's a second copy of both of
these folders inside of another folder.

180
00:09:06.660 --> 00:09:11.270
Here's what they, they all get related, so
if I go back to my root folder and look,

181
00:09:11.270 --> 00:09:16.680
so I was just talking about bin and,
sbin, right?

182
00:09:16.680 --> 00:09:19.590
There's another folder in here called usr.

183
00:09:19.590 --> 00:09:20.800
Usr, right there.

184
00:09:20.800 --> 00:09:22.570
And that's short for user.

185
00:09:22.570 --> 00:09:24.900
And these are user binaries.

186
00:09:24.900 --> 00:09:26.910
Not just binaries,
there's other things in here too, but

187
00:09:26.910 --> 00:09:28.850
this is user stuff, how about that?

188
00:09:28.850 --> 00:09:33.310
So, now when we install things,
they'll go in USR.

189
00:09:33.310 --> 00:09:37.697
And so if I go into that USR folder and
take a look,

190
00:09:37.697 --> 00:09:43.120
I'll find another bin folder and
another S bin folder.

191
00:09:43.120 --> 00:09:47.540
So, /user /bin, and /user / s bin.

192
00:09:47.540 --> 00:09:49.570
These are programs that we've installed.

193
00:09:49.570 --> 00:09:53.010
Its not part of the base operating system,
although it might be from the vendor so it

194
00:09:53.010 --> 00:09:56.424
might be something I got from Ubuntu but
its not part of the base operating system.

195
00:09:56.424 --> 00:10:01.510
So its not considered necessary or
even useful as far as the OS is concerned.

196
00:10:01.510 --> 00:10:04.790
But that we've installed and added on.

197
00:10:04.790 --> 00:10:06.870
And here you'll find things change a lot.

198
00:10:06.870 --> 00:10:13.170
Now, technically, this is the official
standard, the slash USR folder,

199
00:10:13.170 --> 00:10:16.030
is supposed to be mounted read only,
in other words we never change it.

200
00:10:16.030 --> 00:10:18.680
You got files in here
that users make use of,

201
00:10:18.680 --> 00:10:22.140
the regular users not the administrators
and that it doesnt get changed.

202
00:10:22.140 --> 00:10:25.081
But not every distro does that,
you will find many distros where

203
00:10:25.081 --> 00:10:27.872
when you install programs they
go right here into slash USR.

204
00:10:27.872 --> 00:10:34.200
Now, you might ask yourself, if this is

I've got one video card,
you might have more than one, right?

427
00:22:07.074 --> 00:22:10.450
Maybe you've got one of those hardcore
gaming rigs with SLI and all that stuff.

428
00:22:10.450 --> 00:22:12.715
So you'll have video zero,
video one, video two.

429
00:22:12.715 --> 00:22:15.077
These are files that
reference your device, and

430
00:22:15.077 --> 00:22:19.020
some of them have some interesting stuff,
if you browse inside of them.

431
00:22:19.020 --> 00:22:20.540
Some are folders, some are not, right?

432
00:22:20.540 --> 00:22:23.770
The dark blue ones are folders, and
so you can browse into them and

433
00:22:23.770 --> 00:22:26.970
see interesting things,
the other ones though are just files.

434
00:22:26.970 --> 00:22:29.580
And you reference the file
to interact with the device.

435
00:22:29.580 --> 00:22:33.620
If I wanna send something to video
I send it to /dev/video0 and

436
00:22:33.620 --> 00:22:35.210
now it goes on screen.

437
00:22:35.210 --> 00:22:38.130
It's gotta be in the right format and
all that but that's how they work.

438
00:22:38.130 --> 00:22:40.170
So all of this stuff is pretty important.

439
00:22:43.620 --> 00:22:47.240
Along with slash dev another
important folder is ETC, right.

440
00:22:47.240 --> 00:22:50.690
ETC is short for
etc as we usually use it but

441
00:22:50.690 --> 00:22:55.020
it's not really just etc here's a bunch
of extra junk, it's really config files.

442
00:22:55.020 --> 00:22:56.170
The configuration files for

443
00:22:56.170 --> 00:22:59.510
the majority of the services and
your operating system are stored in there.

444
00:22:59.510 --> 00:23:03.410
So when you become like a system
administrator and you're installing

445
00:23:03.410 --> 00:23:07.980
the Apache web server or something,
the configuration for Apache is in there.

446
00:23:07.980 --> 00:23:10.500
But even as just a regular user if
you're configuring your systems so

447
00:23:10.500 --> 00:23:17.540
you can remote SSH into it, SSHD, the SSHD
daemon, it stores it's config inside ETC.

448
00:23:17.540 --> 00:23:21.603
So when you look inside a ETC
you'll see a ton of config files.

449
00:23:21.603 --> 00:23:24.422
And if you want to modify
the behavior of Linux or

450
00:23:24.422 --> 00:23:28.793
modify the behavior of a particular
service, this is the place to go, and

451
00:23:28.793 --> 00:23:30.923
you'll see a ton of things in here.

452
00:23:30.923 --> 00:23:32.736
Some of these are things that you'll have,

453
00:23:32.736 --> 00:23:35.240
just like I do, other things
are software that I installed.

454
00:23:35.240 --> 00:23:37.320
So, for example,
I installed the BitBabbler software,

455
00:23:37.320 --> 00:23:41.000
so I've got a folder for
that with the BitBabbler configuration.

456
00:23:41.000 --> 00:23:43.490
You may not have one of those,
the little random number generator.

457
00:23:43.490 --> 00:23:45.579
So, if you don't have one of those,
then you're not going to have that folder.

458
00:23:46.660 --> 00:23:48.205
Each application will create these and

459
00:23:48.205 --> 00:23:50.460
deposit them in store
configurations in there, right?

460
00:23:50.460 --> 00:23:54.187
So cups for example,
that's the common Unix print service,

461
00:23:54.187 --> 00:23:56.777
so that's where my printers get defined.

462
00:23:56.777 --> 00:24:01.281
Well Most Linux distros run cups, and
it stores its config right in there.

463
00:24:01.281 --> 00:24:05.430
So if I browse into the cups folder,
and take a look there.

464
00:24:05.430 --> 00:24:07.648
I can start to see my classes and
my printers.

465
00:24:07.648 --> 00:24:11.695
Printers.conf, that's where it's actually
storing which printers I'm connected to.

466
00:24:11.695 --> 00:24:15.530
And then in the PPD folder is where
it'll store any drivers that it's got.

467
00:24:15.530 --> 00:24:18.365
So I print to a LaserJet M506
here in the building,

468
00:24:18.365 --> 00:24:21.455
there's the PPD that defines
how to talk to that printer.

469
00:24:21.455 --> 00:24:25.096
So each service, each application,

470
00:24:25.096 --> 00:24:31.485
will store config files right in
here inside of /etc, all right.

471
00:24:31.485 --> 00:24:34.979
There's a couple others that I can
cover a little bit more quickly,

472
00:24:34.979 --> 00:24:37.074
because I know I'm running low on time.

473
00:24:37.074 --> 00:24:37.897
>> [LAUGH]
>> So let me show you

474
00:24:37.897 --> 00:24:38.525
the important ones here.

475
00:24:38.525 --> 00:24:39.028
>> It's great stuff.

476
00:24:39.028 --> 00:24:42.850
>> [LAUGH] I really thought
I could do this faster.

477
00:24:42.850 --> 00:24:44.420
Home, that's where your home directory is,
right?

478
00:24:44.420 --> 00:24:48.276
So every user has a home directory and
it gets dropped right inside of home.

479
00:24:48.276 --> 00:24:51.880
So my user comes dpezet,
there's a /home/dpezet.

480
00:24:51.880 --> 00:24:55.500
I'm the only one that uses the computer,
so nobody else has a folder here, just me.

481
00:24:55.500 --> 00:24:57.837
There's one exception,
and that's the root user.

482
00:24:57.837 --> 00:25:00.950
The root user's folder is put
somewhere else to keep it safe.

483
00:25:00.950 --> 00:25:03.124
It's put, oddly enough,
in the root of the drive.

484
00:25:03.124 --> 00:25:06.994
So there's actually a separate
root folder, cd /root.

485
00:25:06.994 --> 00:25:09.117
And see how I'm getting
blocked right here?

486
00:25:09.117 --> 00:25:12.622
I'm not an administrator,
I can't even get to that folder, but

487
00:25:12.622 --> 00:25:14.480
it does exist right there.

488
00:25:14.480 --> 00:25:21.760
And if I switch to the root user,
I can change right into that folder.

489
00:25:21.760 --> 00:25:25.399
And there we are, and
it's just my home folder, for

490
00:25:25.399 --> 00:25:27.977
the root user if that's who you are.

491
00:25:27.977 --> 00:25:29.076
[COUGH] What else do we have?

492
00:25:29.076 --> 00:25:33.240
That was home, there's lib and
lib64, those are libraries.

493
00:25:34.240 --> 00:25:35.084
When you run an application, right?

494
00:25:35.084 --> 00:25:36.872
When you run GUI, for example, and

495
00:25:36.872 --> 00:25:39.610
maybe you're the developer
that writing this GUI.

496
00:25:39.610 --> 00:25:41.683
And you need to put
a button on your screen,

497
00:25:41.683 --> 00:25:44.518
you're not the first person
to think of a button, right?

498
00:25:44.518 --> 00:25:46.640
Tons of applications already have buttons.

499
00:25:46.640 --> 00:25:47.738
So why reinvent the wheel?

500
00:25:47.738 --> 00:25:51.755
You don't have to, there are plenty of
libraries out there that already include

501
00:25:51.755 --> 00:25:54.010
the majority of functions
that people need.

502
00:25:54.010 --> 00:25:57.060
So if you need a button on the screen, you
can go get a library that does buttons.

503
00:25:57.060 --> 00:26:01.556
If you need to put video up on a monitor
there's libraries out there that already

504
00:26:01.556 --> 00:26:02.910
put video on a monitor.

505
00:26:02.910 --> 00:26:06.553
So don't write it yourself, just use
the library and they go here, right?

506
00:26:06.553 --> 00:26:12.180
/lib is for 32 bit libraries and
lib64 is for 64 bit libraries.

507
00:26:12.180 --> 00:26:16.034
That'll change in the future,
eventually lib64 will become lib.

508
00:26:16.034 --> 00:26:20.590
But for right now the 32 bit is
still the default, so they're there.

509
00:26:20.590 --> 00:26:22.787
64 bit applications know
to look to the /lib64.

510
00:26:22.787 --> 00:26:29.100
Let's see, lost and found,
that's where damaged files go.

511
00:26:29.100 --> 00:26:31.496
If there's ever a file that
somehow gets a damaged pointer and

512
00:26:31.496 --> 00:26:32.704
a file system repair fixes it.

513
00:26:32.704 --> 00:26:37.180
It'll end up there, hopefully that's
empty for you, but files do end up there.

514
00:26:37.180 --> 00:26:39.190
Stuff happens,
especially with temporary files.

515
00:26:39.190 --> 00:26:41.630
Media and mount,
I already talked about opt.

516
00:26:41.630 --> 00:26:44.493
I talked about proc,
proc is another new one.

517
00:26:44.493 --> 00:26:46.830
Proc is short for processes.

518
00:26:46.830 --> 00:26:49.850
When you run a program,
I said earlier that everything,

519
00:26:49.850 --> 00:26:51.980
almost everything is
represented as a file.

520
00:26:51.980 --> 00:26:54.486
Even your programs running
are represented as your files, and

521
00:26:54.486 --> 00:26:55.961
they are right there inside of proc.

522
00:26:55.961 --> 00:26:59.936
And so here's all these folders with
numbers that don't mean a whole lot to

523
00:26:59.936 --> 00:27:00.640
me, right?

524
00:27:00.640 --> 00:27:03.370
Well it's not that they
don't mean anything,

525
00:27:03.370 --> 00:27:08.092
it's just that when I look at them here,
they don't necessarily show anything.

526
00:27:08.092 --> 00:27:09.742
For example,
let me open another terminal here.

527
00:27:09.742 --> 00:27:10.436
I'm gonna run a program.

528
00:27:10.436 --> 00:27:11.731
I'm gonna run Midnight Commander, right?

529
00:27:11.731 --> 00:27:12.621
So I just ran MC.

530
00:27:12.621 --> 00:27:19.700
If I go back to this screen, I can run
ps aux, ps shows me all of my processes.

531
00:27:19.700 --> 00:27:24.160
And I can look for that midnight
commander process, so there it is.

532
00:27:24.160 --> 00:27:26.615
And its process ID 28593, right?

533
00:27:26.615 --> 00:27:32.610
And inside of proc,
there'll be a folder that is 28593.

534
00:27:32.610 --> 00:27:35.005
There it is, right there, right?

535
00:27:35.005 --> 00:27:38.930
And so that running process
is represented right here.

536
00:27:38.930 --> 00:27:43.498
And if I try and browse into it,
oops, I have to type it right first.

537
00:27:43.498 --> 00:27:47.727
Once I get, wow,
my typing skills are sub par.

538
00:27:47.727 --> 00:27:49.670
There we go, 28593 there.

539
00:27:49.670 --> 00:27:50.509
When I get into it,

540
00:27:50.509 --> 00:27:53.661
I can find all sorts of interesting
things about that process, right?

541
00:27:53.661 --> 00:27:56.432
I can pull up information on
how much memory it's using,

542
00:27:56.432 --> 00:27:59.330
how much CPU it's utilizing,
what files it is accessing.

543
00:27:59.330 --> 00:28:02.804
It is all stored right in here, all this
information about that running process.

544
00:28:02.804 --> 00:28:05.180
It's all represented
here in the file system.

545
00:28:05.180 --> 00:28:06.560
This is all virtual stuff,

546
00:28:06.560 --> 00:28:10.105
the moment I close that program
this folder will dissappear, right?

547
00:28:10.105 --> 00:28:17.310
Right now if I do a ls 28593, okay?

548
00:28:17.310 --> 00:28:19.575
I see it, and if I go back here.

549
00:28:19.575 --> 00:28:26.416
And I get out of Midnight Commander,

550
00:28:26.416 --> 00:28:32.160
which is, oop, not that one.

551
00:28:32.160 --> 00:28:33.973
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right,

552
00:28:33.973 --> 00:28:38.130
well let me, Just kill that out.

553
00:28:41.336 --> 00:28:45.270
Come on, It's not gonna let me kill it.

554
00:28:45.270 --> 00:28:48.544
But if I exit out of that program,
there we go.

555
00:28:48.544 --> 00:28:52.242
Now when I come back over here, if I look
for it, the directory's gone, right?

556
00:28:52.242 --> 00:28:53.477
It's no longer running, so

557
00:28:53.477 --> 00:28:56.159
proc represents the running
programs that are on our system.

558
00:28:57.826 --> 00:29:00.420
All right, shouldn't have been so
hard to get out of that.

559
00:29:00.420 --> 00:29:02.229
>> [LAUGH]
>> F10 is what exits for some reason,

560
00:29:02.229 --> 00:29:04.012
I couldn't do F10 on my keyboard.

561
00:29:04.012 --> 00:29:06.437
All right, what else do we have?

562
00:29:06.437 --> 00:29:07.928
That was proc, we've got roots.

563
00:29:07.928 --> 00:29:09.211
We already talked about root-
>> We talked about root-

564
00:29:09.211 --> 00:29:09.869
>> That's what gets us home.

565
00:29:09.869 --> 00:29:10.585
>> Yep.
>> Run,

566
00:29:10.585 --> 00:29:14.639
I talked about a little bit inside of
/var/run, but here, it's in the root.

567
00:29:14.639 --> 00:29:19.010
Ubuntu likes to do this with media
that it'll end up in the run folder.

568
00:29:19.010 --> 00:29:22.653
This is usually temporary stuff for
users and so you'll see like a mount or

569
00:29:22.653 --> 00:29:25.435
other programs might store
data there inside of /run.

570
00:29:25.435 --> 00:29:31.205
That's not common across Linux distros, so
on Red Hat, you won't see that, it's not.

571
00:29:31.205 --> 00:29:32.087
Not a normal thing.

572
00:29:32.087 --> 00:29:34.003
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

573
00:29:34.003 --> 00:29:34.777
>> Ubuntu does some weird stuff.

574
00:29:34.777 --> 00:29:39.195
As Ben and I talked about snap,
we don't have to worry about that's for

575
00:29:39.195 --> 00:29:40.908
the snap packet managers.

576
00:29:40.908 --> 00:29:43.636
Srv for services that really
doesn't get used anymore.

577
00:29:43.636 --> 00:29:46.720
But it's still here, let's see if
I actually have anything in it.

578
00:29:46.720 --> 00:29:47.633
Yeah, it's empty for me.

579
00:29:47.633 --> 00:29:49.810
It used to be the services went there.

580
00:29:49.810 --> 00:29:53.018
Most of them store their information
in /var now, so it's just there for

581
00:29:53.018 --> 00:29:54.271
backwards compatibility.

582
00:29:54.271 --> 00:29:59.770
/usr, we already talked about, and /var,
I talked about but didn't really go into.

583
00:29:59.770 --> 00:30:03.379
But that's where a lot of our services
will store their actual configurations.

584
00:30:03.379 --> 00:30:07.680
And so when you come in here you
will find /var/opt or mail for

585
00:30:07.680 --> 00:30:11.460
a mail server, spool,
for your printer spool.

586
00:30:11.460 --> 00:30:14.627
If you print a job, it saves it to the
hard drive, sends it to the printer and

587
00:30:14.627 --> 00:30:17.061
it doesn't delete it until
the printer says it's done.

588
00:30:17.061 --> 00:30:19.513
And that way if the job
fails you can retransmitted,

589
00:30:19.513 --> 00:30:22.160
well it's waiting right here in /var/pool,
right?

590
00:30:22.160 --> 00:30:25.063
That's what that various folder is for,
so.

591
00:30:25.063 --> 00:30:28.202
And James in the chatroom
mentioned /var/log.

592
00:30:28.202 --> 00:30:30.600
That's a really great one,
if you're troubleshooting.

593
00:30:30.600 --> 00:30:34.140
All your log files end up
right there in /var/log.

594
00:30:34.140 --> 00:30:37.356
So if you need to dig into your
sys log and find information about

595
00:30:37.356 --> 00:30:40.155
why a crash happened,
you can jump in here and find it.

596
00:30:40.155 --> 00:30:42.994
We will see that in some later episodes,
but

597
00:30:42.994 --> 00:30:46.080
that is definitely
another important folder.

598
00:30:46.080 --> 00:30:48.991
>> All right, Don anything else we need
to take a peak at while it comes to

599
00:30:48.991 --> 00:30:50.308
the systems hierarchy Linux?

600
00:30:50.308 --> 00:30:54.135
>> I think that's about it, just keeping
in mind, these names all matter, right?

601
00:30:54.135 --> 00:30:54.709
Well somebody maid them-
>> [LAUGH]

602
00:30:54.709 --> 00:30:55.621
>> At some point, but

603
00:30:55.621 --> 00:30:59.227
now is a part of what is called FHS,
the file systems hierarchy standards.

604
00:30:59.227 --> 00:31:03.952
And most Linux distributions,
almost all of the BSDs and

605
00:31:03.952 --> 00:31:09.310
even OS X, Mac OS follows this
standard for the file system.

606
00:31:09.310 --> 00:31:11.926
So once you learn it, it's easy to
move from system to system, and

607
00:31:11.926 --> 00:31:13.585
know basically where to look for things.

608
00:31:13.585 --> 00:31:16.460
Now some of them like to change it a bit.

609
00:31:16.460 --> 00:31:19.642
Ubuntu is bad about that,
which is what I'm running.

610
00:31:19.642 --> 00:31:24.580
But there are other vendors that stick to
it, like Slackware, that will not deviate.

611
00:31:24.580 --> 00:31:27.946
They follow the standard to the letter,
and then there's other ones like Red Hat

612
00:31:27.946 --> 00:31:30.338
that are really influential
in changing the standards.

613
00:31:30.338 --> 00:31:33.730
So they everyone wanna change
something they modify the standards.

614
00:31:33.730 --> 00:31:34.296
So, [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

615
00:31:34.296 --> 00:31:35.635
>> There's that option too, but

616
00:31:35.635 --> 00:31:37.499
once you learn the file system hierarchy.

617
00:31:37.499 --> 00:31:41.070
It pretty much ports across every system,
it's a good thing to learn.

618
00:31:41.070 --> 00:31:44.097
>> All right, fantastic information Don,
wait for me call that very exciting.

619
00:31:44.097 --> 00:31:48.046
Teaching us what all those folders are in
our Linux file system hierarchy, so

620
00:31:48.046 --> 00:31:49.530
we appreciate that.

621
00:31:49.530 --> 00:31:51.174
Hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

622
00:31:51.174 --> 00:31:52.381
Signing off for ITPro.TV.

623
00:31:52.381 --> 00:31:53.504
I've been your host, Mike Roderick.

624
00:31:53.504 --> 00:31:54.495
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

625
00:31:54.495 --> 00:31:55.458
>> And we'll see you next time.

626
00:31:55.458 --> 00:32:03.302
[MUSIC]

627
00:32:03.302 --> 00:32:05.628
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

00:11:27.534 --> 00:11:29.219
