470
00:24:23.916 --> 00:24:25.750
the question mark is available as well.

471
00:24:27.140 --> 00:24:28.790
Let's see, what else do we have?

472
00:24:28.790 --> 00:24:31.784
Brackets, square brackets, you can
have some fun with this one, right?

473
00:24:31.784 --> 00:24:37.586
For example, I might wanna say ls dir, and
maybe I just want to get directory 1 and

474
00:24:37.586 --> 00:24:41.134
directory 2, and
not directory 3, all right?

475
00:24:41.134 --> 00:24:47.090
If you do a square bracket like that
[ ] you can put ranges in between.

476
00:24:47.090 --> 00:24:51.911
I could say something like [a-z],

477
00:24:51.911 --> 00:24:56.900
or [A-Z], or [0-9], right?

478
00:24:56.900 --> 00:25:00.436
That would find any letter, upper case or
lower case, and any number, 0-9,

479
00:25:00.436 --> 00:25:01.950
not special characters, right?

480
00:25:01.950 --> 00:25:06.403
But if I just wanted to find 1 and 2,
I might come in here and say ls dir and

481
00:25:06.403 --> 00:25:10.857
then in brackets, [1,2] or really,
I could say 1 through 2, but

482
00:25:10.857 --> 00:25:12.877
that's, either way-
>> [LAUGH]

483
00:25:12.877 --> 00:25:14.630
>> Same goal here, right?

484
00:25:14.630 --> 00:25:17.040
And when I run that,
see what it found, directory 1 and

485
00:25:17.040 --> 00:25:19.030
2, and it didn't find directory 3?

486
00:25:19.030 --> 00:25:22.010
Ranges like that can be handy sometimes
when you're working with files,

487
00:25:22.010 --> 00:25:24.000
when you're trying to return
a list that's very specific.

488
00:25:25.070 --> 00:25:28.120
This lets you filter that down and
minimize it.

489
00:25:28.120 --> 00:25:31.693
Just remember that letters are treated
differently if they're uppercase, and

490
00:25:31.693 --> 00:25:33.857
they're lowercase, and special characters.

491
00:25:33.857 --> 00:25:37.763
So when you do a bracket like this,
they're square brackets, first off,

492
00:25:37.763 --> 00:25:40.243
don't leave a space after
your search string,

493
00:25:40.243 --> 00:25:43.290
cuz that would mean there would
be a space in the file name.

494
00:25:43.290 --> 00:25:47.573
And then you specify the ranges as
either a single entry and a comma, or

495
00:25:47.573 --> 00:25:51.650
a range with a hyphen in between it and
then commas between breaks.

496
00:25:51.650 --> 00:25:58.294
So I might say [a-c], and then [e-z].

497
00:25:58.294 --> 00:26:01.390
So that would be any file
that started with dir, and

498
00:26:01.390 --> 00:26:05.710
then had any letter after it except for
the letter d, skip the letter d.

499
00:26:05.710 --> 00:26:09.410
And so now it's going to look for
that range, and you can do many ranges.

500
00:26:09.410 --> 00:26:10.280
There is a limit.

501
00:26:10.280 --> 00:26:11.720
I think it's something like nine ranges.

502
00:26:11.720 --> 00:26:12.883
But after that it gets a really angry.

503
00:26:12.883 --> 00:26:15.740
[LAUGH] But
you can do usually more than enough.

504
00:26:15.740 --> 00:26:18.300
And typically it's numbers
that we are doing with this.

505
00:26:18.300 --> 00:26:20.122
I might be looking for a script, though.

506
00:26:20.122 --> 00:26:24.920
And saying, well, I can't remember,
I wanna find DOM script.

507
00:26:26.060 --> 00:26:31.042
And I can't remember if it was
a shell script like sh, or

508
00:26:31.042 --> 00:26:36.034
if it was Python, or
if it was something of that nature.

509
00:26:36.034 --> 00:26:40.210
And so you can come in, and
you can designate those values.

510
00:26:40.210 --> 00:26:47.540
So I might look for, if it's got sh,
or if it's got py, or whatever, and

511
00:26:47.540 --> 00:26:51.150
so you can start to put entries in like
that, and now you're looking for those.

512
00:26:51.150 --> 00:26:53.820
For me, it's usually faster just to
look for each one individually, or

513
00:26:53.820 --> 00:26:55.985
just do a stinking wild card here.

514
00:26:55.985 --> 00:26:58.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> And say, show me all of them.

515
00:26:58.040 --> 00:27:00.080
So there are different
ways you can use ranges.

516
00:27:00.080 --> 00:27:03.150
We'll cover ranges more when
we get into the grep command.

517
00:27:03.150 --> 00:27:05.660
A grep is an amazing regular
expression searcher and

518
00:27:05.660 --> 00:27:07.720
regular expressions are super powerful.

519
00:27:07.720 --> 00:27:11.470
This is actually a very light version
of a regular expression right here.

520
00:27:11.470 --> 00:27:13.100
So we're gonna see those
later cause they're very,

521
00:27:13.100 --> 00:27:16.380
very powerful tools that we use
a lot in system administration.

522
00:27:16.380 --> 00:27:20.580
But as far as finding files, you can use
that just to simply define ranges and

523
00:27:20.580 --> 00:27:22.070
locate stuff quickly.

524
00:27:22.070 --> 00:27:23.210
>> All right, great stuff there, Don.

525
00:27:23.210 --> 00:27:25.820
We've learned about the file system
hierarchy in previous episodes.

526
00:27:25.820 --> 00:27:28.880
In this episode, we learned how to
navigate around that hierarchy,

527
00:27:28.880 --> 00:27:30.950
work through those different folders,

528
00:27:30.950 --> 00:27:34.310
as well as being able to
locate things when we need to.

529
00:27:34.310 --> 00:27:37.100
So we've got more coming your way, but
unfortunately we're out of time for

530
00:27:37.100 --> 00:27:38.340
this particular episode.

531
00:27:38.340 --> 00:27:41.550
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

532
00:27:41.550 --> 00:27:42.340
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

533
00:27:42.340 --> 00:27:44.410
>> And we'll see you next time.

534
00:27:44.410 --> 00:27:50.128
[MUSIC]

535
00:27:50.128 --> 00:27:53.831
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss where to send re-directed output, creating a file, how to add data on an existing file, expansion, and creating a numerical range-useful for working with multiple files.
episodes.title: Filesystem Commands Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.260
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.260 --> 00:00:06.011
I'm your host Don- [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.011 --> 00:00:08.480
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.480 --> 00:00:12.170
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.170 --> 00:00:13.640
>> Hello again, and thank you for

6
00:00:13.640 --> 00:00:17.430
choosing ITPRO.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:17.430 --> 00:00:21.280
I'm you host, Zach Memos as we continue
on with becoming a Linux Power user.

8
00:00:21.280 --> 00:00:26.780
This is Part 2 Of file system commands,
and I'm not the brain behind this.

9
00:00:26.780 --> 00:00:29.490
The man bringing us all
the information is Don Pezet.

10
00:00:29.490 --> 00:00:30.010
Right over here.

11
00:00:30.010 --> 00:00:31.530
Don, good to see you, sir.

12
00:00:31.530 --> 00:00:32.873
>> Hey, thanks for
having me back in the studio.

13
00:00:32.873 --> 00:00:36.100
And you're ready to dive right back
into becoming a Linux power user.

14
00:00:36.100 --> 00:00:39.340
In this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at a few different things.

15
00:00:39.340 --> 00:00:41.904
We're gonna take a look at
command output redirection.

16
00:00:41.904 --> 00:00:45.407
And some file expansion which is kind of
a fun little thing we'll take a look at at

17
00:00:45.407 --> 00:00:46.820
the end of the episode.

18
00:00:46.820 --> 00:00:49.453
But command redirection is
the main one that I wanna hit.

19
00:00:49.453 --> 00:00:52.476
Cuz it's an important thing
that we'll utilize quite a bit.

20
00:00:52.476 --> 00:00:54.400
But we kinda already saw
some command redirection.

21
00:00:54.400 --> 00:00:55.930
We're gonna see a little more here.

22
00:00:55.930 --> 00:00:59.590
And it ties in to working with the files
system because we need output to a file.

23
00:00:59.590 --> 00:01:01.618
So we're gonna get a chance to
see how all of that works and

24
00:01:01.618 --> 00:01:03.104
go through it right here in this episode.

25
00:01:03.104 --> 00:01:05.774
>> Don,
where would I want to redirect the output?

26
00:01:05.774 --> 00:01:08.224
Where are we sending it?

27
00:01:08.224 --> 00:01:10.338
>> Let's set the ground rules here right.

28
00:01:10.338 --> 00:01:14.011
Which is when I run a command,
it's normally gonna output to the screen.

29
00:01:14.011 --> 00:01:15.862
And we normally want that so
we can see it.

30
00:01:15.862 --> 00:01:19.550
But we don't always want to
output to the screen, right?

31
00:01:19.550 --> 00:01:20.945
Sometimes we wanna output to a file.

32
00:01:20.945 --> 00:01:25.805
And a great example of that would be
if I'm about to run a command that

33
00:01:25.805 --> 00:01:29.058
has a lot of output,
tons and tons of output.

34
00:01:29.058 --> 00:01:31.032
I might wanna dump that to a file.

35
00:01:31.032 --> 00:01:33.643
The reason I would dump it to a file
is that I can come back later on, and

36
00:01:33.643 --> 00:01:35.910
I can edit it, and
I can look at it, and I can read it.

37
00:01:35.910 --> 00:01:38.764
Technically all logging
systems are doing this, right.

38
00:01:38.764 --> 00:01:41.390
There's error messages that
pop up on your system.

39
00:01:41.390 --> 00:01:43.000
Well if you have a headless server,

40
00:01:43.000 --> 00:01:45.477
you've got a server that's
on a rack in a server room.

41
00:01:45.477 --> 00:01:48.410
It starts generating errors,
you're not gonna see that.

42
00:01:48.410 --> 00:01:49.870
You're not standing in
front of that servers,

43
00:01:49.870 --> 00:01:51.700
especially if there's a thousand servers.

44
00:01:51.700 --> 00:01:54.787
So instead,
they upload those messages to a file.

45
00:01:54.787 --> 00:01:56.130
And that where you'd just come back and

46
00:01:56.130 --> 00:01:57.806
then look at the file
whenever you've got time.

47
00:01:57.806 --> 00:02:00.731
So, anytime you're dealing with
a large amount of screen output,

48
00:02:00.731 --> 00:02:01.830
you want to go to a file.

49
00:02:01.830 --> 00:02:03.200
Or anytime you want a time delay,

50
00:02:03.200 --> 00:02:06.470
where you can look at the data later,
you'll want to output to a file.

51
00:02:06.470 --> 00:02:11.860
And fortunately, any command output can be
redirected and output right into a file.

52
00:02:11.860 --> 00:02:12.848
>> Let's see it.

53
00:02:12.848 --> 00:02:13.358
>> All right.
>> [LAUGH]

54
00:02:13.358 --> 00:02:15.944
>> It's actually really easy to do.

55
00:02:15.944 --> 00:02:17.175
In an earlier episode,

56
00:02:17.175 --> 00:02:20.806
we took a look at pipelining commands.
Where you take the output for

57
00:02:20.806 --> 00:02:24.068
one command, and
you feed it as input to another command.

58
00:02:24.068 --> 00:02:24.848
So for example,

59
00:02:24.848 --> 00:02:29.490
what I did, I'll show you here on my
laptop is I took the LS command, right?

60
00:02:29.490 --> 00:02:32.210
So let me just go into the binary
folder here and I'll do an LS.

61
00:02:32.210 --> 00:02:34.056
So here's a list of all the files.

62
00:02:34.056 --> 00:02:37.638
And I might want to pipe
that into another command,

63
00:02:37.638 --> 00:02:41.150
like the sort command to
sort it alphabetically.

64
00:02:41.150 --> 00:02:43.060
Well, this is already
sorted alphabetically,

65
00:02:43.060 --> 00:02:45.170
so maybe I'll sort it in reverse.

66
00:02:45.170 --> 00:02:46.670
So instead of a to z, we'll go z to a.

67
00:02:46.670 --> 00:02:47.670
There we go.

68
00:02:47.670 --> 00:02:52.020
I took the output of one command and I
sent it as the input for another command.

69
00:02:52.020 --> 00:02:54.390
Well, very similar to that,

70
00:02:54.390 --> 00:02:59.640
instead of using the pipe symbol,
I can use the greater than symbol.

71
00:02:59.640 --> 00:03:03.640
And what the greater than symbol
does is it says, take the output.

72
00:03:03.640 --> 00:03:08.225
And instead of sending it to my
screen send it somewhere else.

73
00:03:08.225 --> 00:03:11.220
And that somewhere else is
normally going to be a file.

74
00:03:11.220 --> 00:03:14.340
Now, what I'm gonna do here is just
kinda point it to my home directory and

75
00:03:14.340 --> 00:03:19.740
I'll do like a file called- whoops,
output.txt.

76
00:03:19.740 --> 00:03:23.650
So now when I ran that LS command,
what came out of my screen?

77
00:03:23.650 --> 00:03:26.110
Nothing, it didn't output to my screen.

78
00:03:26.110 --> 00:03:29.480
Instead, it output to that
file that I specified.

79
00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:34.760
And now at my leisure, whenever I want,
I can go and take a look at that file.

80
00:03:34.760 --> 00:03:37.110
I'll use the less command,
but you could use cat,

81
00:03:37.110 --> 00:03:41.540
or more, or any of the various
commands to open up a file.

82
00:03:41.540 --> 00:03:44.770
And I'll take a look at it,
and there's that output.

83
00:03:44.770 --> 00:03:47.790
Instead of going to screen,
it went right here to this file.

84
00:03:47.790 --> 00:03:48.531
>> That's great.

85
00:03:48.531 --> 00:03:50.250
Now does that get everything?

86
00:03:50.250 --> 00:03:53.080
Does that get all the output
when you send out?

87
00:03:53.080 --> 00:03:55.090
>> In normal circumstances, yes.

88
00:03:55.090 --> 00:03:56.813
So normally yeah this
would get everything.

89
00:03:56.813 --> 00:03:59.178
But there are some situations
where it doesn't and

90
00:03:59.178 --> 00:04:01.690
the most common example
that would be errors.

91
00:04:01.690 --> 00:04:04.830
When you run a command,
sometimes you get an error, okay.

92
00:04:04.830 --> 00:04:07.680
Well what this is capturing is
what's called standard out.

93
00:04:07.680 --> 00:04:10.484
There's actually a couple of different
outputs that you get when you

94
00:04:10.484 --> 00:04:11.122
run a command.

95
00:04:11.122 --> 00:04:15.877
But the main reasons that we care
about are the standard output or

96
00:04:15.877 --> 00:04:18.882
stdout, and standard error or stderr.

97
00:04:18.882 --> 00:04:21.670
All right so standard out and
standard error.

98
00:04:21.670 --> 00:04:25.120
When I do a redirect like what we
see here with a greater than symbol,

99
00:04:25.120 --> 00:04:29.580
that is just capturing standard out,
stdout.

100
00:04:29.580 --> 00:04:33.052
So if you run that,
it's gonna capture it and there you go.

101
00:04:33.052 --> 00:04:38.150
It's not going to capture std err,
E-R-R, right?

102
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:40.143
Errors will still go to my screen.

103
00:04:40.143 --> 00:04:43.629
So now, if I run it like this it's
capturing all the good output and

104
00:04:43.629 --> 00:04:44.760
leaving out the bad.

105
00:04:44.760 --> 00:04:48.290
Now, that can be a problem because
what if I'm running a script, and

106
00:04:48.290 --> 00:04:50.210
the script is a 100 steps?

107
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:51.870
And two of the steps fail.

108
00:04:51.870 --> 00:04:55.090
Well, I'll capture the output for
the 98 steps that succeeded.

109
00:04:55.090 --> 00:04:57.201
And I"ll be missing the output for
the two that failed.

110
00:04:57.201 --> 00:04:58.974
So I'm looking at this file down the road.

111
00:04:58.974 --> 00:05:00.260
I'm gonna look at it and say,

112
00:05:00.260 --> 00:05:03.080
I know two commands failed
because I'm two lines shorts.

113
00:05:03.080 --> 00:05:04.068
Which ones?

114
00:05:04.068 --> 00:05:06.480
Now I've got to go through all 98 lines.

115
00:05:06.480 --> 00:05:07.930
It's a nightmare.

116
00:05:07.930 --> 00:05:11.120
So we wanna capture standard
error as well, right.

117
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:12.335
Let me just give you an example here.

118
00:05:12.335 --> 00:05:15.281
If I try and run something like rngd -v,

119
00:05:15.281 --> 00:05:20.405
that's gonna get the version of my
random number generator, right.

120
00:05:20.405 --> 00:05:22.210
And tell me what sources that I'm using.

121
00:05:22.210 --> 00:05:27.813
Well when I run it, see how I got
this unable to open file/dev/tpm0.

122
00:05:27.813 --> 00:05:31.499
And I got unable to adjust the right
wake up threshold permission denied.

123
00:05:31.499 --> 00:05:35.020
Well, I didn't run it as an administrator,
so it generated some errors, right?

124
00:05:35.020 --> 00:05:35.690
The command ran,

125
00:05:35.690 --> 00:05:40.700
I can actually see here's my entropy
source is great but I did get errors.

126
00:05:40.700 --> 00:05:44.498
If I wanna output errors I
could take that command.

127
00:05:44.498 --> 00:05:47.750
And I could use that greater
than symbol like before.

128
00:05:47.750 --> 00:05:52.330
And I've could send that somewhere
to like output.txt, right.

129
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:54.550
But when I run that it's
not gonna get the errors.

130
00:05:54.550 --> 00:05:57.915
But if I change this greater than
symbol and stick a 2 before it.

131
00:05:57.915 --> 00:06:01.390
Now it's gonna get the errors, okay?

132
00:06:01.390 --> 00:06:05.792
Now when I run that,
what I'm doing is saying two greater than.

133
00:06:05.792 --> 00:06:08.830
And two greater than means get
the second set of information.

134
00:06:08.830 --> 00:06:11.510
The first set of information
is standard out, right?

135
00:06:11.510 --> 00:06:12.840
So if I did one greater than,

136
00:06:12.840 --> 00:06:14.880
that's the same thing as doing
a regular greater than, right?

137
00:06:14.880 --> 00:06:16.000
That's the standard out.

138
00:06:16.000 --> 00:06:18.290
This is gonna get standard error.

139
00:06:18.290 --> 00:06:21.720
Now just like before,
this is only getting the errors.

140
00:06:21.720 --> 00:06:24.900
The other one only got the good stuff,
the successes.

141
00:06:24.900 --> 00:06:28.550
This is only gonna get the errors,
and dump those in output.txt.

142
00:06:28.550 --> 00:06:30.656
So look what came up on my screen.

143
00:06:30.656 --> 00:06:34.320
The success, this is the good stuff,
came up on the screen.

144
00:06:34.320 --> 00:06:38.020
And just the error went into output.txt.

145
00:06:38.020 --> 00:06:41.390
And so if I take a look at that file.

146
00:06:41.390 --> 00:06:43.730
So I'm gonna pull that up on the screen.

147
00:06:43.730 --> 00:06:46.359
There we go I can see the two
errors are right there.

148
00:06:46.359 --> 00:06:49.804
All right now if you want to give them
both which would probably be a little more

149
00:06:49.804 --> 00:06:50.730
realistic.

150
00:06:50.730 --> 00:06:52.945
Then instead of a one or a two.

151
00:06:52.945 --> 00:06:56.351
What you'll do is you'll replace
that with an ampersand and

152
00:06:56.351 --> 00:06:58.670
when you do an ampersand like that.

153
00:06:58.670 --> 00:07:01.917
It's gonna get the successes and
the failures, right.

154
00:07:01.917 --> 00:07:05.610
So standard out and standard error,
and put them both in there.

155
00:07:05.610 --> 00:07:08.825
So when you're running a command,
or a script, or a series of events.

156
00:07:08.825 --> 00:07:11.769
And you wanna output that to
a file to be able to review,

157
00:07:11.769 --> 00:07:14.149
then this is usually what we're gonna use.

158
00:07:14.149 --> 00:07:17.060
The ampersand followed by
a greater than symbol.

159
00:07:17.060 --> 00:07:18.080
And that'll dump out.

160
00:07:18.080 --> 00:07:20.250
And see how nothing came up on my screen?

161
00:07:20.250 --> 00:07:22.790
It all went right into there.

162
00:07:22.790 --> 00:07:26.000
Now, I'm not the biggest fan of this.

388
00:19:03.730 --> 00:19:08.620
And I wanna create five memos for
each of them, right?

389
00:19:08.620 --> 00:19:13.027
So, I might wanna create a series of
files that are named after them and

390
00:19:13.027 --> 00:19:16.178
that are tied to each of
these different numbers.

391
00:19:16.178 --> 00:19:21.996
And so I can come through and
I can say something like touch and

392
00:19:21.996 --> 00:19:27.950
then in parenthesis we can do tom,
dick, harry, all right.

393
00:19:27.950 --> 00:19:33.950
So there's the three users, and then maybe
I wanna have a hyphen followed by memo,

394
00:19:33.950 --> 00:19:35.580
and in parenthesis, 1,2,3,4,5, okay.

395
00:19:38.300 --> 00:19:41.150
So there, I'm kind of specifying
that I wanna create these files.

396
00:19:41.150 --> 00:19:44.760
Now, there's two different expansions that
are gonna happen at the same time here.

397
00:19:44.760 --> 00:19:48.560
It's gonna expand the names first, and
it's gonna expend the memos second,

398
00:19:48.560 --> 00:19:49.900
or the numbers second.

399
00:19:49.900 --> 00:19:53.220
And so it's actually gonna end up
running 15 different commands.

400
00:19:53.220 --> 00:19:57.470
It'll run touch, tom, dash memo1,
touch, tom, dash memo2, touch, tom,

401
00:19:57.470 --> 00:20:00.740
dash memo3 and so on, and

402
00:20:00.740 --> 00:20:04.880
then it'll move to the next one, touch,
dick, dash memo1 and so on, right.

403
00:20:04.880 --> 00:20:08.248
And each one is gonna get created
out here from a second command.

404
00:20:08.248 --> 00:20:12.350
And so when I run that and take a look,
there they all are, right?

405
00:20:12.350 --> 00:20:13.810
So oops, let me just do a, there.

406
00:20:15.610 --> 00:20:18.370
So, we can see it created each one,
I didn't have to go through and

407
00:20:18.370 --> 00:20:20.525
do it myself, one by one.

408
00:20:20.525 --> 00:20:21.202
>> Very nice.
>> And in fact,

409
00:20:21.202 --> 00:20:24.460
I kinda did this the hard way,
because I typed all the values in.

410
00:20:24.460 --> 00:20:29.750
Remember what I said, what if I need
to create 100 of these files, right.

411
00:20:29.750 --> 00:20:31.320
>> So Don, that's very helpful.

412
00:20:31.320 --> 00:20:33.900
I mean you've had multiple
memos that you've had to do.

413
00:20:33.900 --> 00:20:35.690
But, what if you had a range,

414
00:20:35.690 --> 00:20:40.490
like you wanted to do 100 memos,
is there an easier way to get around that?

415
00:20:40.490 --> 00:20:43.780
>> I kind of set it up that way saying
if I had to create 100 this is easy.

416
00:20:43.780 --> 00:20:49.280
But if you look at the command I ran,
I had to do memo(1, 2, 3, 4, 5).

417
00:20:49.280 --> 00:20:52.190
If I was gonna create 100, I would have
to do commas all the way out to 100.

418
00:20:52.190 --> 00:20:52.860
>> Lots of commas.

419
00:20:52.860 --> 00:20:54.510
>> Yeah, that's not really so easy, is it?

420
00:20:54.510 --> 00:20:58.280
Right, but we can do ranges here and
that makes life a lot easier for us.

421
00:20:58.280 --> 00:21:00.630
Let me just clean up my directory here.

422
00:21:03.025 --> 00:21:05.905
I'll just delete all that,
and there we go.

423
00:21:05.905 --> 00:21:11.643
And so let's say that I wanted
to create memo 1 through 100.

424
00:21:11.643 --> 00:21:13.291
I wanna create a vast one, or

425
00:21:13.291 --> 00:21:16.741
we'll just do one through nine
to save screens space here.

426
00:21:16.741 --> 00:21:18.549
>> Okay
>> So, I'll do a touch memo,

427
00:21:18.549 --> 00:21:22.248
I'll bring up the squiggly bracket or,
Demie is in the chat room and so

428
00:21:22.248 --> 00:21:26.342
let me here, it's the curly bracket,
so I'll bring up the curly brackets.

429
00:21:26.342 --> 00:21:26.928
>> Curly braces.

430
00:21:26.928 --> 00:21:33.926
>> And [LAUGH] 1, followed by
double dots and the 9, not comma.

431
00:21:33.926 --> 00:21:38.116
So right, by doing, period, period, dot,
dot, or whatever you wanna call them,

432
00:21:38.116 --> 00:21:42.251
I'm sure there's a code name for that
one too, LAUGH] ..9, that tells it hey,

433
00:21:42.251 --> 00:21:45.655
this is not just one, this is not
just nine, it's one through nine.

434
00:21:45.655 --> 00:21:46.350
>> A range.

435
00:21:46.350 --> 00:21:51.970
>> And by doing that range, I can take
a look, and there's memo1 through memo9.

436
00:21:51.970 --> 00:21:55.500
So if I need to create a large quantity
of files, or, usually it's folders,

437
00:21:55.500 --> 00:22:00.230
a large quantity of folders, it's pretty
easy to that through command expansion and

438
00:22:00.230 --> 00:22:01.160
be able to work with that.

439
00:22:01.160 --> 00:22:04.500
Also with removing files, if you're
trying to remove files that have a date

440
00:22:04.500 --> 00:22:07.050
in their name, you can use this to
kind of grab those real quick and

441
00:22:07.050 --> 00:22:10.570
delete them or move them somewhere else,
it's a really neat thing to do and

442
00:22:10.570 --> 00:22:13.450
very handy when working with
files especially in bulk.

443
00:22:13.450 --> 00:22:15.720
So definitely it's something I wanted
to highlight here in this episode.

444
00:22:15.720 --> 00:22:17.410
>> And we learned about curly braces.

445
00:22:17.410 --> 00:22:20.900
>> Yeah curly braces,
curly brackets, squiggly, whatever,

446
00:22:20.900 --> 00:22:21.850
I don't know what they are.

00:22:21.850 --> 00:22:24.220
>> It all works
>> Dead snakes, something,

whatever they [LAUGH].

>> [LAUGH] Becoming a Linux power user.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:02.648
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.648 --> 00:00:10.620
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:10.620 --> 00:00:14.228
>> Hello again and
thank you for choosing ITProTV,

4
00:00:14.228 --> 00:00:17.140
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:17.140 --> 00:00:21.250
I'm your host, Zach Memos, as we continue
on with becoming a Linux power user.

6
00:00:21.250 --> 00:00:24.770
This is gonna be file system permissions.

7
00:00:24.770 --> 00:00:28.290
So it's important information
coming your way from Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:28.290 --> 00:00:29.060
Hello there, sir.

9
00:00:29.060 --> 00:00:30.280
>> Thanks for having me back, Zach.

10
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:31.730
Yeah, ready to dive right in.

11
00:00:31.730 --> 00:00:34.723
In this episode, we're gonna talk a little
bit about our files and folders again,

12
00:00:34.723 --> 00:00:36.195
cuz we're focusing on the file system.

13
00:00:36.195 --> 00:00:40.668
And the permissions that are assigned to
everything, that control who has access to

14
00:00:40.668 --> 00:00:44.050
what, because a Linux system
is supposed to be more secure.

15
00:00:44.050 --> 00:00:44.910
How do we achieve that?

16
00:00:44.910 --> 00:00:46.620
Well, through security and permissions.

17
00:00:46.620 --> 00:00:49.055
That's what we've got coming
up right here in this episode.

18
00:00:49.055 --> 00:00:51.580
>> Now, when you're talking about
permissions and we're looking at your

19
00:00:51.580 --> 00:00:55.545
screen and whatnot, there appears to be
a bunch of extraneous things going on.

20
00:00:55.545 --> 00:00:57.380
>> [LAUGH]
>> It doesn't really

21
00:00:57.380 --> 00:00:58.570
quite make sense to me.

22
00:00:58.570 --> 00:01:00.590
I mean, are those permissions,
what is all that?

23
00:01:00.590 --> 00:01:03.340
>> Okay, it is confusing,
the way the screen output is.

24
00:01:03.340 --> 00:01:06.030
But once you understand what's on the
screen, it actually makes a lot of sense.

25
00:01:06.030 --> 00:01:07.870
But at first glance,
it's really confusing.

26
00:01:07.870 --> 00:01:10.650
You guys are probably seen me do this
in the early episodes, let me show you.

27
00:01:10.650 --> 00:01:13.330
If I pull up just a regular
directory listing,

28
00:01:13.330 --> 00:01:17.680
like maybe I go into the binary folder and
I pull up a listing, well there it is.

29
00:01:17.680 --> 00:01:19.790
It's colorized, it's nice and pretty.

30
00:01:19.790 --> 00:01:21.230
I can see these files.

31
00:01:21.230 --> 00:01:23.430
And that's usually all I care about.

32
00:01:23.430 --> 00:01:26.820
But sometimes I want to see more, I want
to see like the size of the files and

33
00:01:26.820 --> 00:01:28.620
I want to see hidden files and things.

34
00:01:28.620 --> 00:01:34.758
And so on the show, I'll typically run and
in real life too, ls -lah.

35
00:01:34.758 --> 00:01:39.318
The -l shows me the long format,
that's gonna show me the file size and

36
00:01:39.318 --> 00:01:43.630
the modified date, a means show
me all files even hidden ones.

37
00:01:43.630 --> 00:01:48.880
And h means make the file sizes human
readable instead of showing them in bytes,

38
00:01:48.880 --> 00:01:53.050
show them in megabytes or
gigabytes, the larger file sizes.

39
00:01:53.050 --> 00:01:55.830
And when I do that,
>> I get a very different

40
00:01:55.830 --> 00:01:57.030
file directory listing.

41
00:01:57.030 --> 00:01:59.430
And I know I've used
this in several episodes.

42
00:01:59.430 --> 00:02:02.640
If I just wanna see file names, well there
they are, and they're still nice and

43
00:02:02.640 --> 00:02:06.190
organized alphabetically and
still pretty, they've got their colors.

44
00:02:06.190 --> 00:02:11.210
The file sizes make a lot more sense,
here's 43K versus 4 bytes.

45
00:02:11.210 --> 00:02:16.140
So I can kinda get an idea of how big
these are in a more reasonable number.

46
00:02:16.140 --> 00:02:20.540
But then to the left all this other stuff,

47
00:02:20.540 --> 00:02:22.680
what's effectively half the screen for
most of these guys.

48
00:02:22.680 --> 00:02:24.280
>> There's other stuff there [LAUGH].

49
00:02:24.280 --> 00:02:28.965
>> It looks like a jumbled mess,
well those are the file permission.

50
00:02:28.965 --> 00:02:33.055
Those are what dictate who's allowed to
touch this file, and if they touch it,

51
00:02:33.055 --> 00:02:34.945
what are they allowed to do with it.

52
00:02:34.945 --> 00:02:36.745
Are they allowed to edit it it?

53
00:02:36.745 --> 00:02:38.105
Can they just look at it?

54
00:02:38.105 --> 00:02:41.235
Can they run it if it's a program,
or can they do nothing at all?

55
00:02:41.235 --> 00:02:43.635
That's all coded right
here in this first half.

56
00:02:43.635 --> 00:02:44.765
It's not even that hard a code.

57
00:02:44.765 --> 00:02:49.010
Once you understand the components,
it all makes sense.

58
00:02:49.010 --> 00:02:52.050
What were actually looking at
are three pieces of information.

59
00:02:53.110 --> 00:02:56.228
There is a user attached to every
single file in your system, and

60
00:02:56.228 --> 00:03:00.183
that user's called the owner, they're
the person responsible for that file.

61
00:03:00.183 --> 00:03:04.270
And normally, they'll have the ability
to do whatever they want to that file.

62
00:03:04.270 --> 00:03:08.790
Then, you have a group assigned to a file.

63
00:03:08.790 --> 00:03:10.500
I keep saying file,
this is folders as well,

64
00:03:10.500 --> 00:03:12.410
it applies to both files and folders.

65
00:03:12.410 --> 00:03:15.445
And that group,
well that's a group of people,

66
00:03:15.445 --> 00:03:18.050
that they have access to that file or
folder.

67
00:03:18.050 --> 00:03:21.450
And then lastly, you have everybody else.

68
00:03:21.450 --> 00:03:23.910
Everybody else, what do they get?

69
00:03:23.910 --> 00:03:28.980
So in the Unix world,
this is called the user, the group and

70
00:03:28.980 --> 00:03:33.448
the others, UGO, user, group, others.

71
00:03:33.448 --> 00:03:37.600
Now user you'll hear often time called
owner, cuz they own the file, but

72
00:03:37.600 --> 00:03:40.200
owner gets confusing cuz o and o.

73
00:03:40.200 --> 00:03:43.960
Well, others sometimes
gets called everyone or e,

74
00:03:43.960 --> 00:03:46.460
but that's not how the lettering
works in the system, so

75
00:03:46.460 --> 00:03:50.480
the official names are the user,
the group, and the other.

76
00:03:51.600 --> 00:03:54.770
User will almost always have
full access to the file.

77
00:03:54.770 --> 00:03:59.700
The group not so much, and then the other
may not have access at all or maybe

78
00:03:59.700 --> 00:04:03.640
a public file that I want everyone to have
access to, it's up to me to dictate that.

79
00:04:03.640 --> 00:04:06.150
So, when I look at this screen,

80
00:04:06.150 --> 00:04:11.640
on the very left side here I'm seeing the
permissions that are being assigned out.

81
00:04:11.640 --> 00:04:15.000
And what you'll actually see
are ten different values.

82
00:04:15.000 --> 00:04:17.170
Some of them will have all
ten values filled out.

83
00:04:17.170 --> 00:04:20.450
If you look at this one right here, let
me zoom in a little bit on that, there.

84
00:04:20.450 --> 00:04:23.620
So see how it's got lrwxrwxrwx.

85
00:04:24.650 --> 00:04:30.370
Well that first letter is an l, and
that l is telling me that this a link.

86
00:04:30.370 --> 00:04:31.440
It's not a real file.

87
00:04:31.440 --> 00:04:34.390
See how the file is light blue and
it's got an arrow.

88
00:04:34.390 --> 00:04:38.180
It's saying the ypdomainename is actually
linked the the hostname command.

89
00:04:38.180 --> 00:04:41.280
If I run ypdomainename it's
just gonna run hostname.

90
00:04:41.280 --> 00:04:44.228
So it's a link is what that
first entry is indicating.

91
00:04:44.228 --> 00:04:47.250
That's important cuz there may be
permissions on the original file that

92
00:04:47.250 --> 00:04:48.970
aren't here on the link.

93
00:04:48.970 --> 00:04:54.160
I might also see a d, d is for directory
if this was a folder and not a file.

94
00:04:54.160 --> 00:04:57.590
But if I see a dash that mean's
the value is not set and

95
00:04:57.590 --> 00:04:59.070
that means that this is a file.

96
00:04:59.070 --> 00:05:02.330
An individual file will have a dash,
a directory will have a d.

97
00:05:02.330 --> 00:05:04.040
Those are the two values
that we normally see.

98
00:05:05.360 --> 00:05:09.570
Now, the rest of this
are the actual permissions, and

99
00:05:09.570 --> 00:05:11.830
they're broken up into groups of three.

100
00:05:11.830 --> 00:05:15.504
So the first three are the permissions
tied to the user or the owner.

101
00:05:15.504 --> 00:05:19.262
The next three are tied to the group.

102
00:05:19.262 --> 00:05:26.170
And the next three after that,
are tied to the other, or everyone else.

103
00:05:26.170 --> 00:05:27.210
That's what those mean.

104
00:05:27.210 --> 00:05:30.490
Those nine values right there
are the three permissions for

105
00:05:30.490 --> 00:05:32.780
the user, the group and the other.

106
00:05:33.910 --> 00:05:37.890
Well, the other, that's everyone else,
that makes sense, but who is the user and

107
00:05:37.890 --> 00:05:39.060
who is the group?

108
00:05:39.060 --> 00:05:40.370
And that's what comes up after that.

109
00:05:40.370 --> 00:05:44.850
Notice on these files,
root is the user and root is the group.

110
00:05:44.850 --> 00:05:50.450
So the root user account is the only
one that has user and group access.

111
00:05:50.450 --> 00:05:53.110
Everybody else falls onto
the other side of things.

112
00:05:53.110 --> 00:05:55.073
And, if you look at these permissions,
well,

113
00:05:55.073 --> 00:05:57.294
what they mean is actually
pretty straight forward.

114
00:05:57.294 --> 00:06:01.960
R is read,
they're allowed to read the file.

115
00:06:01.960 --> 00:06:06.290
They open it and look at it, they can't
change it, they can just look at it.

116
00:06:06.290 --> 00:06:10.210
W is write, not only can they look at it,
they can modify,

117
00:06:10.210 --> 00:06:12.000
they can change what's inside of the file.

118
00:06:12.000 --> 00:06:13.470
They can write to it.

119
00:06:13.470 --> 00:06:18.710
And then x is execute,
if it's a program, they can run it.

120
00:06:18.710 --> 00:06:21.188
Now, if it's a text file they
will execute permission on it,

121
00:06:21.188 --> 00:06:22.480
it's not gonna do anything.

122
00:06:22.480 --> 00:06:25.894
It needs to be script or a program but
if it has execute you can then run it and

123
00:06:25.894 --> 00:06:27.490
execute that application.

124
00:06:27.490 --> 00:06:34.020
So, rwx, the root user can read,
write and execute this command.

125
00:06:34.020 --> 00:06:39.220
The root group, which none of us
are a part of, can read and execute,

126
00:06:39.220 --> 00:06:44.220
but then everybody else,
the other, has read and execute.

127
00:06:44.220 --> 00:06:47.600
And that means that if I'm just
a regular user on this system I'm

128
00:06:47.600 --> 00:06:49.270
gonna fall under other.

129
00:06:49.270 --> 00:06:52.130
And I will be able to read in
this case the which command.

130
00:06:52.130 --> 00:06:56.470
I will be able to read that command and
I be able to execute it, which

131
00:06:56.470 --> 00:07:01.820
we can see I've run it in several episodes
where I do something like which ls.

132
00:07:01.820 --> 00:07:05.320
I can run the command, but
I can't edit it and that's important.

133
00:07:05.320 --> 00:07:09.440
Because if I was a hacker I could
modify the which command, or

134
00:07:09.440 --> 00:07:12.350
I could modify ls or whatever and
make it do bad things.

135
00:07:12.350 --> 00:07:14.910
And then when the root user runs it,
it's now running as root and

136
00:07:14.910 --> 00:07:16.780
they can do all sorts of
damage to the system.

137
00:07:16.780 --> 00:07:21.000
So those permissions are really important
to get set right, and put in place and

138
00:07:21.000 --> 00:07:22.240
protecting our system.

139
00:07:22.240 --> 00:07:23.785
>> And I notice that we're using letters.

140
00:07:23.785 --> 00:07:24.600
>> Yes.

141
00:07:24.600 --> 00:07:27.130
>> But can we use numbers?

142
00:07:27.130 --> 00:07:30.550
>> You can, so
thankfully we're using letters.

143
00:07:30.550 --> 00:07:33.850
In the olden days we didn't have
[LAUGH] we didn't have shoes,

144
00:07:33.850 --> 00:07:37.180
we had to walk uphill to school both ways.

145
00:07:37.180 --> 00:07:39.930
In the olden days, we had numbers.

146
00:07:39.930 --> 00:07:42.330
And the numbers indicated the permissions.

147
00:07:42.330 --> 00:07:44.280
And you had to memorize this little table.

148
00:07:44.280 --> 00:07:46.720
Fortunately we don't have to do that,

So a user can override this, but this is
where they system defaults come from.

369
00:19:27.030 --> 00:19:30.780
I don't think I've ever here in
production modified this default.

370
00:19:30.780 --> 00:19:33.703
But if you do, here's where you
do it basically globally for

371
00:19:33.703 --> 00:19:36.529
everybody, but
it can still be overridden for the users.

372
00:19:36.529 --> 00:19:37.430
So just be aware of that.

373
00:19:37.430 --> 00:19:40.760
If it doesn't work for you quite right in
the field, double check the user profiles,

374
00:19:40.760 --> 00:19:42.530
make sure they haven't
overridden it there.

375
00:19:43.830 --> 00:19:49.360
All right, so that's where
the permissions come from, but the owner,

376
00:19:49.360 --> 00:19:53.250
the user, and the group, those are being
assigned as a default value as well.

377
00:19:53.250 --> 00:19:56.880
And we can jump in and we can start
to modify and tweak those too.

378
00:19:56.880 --> 00:19:59.580
So we've got a couple of commands
that are available to do that.

379
00:19:59.580 --> 00:20:01.790
And let me just show you those real quick.

380
00:20:01.790 --> 00:20:05.641
The command I showed you
earlier was chmod, change mode,

381
00:20:05.641 --> 00:20:09.420
and now let's just go in and
modify permissions.

382
00:20:09.420 --> 00:20:14.482
But there's two other commands
that are very similar,

383
00:20:14.482 --> 00:20:17.936
there's chown, and there is chgrp.

384
00:20:17.936 --> 00:20:20.340
chown is change owner, right.

385
00:20:20.340 --> 00:20:23.494
So that the user that owns the file,
we can change that.

386
00:20:23.494 --> 00:20:28.090
And chgrp is change group, so
we can modify the group that owns it.

387
00:20:28.090 --> 00:20:32.350
So when I look at my permissions,
I've got three sets of data here.

388
00:20:32.350 --> 00:20:34.060
I've got the permissions.

389
00:20:34.060 --> 00:20:37.830
Followed by the user,
followed by the group, and

390
00:20:37.830 --> 00:20:41.550
I've got three commands because it
would be too hard to have one command.

391
00:20:41.550 --> 00:20:46.337
So we've got chmod or change mode for
the permissions, chown or

392
00:20:46.337 --> 00:20:51.850
change owner for the owner, and
chgroup for change group, right there.

393
00:20:51.850 --> 00:20:54.810
Three different commands that
let me easily modify that.

394
00:20:54.810 --> 00:20:59.900
So, if I decide, for example,
that I'm the owner of a file,

395
00:20:59.900 --> 00:21:04.450
or what happens a lot of times is
people will be sudo-ing things, right?

396
00:21:04.450 --> 00:21:08.240
Sudo is the superuser do,
which means I'm gonna run a command, but

397
00:21:08.240 --> 00:21:10.630
I wanna run it as the root user, right?

398
00:21:10.630 --> 00:21:13.060
So if I do, who am I?

399
00:21:13.060 --> 00:21:14.500
I'm dpezet, right?

400
00:21:14.500 --> 00:21:18.290
But if I sudo who am I,
and I run that, who am I?

401
00:21:18.290 --> 00:21:20.360
I'm root, I'm now an administrator.

402
00:21:20.360 --> 00:21:25.250
So I might be sudo-ing something,
and maybe just a file listing,

403
00:21:26.430 --> 00:21:30.510
and I pipe the output of that
command into something else.

404
00:21:31.710 --> 00:21:35.930
So maybe I do a sudo ls, and
I'll pipe that in to t, and

405
00:21:39.930 --> 00:21:43.500
I'll just do it right here,
I'll put text like that, okay.

406
00:21:43.500 --> 00:21:46.010
So I just output some information,
I dumped it into a file, and

407
00:21:46.010 --> 00:21:50.330
if I take a look at output.text,
shoot, the t command rehends me.

408
00:21:50.330 --> 00:21:51.699
Let me do this a little
bit different here.

409
00:21:51.699 --> 00:21:55.422
I'm gonna do,
let me remove output.text here.

410
00:21:55.422 --> 00:21:59.962
I'll do sudo touch output.text.

411
00:21:59.962 --> 00:22:04.580
There, okay so when I create that file,
who created it?

412
00:22:04.580 --> 00:22:06.740
Well normally it would be me, but

413
00:22:06.740 --> 00:22:10.380
because I was sudo-ing,
I was running things as the root user.

414
00:22:10.380 --> 00:22:14.250
So now when I look at it,
who's the owner and who's the group?

415
00:22:14.250 --> 00:22:16.290
The root user, not me.

416
00:22:16.290 --> 00:22:17.690
Well I didn't intend for
that to happen, right?

417
00:22:17.690 --> 00:22:20.730
I was just trying to run something,
I needed administrative privileges.

418
00:22:20.730 --> 00:22:25.270
I wanted this file for
me, but I didn't do it.

419
00:22:25.270 --> 00:22:28.540
Earlier when I ran the t command, the t
command actually ran under my context,

420
00:22:28.540 --> 00:22:31.830
I could have sudo the t command and
that would have achieved the same thing.

421
00:22:31.830 --> 00:22:35.000
But basically here,
I need to change that owner and

422
00:22:35.000 --> 00:22:36.610
I really need to change that group.

423
00:22:36.610 --> 00:22:40.230
And so I can say chown,
to change the owner, and

424
00:22:40.230 --> 00:22:43.100
then I can specify who I want this to be.

425
00:22:43.100 --> 00:22:45.690
Now, in this case I want it to be me.

426
00:22:45.690 --> 00:22:49.071
So I'll say chown dpezet, and
I need to specify the file or

427
00:22:49.071 --> 00:22:51.910
files, cuz I might be
changing multiple files.

428
00:22:51.910 --> 00:22:55.802
In this case,
it's just output .txt, all right.

429
00:22:55.802 --> 00:22:59.200
And so I'm gonna change that owner now,
when I want to do what do I get?

430
00:22:59.200 --> 00:23:00.080
Operation not permitted.

431
00:23:01.250 --> 00:23:08.250
Because I'm not the owner, I am considered
other, and other can only read.

432
00:23:08.250 --> 00:23:10.340
I don't have permission to do it.

433
00:23:10.340 --> 00:23:12.520
So you have to have permission
to the file to change.

434
00:23:12.520 --> 00:23:14.860
Otherwise, anybody can become
the owner of any file and

435
00:23:14.860 --> 00:23:16.200
now permissions serve no purpose.

436
00:23:16.200 --> 00:23:17.990
You can gain access to
whatever you wanted.

437
00:23:17.990 --> 00:23:19.660
So I'm gonna have to sudo this one.

438
00:23:21.180 --> 00:23:24.160
Because the super user,
the root user can override anybody, right?

439
00:23:24.160 --> 00:23:25.240
That's why they're super.

440
00:23:25.240 --> 00:23:28.370
So when I do that,
now the command succeeds, and

441
00:23:28.370 --> 00:23:30.600
I can see that I'm now the owner.

442
00:23:30.600 --> 00:23:34.160
The group is still wrong right,
so I can use chgroup to fix that.

443
00:23:34.160 --> 00:23:40.060
If I do chgroup and
I wanna change that to my group, right?

444
00:23:40.060 --> 00:23:41.110
So I'm just gonna make it mine or

445
00:23:41.110 --> 00:23:43.410
maybe I want it to be
the administrator's group right?

446
00:23:43.410 --> 00:23:47.288
So I'll get an admin group, adm,
and so I'll say chgroup adm.

447
00:23:47.288 --> 00:23:49.904
And my dpezet account is
not in the root group, but

448
00:23:49.904 --> 00:23:53.284
I am in the adm group cuz I'm
an administrator for this machine.

449
00:23:53.284 --> 00:23:57.789
So I'm gonna say change group adm, and
then I'll specify that output.text file,

450
00:23:57.789 --> 00:23:58.430
like that.

451
00:23:58.430 --> 00:24:01.038
Now I didn't get a permission
error this time.

452
00:24:01.038 --> 00:24:04.202
I got one a minute ago because
I wasn't the route user, but

453
00:24:04.202 --> 00:24:07.750
now I'm overriding route and
it's not asking.

454
00:24:07.750 --> 00:24:09.190
Because I am the owner.

455
00:24:09.190 --> 00:24:12.210
The owner permissions always
take precedence, right?

456
00:24:12.210 --> 00:24:13.890
You're the owner,
you can do whatever you want.

457
00:24:13.890 --> 00:24:15.045
Well within limits.

458
00:24:15.045 --> 00:24:18.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> So now I'm changing that group and

459
00:24:18.490 --> 00:24:20.760
if I take a look at it it's succeeded and

460
00:24:20.760 --> 00:24:25.190
now ADM is the group that
is attached to the file.

461
00:24:25.190 --> 00:24:28.240
And I can put other people, I can take
Zach and put him in the ADM group.

462
00:24:28.240 --> 00:24:31.620
And now he'll have well,
sadly just read permission right but

463
00:24:31.620 --> 00:24:33.750
if I gave him more permission
to it he'd have that access.

464
00:24:33.750 --> 00:24:36.778
So I can use those groups to give other
people access to the file, right?

465
00:24:36.778 --> 00:24:42.320
Now, using changed group and
changed owner.

466
00:24:42.320 --> 00:24:46.750
Typically we're changing a single file,
but you might actually have nested files,

467
00:24:46.750 --> 00:24:51.060
so, like if I have test two and
I switch it to test two,

468
00:24:51.060 --> 00:24:52.905
maybe have another directory in here.

469
00:24:52.905 --> 00:24:55.680
Whoops.

470
00:24:55.680 --> 00:25:03.030
Test three, and in here I have
a file called file dot text, okay?

471
00:25:03.030 --> 00:25:09.000
And let's say that I want to change all
of this to have the group of ADM, okay?

472
00:25:09.000 --> 00:25:14.280
Well if I do a CH group,
ADM dot slash star, right?

473
00:25:14.280 --> 00:25:18.420
I'm saying change everything in
this folder to have a group of ADM.

474
00:25:18.420 --> 00:25:21.340
When I run that It works.

475
00:25:21.340 --> 00:25:23.120
Everyone's got a group ADM.

476
00:25:23.120 --> 00:25:28.150
But when I start navigating down into
the tree, it didn't go very far, did it?

477
00:25:28.150 --> 00:25:30.840
It only got everything that
was literally in that folder.

478
00:25:30.840 --> 00:25:35.580
So all of these commands have a -R tag.

479
00:25:35.580 --> 00:25:38.030
If you do the command line argument -R?

480
00:25:38.030 --> 00:25:39.040
It makes recursive.

481
00:25:39.040 --> 00:25:41.610
And they'll dig down
into those sub folders.

482
00:25:41.610 --> 00:25:43.880
And they'll fix the permissions
all the way along that tree.

483
00:25:43.880 --> 00:25:45.470
So if you ever wanna do it that way.

484
00:25:45.470 --> 00:25:46.850
Remember that -R.

485
00:25:46.850 --> 00:25:48.620
And I did a dash capital R.

486
00:25:48.620 --> 00:25:50.710
Dash capital R works
in all three commands.

487
00:25:50.710 --> 00:25:53.360
CHMOD, CHOWN CHGRP.

488
00:25:53.360 --> 00:25:54.660
Dash lower case R?

489
00:25:54.660 --> 00:25:55.590
Works in most of them.

490
00:25:55.590 --> 00:25:56.630
And I can never remember which one.

491
00:25:56.630 --> 00:25:59.070
One of them doesn't have dash lowercase R.

492
00:25:59.070 --> 00:26:01.210
So I've gotten in the habit of
using dash capital R because

493
00:26:01.210 --> 00:26:02.400
I know it works everywhere.

494
00:26:02.400 --> 00:26:07.403
And now if I go into test two, even
all the way down into test three I can

495
00:26:07.403 --> 00:26:12.460
see that those permissions trickle
all the way down into that tree.

496
00:26:12.460 --> 00:26:13.780
And while we're talking about shortcuts.

497
00:26:13.780 --> 00:26:15.790
Let me just show you one more shortcut.

498
00:26:15.790 --> 00:26:18.050
I'm running low on time,
Zach's giving me the eye.

499
00:26:18.050 --> 00:26:19.250
So let me do one more shortcut.

500
00:26:19.250 --> 00:26:21.190
>> Shortcuts are important.

501
00:26:21.190 --> 00:26:23.050
>> I don't usually use change group.

502
00:26:23.050 --> 00:26:24.660
All right because CHMOD?

503
00:26:24.660 --> 00:26:27.392
Can actually change the group as well.

504
00:26:27.392 --> 00:26:32.676
So CHGRP is somewhat of a redundant
command, I use CHMOD to modify both.

505
00:26:32.676 --> 00:26:33.737
With CHMOD?

506
00:26:33.737 --> 00:26:37.740
You can actually take a file,
let's say I changed my mind and

507
00:26:37.740 --> 00:26:43.100
I want a file to be owned by the root
user and the root group, okay?

508
00:26:43.100 --> 00:26:45.960
I could come in and I could take that
output file, I'll have to sudo this.

509
00:26:45.960 --> 00:26:48.773
Actually, yeah well,
I'll sudo it just to be on the safe side.

510
00:26:48.773 --> 00:26:51.202
I'm gonna use CHOWN.

511
00:26:51.202 --> 00:26:53.281
You know what I think I
said CHMOD a minute ago.

512
00:26:53.281 --> 00:26:53.987
>> CHMOD.

513
00:26:53.987 --> 00:26:56.475
>> Sorry I meant CHOWN that
we can change the owner and

514
00:26:56.475 --> 00:26:58.740
specify these things at the same time.

515
00:26:58.740 --> 00:27:00.910
Not CHMOD I wanna clarify that.

516
00:27:00.910 --> 00:27:04.370
So I can say CHOWN and
then I can specify the user.

517
00:27:04.370 --> 00:27:08.720
Maybe I want that to be root and
then a colon and the group.

518
00:27:08.720 --> 00:27:12.430
I can specify the user and the group
at the same time by using that colon.

519
00:27:12.430 --> 00:27:17.080
And now I can specify output.text and

520
00:27:17.080 --> 00:27:21.180
it goes in and
it modifies the user and the group.

521
00:27:21.180 --> 00:27:23.218
And so there I can see it modified it and

522
00:27:23.218 --> 00:27:25.960
you can even use it to
modify just the group.

523
00:27:25.960 --> 00:27:29.930
Maybe I don't want the group to be route,
I want the group to be admin, right?

524
00:27:29.930 --> 00:27:34.070
So I can take that command and
instead of saying user colon group,

525
00:27:34.070 --> 00:27:37.170
I can just say colon group, right?

526
00:27:37.170 --> 00:27:39.090
I'm going to leave the user off.

527
00:27:39.090 --> 00:27:41.850
Leaving the user off says,
leave it at whatever it already is.

528
00:27:41.850 --> 00:27:43.010
Mine's already at route.

529
00:27:43.010 --> 00:27:46.270
And so now it's just gonna change
the group by doing that colon.

530
00:27:46.270 --> 00:27:47.820
And when I take a look at it now?

531
00:27:47.820 --> 00:27:49.330
Just the group changed.

532
00:27:49.330 --> 00:27:54.660
So, in the textbook definition of
it we have CHGRP, that you can use.

533
00:27:54.660 --> 00:27:59.410
But in practice I rarely use CHGRP,
instead I just use CHOWN.

534
00:27:59.410 --> 00:28:01.480
And you can specify the user and
group or one and

535
00:28:01.480 --> 00:28:04.110
the other by using that colon
to designate the group.

536
00:28:04.110 --> 00:28:06.288
And you get it right there
in a single command and

537
00:28:06.288 --> 00:28:07.610
it makes it a little bit easier.

538
00:28:07.610 --> 00:28:08.940
>> Shortcuts are nice.

539
00:28:08.940 --> 00:28:12.295
>> Yeah, absolutely, anything you can
do to save time and reduce typos.

540
00:28:12.295 --> 00:28:15.050
[LAUGH]
>> Wonderful job as usual, sir.

541
00:28:15.050 --> 00:28:18.750
Becoming a Linux Power User,
this has been Filesystem Permissions.

542
00:28:18.750 --> 00:28:22.270
And there's a whole bunch of videos
in the Becoming a Linux Power User,

543
00:28:22.270 --> 00:28:25.120
make sure you watch all of them,
you'll be glad you did.

544
00:28:25.120 --> 00:28:27.700
And thank you for
watching ITProTV, remember,

545
00:28:27.700 --> 00:28:30.040
a good IT pro is always learning.

546
00:28:30.040 --> 00:28:30.940
I'm Zach Memos.

547
00:28:30.940 --> 00:28:31.610
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

548
00:28:31.610 --> 00:28:32.594
>> And we'll see you very soon.

549
00:28:32.594 --> 00:28:40.090
[MUSIC]

550
00:28:40.090 --> 00:28:43.059
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:01.291
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.291 --> 00:00:06.673
I'm your host Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.673 --> 00:00:08.233
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.233 --> 00:00:11.993
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.993 --> 00:00:14.926
>> Hello again and
thank you for choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.926 --> 00:00:17.270
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:17.270 --> 00:00:20.920
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue
on with becoming a LinuxPowerUser, and

8
00:00:20.920 --> 00:00:24.688
in this episode, we're looking at moving
some files, isn't that right, Don?

9
00:00:24.688 --> 00:00:25.557
>> That's right.

10
00:00:25.557 --> 00:00:29.113
Up until this point we keep dealing
with files from the file system.

11
00:00:29.113 --> 00:00:32.424
As a regular user, you don't have
to do it from the command line.

12
00:00:32.424 --> 00:00:35.351
You have this nice graphical user
interface in front of you and

13
00:00:35.351 --> 00:00:38.130
most things are just drag and
drop and that's that.

14
00:00:38.130 --> 00:00:41.748
But as a power user, we're oftentimes
having to do things from the command line

15
00:00:41.748 --> 00:00:44.502
interface, and files are rarely
where we want them to be, so

16
00:00:44.502 --> 00:00:48.292
we need to know how to manipulate them,
how to move them, copy them, delete them.

17
00:00:48.292 --> 00:00:50.495
That's a critical skill we need
to function with files, and

18
00:00:50.495 --> 00:00:52.525
we really haven't addressed
it in a previous episode,

19
00:00:52.525 --> 00:00:54.313
so we're gonna tackle it
right here in this one.

20
00:00:54.313 --> 00:00:54.827
>> Awesome.

21
00:00:54.827 --> 00:00:58.226
Yeah, because up to this point, we've
been creating permissions in files and

22
00:00:58.226 --> 00:01:01.552
what not, but now we're actually gonna
be able to put them somewhere of use.

23
00:01:01.552 --> 00:01:04.263
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah we've kind of been leaving things

24
00:01:04.263 --> 00:01:07.154
where they landed and
that gets messy really fast, right?

25
00:01:07.154 --> 00:01:09.290
>> Yeah.
So having some good organizational skills,

26
00:01:09.290 --> 00:01:11.610
getting things put in the right
spot it is a pretty handy thing.

27
00:01:11.610 --> 00:01:16.291
So let's kick things off with the good
old trusty Unix copy command.

28
00:01:16.291 --> 00:01:18.715
Now back in the olden days
when Unix was written,-

29
00:01:18.715 --> 00:01:19.947
>> Back in the olden days.

30
00:01:19.947 --> 00:01:22.095
>> Yeah it was all in the late 70s,
early 80s,

31
00:01:22.095 --> 00:01:25.115
they would really just take a command and
drop the vowels out of it.

32
00:01:25.115 --> 00:01:28.560
So, if I wanna copy something,
it's gonna be cp.

33
00:01:28.560 --> 00:01:31.170
It's a pretty safe guess as to
what a command is gonna be.

34
00:01:31.170 --> 00:01:35.070
For copying files from our command line,
that's exactly what we are gonna do.

35
00:01:35.070 --> 00:01:41.080
So, if you were to run man cp,
you could pull up the manual page for cp.

36
00:01:41.080 --> 00:01:43.130
There's not a whole heck
of a lot to this command.

37
00:01:43.130 --> 00:01:47.029
We're gonna copy from a source
to a destination, and

38
00:01:47.029 --> 00:01:50.332
that's basically all we need to know for
cp.

39
00:01:50.332 --> 00:01:53.756
If I take a look at my home directory,
I have a folder called notes and

40
00:01:53.756 --> 00:01:57.122
that's where I put a bunch of note files,
and for whatever reason I

41
00:01:57.122 --> 00:02:00.629
created a note and left it right here
on the root of my note directory.

42
00:02:00.629 --> 00:02:05.238
So I wanna copy that and get note21 into
the notes folder where it needs to be.

43
00:02:05.238 --> 00:02:09.687
If I look in the notes folder I've got

So rm, pretty straightforward, well,

258
00:15:28.959 --> 00:15:33.769
it's pretty straightforward except if
I try to remove a folder for example.

259
00:15:33.769 --> 00:15:38.413
Let's do rm test1, okay,
I can't remove it, test1 is a directory,

260
00:15:38.413 --> 00:15:40.945
all right, well that's pretty lame.

261
00:15:40.945 --> 00:15:47.115
If I want to remove a directory, I need
to make make this a recursive command,

262
00:15:47.115 --> 00:15:51.005
to make it recursive,
you add a dash R, just like cp, right?

263
00:15:51.005 --> 00:15:55.578
With cp, if I wanted to copy a folder and
everything underneath it you do a dash R,

264
00:15:55.578 --> 00:15:58.159
and when I run that now
it doesn't complain.

265
00:15:58.159 --> 00:16:00.499
And if I look, test1 is gone and

266
00:16:00.499 --> 00:16:05.722
all the folders underneath it
are gone too, test2, test3 and so on.

267
00:16:05.722 --> 00:16:10.106
So rm dash R will remove that
whole structure down beneath.

268
00:16:10.106 --> 00:16:11.800
Now, occasionally,

269
00:16:11.800 --> 00:16:17.520
you'll bump into a situation where it
doesn't let you do that, all right?

270
00:16:17.520 --> 00:16:20.110
You try and remove a folder,
and it warns you it's a folder.

271
00:16:20.110 --> 00:16:22.950
So you do -r, so rm -r and
it goes to delete it.

272
00:16:22.950 --> 00:16:27.553
And it may complain and say something
like the directory is not empty, or

273
00:16:27.553 --> 00:16:30.055
you don't have permissions to a file.

274
00:16:30.055 --> 00:16:31.782
But you've got permissions to the folder.

275
00:16:31.782 --> 00:16:34.950
Various things like that can
stop the command from working.

276
00:16:34.950 --> 00:16:37.258
So, there is one more little
flag that you can add.

277
00:16:37.258 --> 00:16:43.010
And hopefully, you don't have to do this,
but it's -f, and -f is the force command.

278
00:16:43.010 --> 00:16:45.800
Force says,
don't prompt me about problems,

279
00:16:45.800 --> 00:16:49.030
if I have the permission to destroy
the folder, then I wanna do it.

280
00:16:49.030 --> 00:16:51.200
And everything inside of it is gonna go,
also.

281
00:16:51.200 --> 00:16:54.376
So if you want to destroy
the files with extreme prejudice-

282
00:16:54.376 --> 00:16:55.446
>> [LAUGH]

283
00:16:55.446 --> 00:16:57.360
>> It's rm -f.

284
00:16:57.360 --> 00:17:02.320
And you'll see people mention this
stuff online a lot of times that

285
00:17:02.320 --> 00:17:05.240
this is a way that they
remove something or whatever.

286
00:17:05.240 --> 00:17:12.710
So, if I wanna get rid of that memo
folder, I can say, rm -rf memo.

287
00:17:12.710 --> 00:17:14.130
And now it's gonna get rid of it.

288
00:17:14.130 --> 00:17:15.720
And if there was anything in
there that gave me grief.

289
00:17:15.720 --> 00:17:17.649
As long as permissions
to the parent folder,

290
00:17:17.649 --> 00:17:20.170
it's gonna destroy what's inside of there,
too.

291
00:17:20.170 --> 00:17:23.820
That's a great way to ensure
that gets taken care of.

292
00:17:23.820 --> 00:17:27.020
Typically, there's these advanced archive
bits and things that get flagged and

293
00:17:27.020 --> 00:17:28.490
make files read-only.

294
00:17:28.490 --> 00:17:31.156
And if I've only got read-only
permission that's what would stop me and

295
00:17:31.156 --> 00:17:32.610
this will override that.

296
00:17:32.610 --> 00:17:35.890
A regular user can only really
do this in their home folder.

297
00:17:35.890 --> 00:17:38.293
But a root user can do this
anywhere in the file system.

298
00:17:38.293 --> 00:17:41.550
So you might have a process
that left some log files, and

299
00:17:41.550 --> 00:17:43.220
the log files can't be removed.

300
00:17:43.220 --> 00:17:45.290
Well, they can be if you force it.

301
00:17:45.290 --> 00:17:47.421
You might have the sudo the command,

302
00:17:47.421 --> 00:17:51.970
you'll to bump up to elevated privileges
to be able to do that and get in there.

303
00:17:51.970 --> 00:17:58.400
But at the end of the day cd, cp, sorry
not cd, we already talked about that one.

304
00:17:58.400 --> 00:18:02.500
Cp for copy, mv for
move and rm for remove.

305
00:18:02.500 --> 00:18:06.510
Those are all really handy ways to knock
this stuff out from the command line and

306
00:18:06.510 --> 00:18:07.505
move things around.

307
00:18:07.505 --> 00:18:11.620
Now, I will throw in one
thing here before I wrap up.

308
00:18:11.620 --> 00:18:16.560
Those three commands are always
present on every Linux system.

309
00:18:16.560 --> 00:18:19.040
They're considered built-ins,
you're going to have them.

310
00:18:19.040 --> 00:18:21.290
I believe they're actually
part of the GNU tool suite.

311
00:18:21.290 --> 00:18:25.876
We can find out if we do a which cp, mv.

312
00:18:25.876 --> 00:18:29.390
Well, they're all in /bin, so
they're part of my core OS.

313
00:18:29.390 --> 00:18:32.360
So even if I do a minimal install,
they're going to be there,

314
00:18:32.360 --> 00:18:34.030
you can assume those commands are there.

315
00:18:34.030 --> 00:18:35.884
But if you're working in
the command line a lot.

316
00:18:35.884 --> 00:18:40.181
And you're doing a ton of file
management these commands are useful.

317
00:18:40.181 --> 00:18:42.150
They're great for
scripting and automation.

318
00:18:42.150 --> 00:18:44.000
But if you're doing things by hand a lot,
there are some

319
00:18:44.000 --> 00:18:47.180
other tools that are available to
help you from the command line.

320
00:18:47.180 --> 00:18:49.960
Some that actually kind of cheat or

321
00:18:49.960 --> 00:18:52.429
push the boundaries of
being in the command line.

322
00:18:52.429 --> 00:18:55.990
One of my favorites is a utility
called Midnight Commander.

323
00:18:55.990 --> 00:18:59.230
Midnight Commander is available on every
Linux distro that I've ever touched.

324
00:18:59.230 --> 00:19:01.070
It's not installed by default
on most of them, though.

325
00:19:01.070 --> 00:19:03.410
You can install it on a Red Hat system.

326
00:19:03.410 --> 00:19:04.690
Here, let me show you.

327
00:19:04.690 --> 00:19:08.610
On a Red Hat system,
you would do a sudo yum install mc,

328
00:19:08.610 --> 00:19:11.770
that's the Midnight Commander.

329
00:19:11.770 --> 00:19:14.470
I'm on a Ubuntu or Debian based system.

330
00:19:14.470 --> 00:19:20.120
So for me,
I would say sudo apt install mc and

331
00:19:20.120 --> 00:19:21.960
that would install the Midnight Commander.

332
00:19:21.960 --> 00:19:23.130
I've already got it on mine.

333
00:19:23.130 --> 00:19:27.317
But once you have that installed from
the command line you can just run mc and

334
00:19:27.317 --> 00:19:29.588
it'll fire up the Midnight Commander.

335
00:19:29.588 --> 00:19:31.913
Which is a borderline
graphical user interface,

336
00:19:31.913 --> 00:19:34.830
except it's completely powered
from the command line.

337
00:19:34.830 --> 00:19:37.740
So I can be using an SSH session or
Telnet, or

338
00:19:37.740 --> 00:19:43.030
just drop to a terminal like I am,
and now I have multi-pane browsing.

339
00:19:43.030 --> 00:19:46.948
I can browse to one location on the left,
and a different location on the right.

340
00:19:46.948 --> 00:19:50.360
And down at the bottom of the screen,
you'll see we have keyboard shortcuts for

341
00:19:50.360 --> 00:19:53.780
copy, move, make directory, delete.

342
00:19:53.780 --> 00:19:58.320
I can easily do this in a much
more user-friendly method.

343
00:19:58.320 --> 00:20:03.100
It's still command line and we can still
run this on a headless server with no GUI.

344
00:20:03.100 --> 00:20:08.990
But it gives us a, shoot,
I forget what this is called,

345
00:20:08.990 --> 00:20:12.890
an emacs based type GUI here that
we use from the command line.

346
00:20:12.890 --> 00:20:16.610
So if you find that you're working
with files from the CLI a lot,

347
00:20:16.610 --> 00:20:18.460
check out Midnight Commander.

348
00:20:18.460 --> 00:20:23.310
Get it installed,
it's a neat program, it does its job.

349
00:20:23.310 --> 00:20:26.250
The shortcuts at the bottom,
these guys down here,

350
00:20:26.250 --> 00:20:28.590
these are actually mapped
to your function keys.

351
00:20:28.590 --> 00:20:29.870
So like 10 is quit.

352
00:20:29.870 --> 00:20:31.670
So that means hit function 10.

353
00:20:31.670 --> 00:20:34.321
Or copy is 5 or function 5.

354
00:20:34.321 --> 00:20:37.410
So I'm just gonna hit function 10 and
get out of that.

355
00:20:37.410 --> 00:20:39.845
But if you pull up the manual file from
Midnight Commander, it goes through.

356
00:20:39.845 --> 00:20:44.530
And it lays out all the information
you need to know on how to use it.

357
00:20:44.530 --> 00:20:46.520
It's even got some basic mal support, but

358
00:20:46.520 --> 00:20:48.616
you're not normally gonna be
able to take advantage of that.

359
00:20:48.616 --> 00:20:51.520
But definitely a handy you a utility
that you wanna double check and

360
00:20:51.520 --> 00:20:54.650
use if you work with files
from the command line a lot.

361
00:20:54.650 --> 00:20:57.666
The other alternative is
to use another station.

362
00:20:57.666 --> 00:20:59.150
I might have a headless
server with no GUI.

363
00:20:59.150 --> 00:21:02.319
I can go to my own laptop where
I do have a GUI and connect and

364
00:21:02.319 --> 00:21:04.350
manage files that way, too.

365
00:21:04.350 --> 00:21:06.100
It's often times faster.

366
00:21:06.100 --> 00:21:07.800
But when it comes to scripting and

367
00:21:07.800 --> 00:21:12.130
automation, if I want something to run
in a script, it's gonna be cp, mv, rm.

368
00:21:12.130 --> 00:21:14.820
The tools we took a look
at here in this episode.

369
00:21:14.820 --> 00:21:18.070
Those are the ones that are going
to make the most use out of.

370
00:21:18.070 --> 00:21:19.730
>> There you have it, moving files.

371
00:21:19.730 --> 00:21:22.530
And that's becoming a Linux power user.

372
00:21:22.530 --> 00:21:26.580
And there's a whole bunch of video
content on becoming a Linux power user.

373
00:21:26.580 --> 00:21:28.490
Make sure you catch every single episode.

374
00:21:28.490 --> 00:21:31.110
Once again, Don, excellent job,
thank you so much.

375
00:21:31.110 --> 00:21:32.683
And thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

376
00:21:32.683 --> 00:21:36.375
And remember,
a good IT pro is always learning.

377
00:21:36.375 --> 00:21:37.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm Zach Memos.

378
00:21:37.810 --> 00:21:38.630
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

379
00:21:38.630 --> 00:21:39.301
>> And we'll see you very soon.

380
00:21:43.674 --> 00:21:47.302
[MUSIC]

381
00:21:47.302 --> 00:21:49.718
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss different pronunciations of 'Vi,' what Vi is, other editing tools nano-jed-mcedit-emacs, Vi is now called 'Vim,' why choose to use Vi (Vim), and how powerful & useful Vi is when you learn the language.
episodes.title: Editing Files with Vi
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:02.084
Welcome to IT Pro TV I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.084 --> 00:00:08.232
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.232 --> 00:00:12.260
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.260 --> 00:00:14.940
>> Hello again and thank you for
choosing IT Pro TV,

5
00:00:14.940 --> 00:00:17.350
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.350 --> 00:00:21.560
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue
on with becoming a Linux power user.

7
00:00:21.560 --> 00:00:27.851
Interesting, interesting course today,
editing files with V, or VI.

8
00:00:27.851 --> 00:00:28.422
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

9
00:00:28.422 --> 00:00:32.086
Don is gonna help us understand this a
little bit more, how do you pronounce it,

10
00:00:32.086 --> 00:00:32.808

11
00:00:32.808 --> 00:00:34.730
[LAUGH]
>> So I am a bit of a stickler for

12
00:00:34.730 --> 00:00:36.810
pronunciation, and
we were talking about before this show.

13
00:00:36.810 --> 00:00:38.080
You really can't go wrong on this one,

14
00:00:38.080 --> 00:00:41.680
cuz there's no officially agreed
upon pronunciation for it.

15
00:00:41.680 --> 00:00:46.100
In this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at the text editor that I call V,

16
00:00:46.100 --> 00:00:47.250
as many other people do.

17
00:00:47.250 --> 00:00:50.660
Some people call it Vy, other people
call it VI, but whatever you call it,

18
00:00:50.660 --> 00:00:52.650
it's a very important text editor.

19
00:00:52.650 --> 00:00:54.373
If you are going to be a Linux power user,

20
00:00:54.373 --> 00:00:57.072
this is on that you are going to
encounter, you do need to know.

21
00:00:57.072 --> 00:00:59.026
And boy, is it not user-friendly, so

22
00:00:59.026 --> 00:01:02.937
we're gonna get a chance to see exactly
how this editor works, what it does and

23
00:01:02.937 --> 00:01:06.300
how we can overcome that un-user
friendliness that it provides.

24
00:01:06.300 --> 00:01:10.483
>> And there's some other editing
systems as well right I mean besides VI.

25
00:01:10.483 --> 00:01:15.110
>> Yeah, yeah for a regular user not
a power user we're all about power.

26
00:01:15.110 --> 00:01:18.500
For a regular user there are a whole
ton of editors out there that you can

27
00:01:18.500 --> 00:01:19.040
choose from.

28
00:01:19.040 --> 00:01:23.773
Many of which are way easier to use
than V, so you might be asking yourself,

29
00:01:23.773 --> 00:01:27.622
why the heck would I even use V
if it's such a pain in the butt?

30
00:01:27.622 --> 00:01:30.170
>> Don, may I ask why the heck
would I wanna use VI?

31
00:01:31.300 --> 00:01:35.320
>> Well, the main reason is it's
been around a long, long time.

32
00:01:35.320 --> 00:01:37.060
It's one of the original text editors,

33
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:41.960
it's said it's the original text editor,
but it has been around a long, long time.

34
00:01:41.960 --> 00:01:45.657
And as a result it is in almost
every single Linux distribution

35
00:01:45.657 --> 00:01:46.872
that's out there.

36
00:01:46.872 --> 00:01:51.181
So it's the one editor that you can count
on, and I used to say you could always

37
00:01:51.181 --> 00:01:55.293
count on it, but now there are a few
distros that started leaving it out for

38
00:01:55.293 --> 00:01:58.773
whatever reason, but
it is a very very powerful text editor.

39
00:01:58.773 --> 00:01:59.677
It has a ton of features,

40
00:01:59.677 --> 00:02:02.610
more features than most other
text editors that are out there.

41
00:02:02.610 --> 00:02:05.065
And it can run entirely text-based,

42
00:02:05.065 --> 00:02:08.451
it's not dependent on
a graphical user interface.

43
00:02:08.451 --> 00:02:13.742
If you got a GUI, then just use gedit,
gedit is a graphical editor.

44
00:02:13.742 --> 00:02:15.870
It lets you edit text files,
you can work with it.

45
00:02:15.870 --> 00:02:19.102
It uses menus, you use your mouse,
it couldn't be simpler.

46
00:02:19.102 --> 00:02:23.523
Right, but when you are remotely
connecting to a server that has no GUI,

47
00:02:23.523 --> 00:02:25.856
gedit doesn't work so well anymore.

48
00:02:25.856 --> 00:02:28.880
It won't run, and so
you are left with the command line.

49
00:02:28.880 --> 00:02:32.757
But even on the command line there are
some simpler ones, so for example here,

50
00:02:32.757 --> 00:02:34.472
I can show you a few editing types.

51
00:02:34.472 --> 00:02:38.874
Yeah, the other utilities,
are things like Nano is

52
00:02:38.874 --> 00:02:43.990
included in Fedora, and
Ubuntu, Debian, Linux Mint.

53
00:02:43.990 --> 00:02:48.361
It's not included in Red Hat, yet,
but you can install it if you want.

54
00:02:48.361 --> 00:02:50.090
Nano works right here
from the command line.

55
00:02:50.090 --> 00:02:53.134
I've got a little file here
we're gonna work with,

56
00:02:53.134 --> 00:02:56.185
The Legend of Sleepy Hollow,
an American classic.

57
00:02:56.185 --> 00:02:59.504
And so, if I want to edit it,
I can fire it right up and

58
00:02:59.504 --> 00:03:04.290
here we go I can jump right in and
start to edit and I can navigate around.

59
00:03:04.290 --> 00:03:06.613
It's giving me all my shortcuts
right down here at the bottom.

60
00:03:06.613 --> 00:03:11.260
So it's easy to remember what to do,
and I can exit out and work with it.

61
00:03:11.260 --> 00:03:14.050
Nano was one example, Jed is another one.

62
00:03:14.050 --> 00:03:18.140
Jed is not installed in most distros by
default, but you can add it really easy.

63
00:03:18.140 --> 00:03:22.680
And it lets you jump in there,
it kinda harkens back to the 1980s

64
00:03:22.680 --> 00:03:26.970
editors like what you'd see in DOS,
in the disk-based operating system.

65
00:03:26.970 --> 00:03:32.297
So you've got little menus up top that
you can navigate through and drop down.

66
00:03:32.297 --> 00:03:35.170
And so, again, you are not having
to remember keyboard shortcuts.

67
00:03:35.170 --> 00:03:37.871
The keyboard shortcuts are there, but
you don't have to remember them,.

68
00:03:37.871 --> 00:03:42.569
You can use these menus if you want, and
this is all working without a GUI, so

69
00:03:42.569 --> 00:03:46.180
it's not like I have to have
a window manager or anything.

70
00:03:47.280 --> 00:03:50.630
MCEdit is another one that's
available that you can jump in to.

71
00:03:50.630 --> 00:03:53.596
Same kind of idea,
except the menus are down at the bottom.

72
00:03:53.596 --> 00:03:57.267
And they're not really menus, they're
actually just individual commands that we

73
00:03:57.267 --> 00:03:59.055
fire up and you can get in and out.

74
00:03:59.055 --> 00:03:59.870
MCEdit is the part of

75
00:03:59.870 --> 00:04:02.310
the Midnight Commander that I've
shown in some other episodes.

76
00:04:02.310 --> 00:04:06.673
So if you've installed MC, you've also
got MCEdit and it's part of that package.

77
00:04:06.673 --> 00:04:09.970
There's some bunch of other ones
that are out there, like Emacs.

78
00:04:09.970 --> 00:04:14.051
Emacs I'm not gonna get into in this
episode, cuz it is insanely powerful.

79
00:04:14.051 --> 00:04:17.398
And if you're a typesetter,
if you're trying to create documents for

80
00:04:17.398 --> 00:04:20.802
a publishing house, Emacs has some
really powerful font management and

81
00:04:20.802 --> 00:04:21.822
margin management.

82
00:04:21.822 --> 00:04:26.039
And things go way beyond what we need
in a text editor to be able to modify

83
00:04:26.039 --> 00:04:27.471
configuration files.

84
00:04:27.471 --> 00:04:31.609
So while all those utilities are great,
they're not usually installed by default

85
00:04:31.609 --> 00:04:36.040
and they all carry a little overhead with
them, extra package that we installed.

86
00:04:36.040 --> 00:04:40.005
So the one that we can count on is simple,
it's basic,

87
00:04:40.005 --> 00:04:44.230
it's included in almost every distro and
it is VI, V-I,

88
00:04:44.230 --> 00:04:50.381
the text editor you can fire up, start to
modify files, and it's pretty powerful.

89
00:04:50.381 --> 00:04:51.654
>> And so then Don what is VIM?

90
00:04:51.654 --> 00:04:52.689
What is that?

91
00:04:52.689 --> 00:04:56.880
>> So VIM what you might notice that if I
just run VI, so I'm wanna drop to command

92
00:04:56.880 --> 00:05:03.340
prompt I'm wanna just write VI I
get VIM which is not a VI, right?

93
00:05:03.340 --> 00:05:06.850
VIM is actually a newer version,
so VI is very old.

94
00:05:06.850 --> 00:05:11.660
VIM is also very old too [LAUGH] but
not as old and it's VI improved, so

95
00:05:11.660 --> 00:05:13.520
they've added more to it.

96
00:05:13.520 --> 00:05:17.760
The original VI, it was very functional,
but it didn't do things like colors and

97
00:05:17.760 --> 00:05:18.900

00:16:19.730 --> 00:16:21.710
And it's going to to do that all at once.

329
00:16:21.710 --> 00:16:24.850
And so I didn't get any complaints
about the file changing

330
00:16:24.850 --> 00:16:27.480
because it actually wrote and then quit.

331
00:16:27.480 --> 00:16:30.380
And then going back to Zach's question
of could I open a different file

332
00:16:30.380 --> 00:16:31.350
or something?

333
00:16:31.350 --> 00:16:32.800
So I'm in file.txt.

334
00:16:32.800 --> 00:16:36.590
If I want to switch to file1.txt,
I could just quit.

335
00:16:36.590 --> 00:16:38.570
And then, run the vi command
to jump into the other one.

336
00:16:38.570 --> 00:16:42.421
But you can open other files by doing :e,

337
00:16:42.421 --> 00:16:46.780
:e to exchange this file for another one.

338
00:16:46.780 --> 00:16:49.940
And if I just run :e,
it doesn't really do anything, right?

339
00:16:49.940 --> 00:16:51.400
Because it just goes back to this one.

340
00:16:51.400 --> 00:16:53.945
So I would need to say :e file1.

341
00:16:53.945 --> 00:16:56.020
.txt, or whatever my other file is.

342
00:16:56.020 --> 00:16:57.960
And see here I jumped over to file1.txt.

343
00:16:57.960 --> 00:17:01.650
So I can quickly move over
without having to get out.

344
00:17:01.650 --> 00:17:04.640
So that's what really makes vi such
a powerful editor is there's so

345
00:17:04.640 --> 00:17:07.530
many shortcuts if we can learn them,
right?

346
00:17:07.530 --> 00:17:09.530
It's just a ton to grasp,
but you can be so

00:17:09.530 --> 00:17:12.580
much faster when you're doing easy
keyboard shortcuts to get things done.

Well, I mean,

00:17:24.710 --> 00:17:28.550

00:17:28.550 --> 00:17:31.050

00:17:31.050 --> 00:17:33.100

sheets that you can download and stick

For the first probably month

00:17:52.320 --> 00:17:55.980

00:17:55.980 --> 00:17:58.450
that's available regardless

Red Hat Enterprise Linux or Ubuntu or

00:18:03.270 --> 00:18:05.540

00:18:05.540 --> 00:18:06.210
>> That's a good one.

00:18:06.210 --> 00:18:07.540
>> And it's the first time I logged in.

00:18:07.540 --> 00:18:11.590
But I'll know there's a text editor that

00:18:11.590 --> 00:18:12.350
be able to work with.
